Toppling of Barad Gúlaran
You have been called upon to do all that needs to be done to close the gates of Barad Gúlaran forever.
Borndol once called the tower at Thangúlhad home. He was forced out before he could pack up his vast Black Speech poetry collection.
Ruithroval often loses competitions of speed and agility with the other drakes in Mirkwood and Dol Guldur. He stays and eats the feast while they race around the skies.
Azrí built many of the ballistae in use at Thangúlhad and has great respect for their power, though he has little respect for your aim.
Hokarul is on a mission to lay claim to the greatest pipe-weed and keep it all for himself...he has only recently heard of the Shire.
It takes a few large hits in the head before Grudom fully wakes up and is prepared to fight.
Frúzglob hates everything about siege-weaponry...give him a good sword and an enemy in front of him, and he is satisfied.
Golugthrug is one of the sneakier uruks in Mirkwood, stealth being his favourite weapon.
Lapus has spent many battles weaving through the lines to avoid the fire of catapults. He eagerly takes any chance he gets to destroy any of them.
Torúglup is a simple Warg, looking for nothing more than a good meal and a dry space to sleep at night.
Defeat Borndol
Defeat Ruithroval
Defeat Azrí
Defeat Hokarul
Defeat Grudom
Defeat Frúzglob
Defeat Golugthrug
Defeat Lapus
Defeat Torúglup
Protectors of Thangúlhad
Thangúlhad is an advance position of which the Golden Host has managed to wrest control from the forces of Dol Guldur.
Complete everything in the Protectors of Thangúlhad Skirmish
Thangaran is an apprentice to the master of Dol Guldur in all things.
The mistress of the tower, Iaerien, is a woman scorned by good and embraced by evil.
Hogaward is an emissary from the less organized brigand groups infesting the lands around Bree.
Múdku is fiercely protective of his weapons, even the dull, rusted ones.
Blord is not often allowed within the tower...his very footsteps cause the foundations to shudder.
Gundnákh is not the fastest of trolls, but eventually he will always catch up to his prey.
Gadhumúrz is one of the hunting Wargs of the tower's master. He feasts on the remains of all that he catches.
Urbor is curiously fascinated by flames of a blue nature.
Defeat Thangaran
Defeat Iaerien
Defeat Hogaward
Defeat Múdku
Defeat Blord
Defeat Gundnákh
Defeat Gadhumúrz
Defeat Urbor
The Battle in the Tower
The tower is the pinnacle of the fortress of Dol Guldur. Its terrible shadow casts darkness and dread over the forests of Mirkwood.
Complete everything in the Battle in the Tower Skirmish
Helchfaer often uses the ancient buildings of Dannenglor to conduct dark and secret offerings and sacrifices to the Dark Lord.
Ghostfang has eaten countless members of the Golden Host... the leg bones are his favourite treat.
Ruingalad only appears when flames lick the ruins of Dannenglor.
Swartclaw rules the roost of Dannenglor with an iron talon.
Rimdeloth is the mistress of Dannenglor and fiercely protective of what she has deemed to be hers.
Gorogmúl guards the bridge into Dannenglor, ever-watchful.
The majority of the spiders in Mirkwood can trace their lineage through the egg-sacs of Gothling.
The only thing Fiklúk likes less than an Elf is the sound of a horn.
Seregruin patrols through the ruins of Dannenglor, an ever-watchful guardian from a time long since past.
Defeat Helchfaer
Defeat Ghostfang
Defeat Ruingalad
Defeat Swartclaw
Defeat Rimdeloth
Defeat Gorogmúl
Defeat Gothling
Defeat Fiklúk
Defeat Seregruin

The ancient Elf-ruins of Dannenglor howl during the dark Mirkwood nights.

Surviving the Night
Only the most courageous -- or foolish -- adventurers would dare to endure the dread night of the Barrow-downs.
The sorcerers of Southern Mirkwood lend great strength to the Enemy, and pose a terrible threat to the safety of the Malledhrim as they press forward.
Defeat sorcerers in Southern Mirkwood
The servants of the Enemy are a formidable presence in Mirkwood as the Malledhrim press forward.
The Golden Host is ever-threatened by the presence of Black Númenórean sorcerers in and around Dol Guldur, lending their aid and fealty to the strength of the Enemy.
You have done much to hinder the foes of the Malledhrim, but the servants of the Enemy are many, and they are evil.
Defeat sorcerers in Southern Mirkwood
Sorcerer-slayer (Advanced)
The servants of the Enemy are a formidable presence in Mirkwood as the Malledhrim press forward.
The Golden Host is ever-threatened by the presence of Black Númenórean sorcerers in and around Dol Guldur, lending their aid and fealty to the strength of the Enemy.
The beasts of Mirkwood are powerful and terribly corrupted by the long presence of Dol Guldur in their midst. They hunt without mercy or necessity and harry the Malledhrim as they press ever forward.
Defeat beasts in Southern Mirkwood
The many predators of Mirkwood are as black as the night itself, corrupted by the long years of evil.
Many dark beasts terrorize the dense forest of Southern Mirkwood.

Mirkwood may never recover from the presence of the Necromancer, and it will never be wholly cleansed of the evil that was present for so long, but the corrupted beasts of this forest will know better than to stand in your way.
Defeat many beasts in Southern Mirkwood
Beast-slayer (Advanced)
The many predators of Mirkwood are as black as the night itself, corrupted by the long years of evil.
Many dark beasts terrorize the dense forest of Southern Mirkwood.
Faelathron spends all of his time worshipping the Dark Lord, praying for a glimmer of his power.
To prepare for battle, Mazaukgrat plays drums made from the skulls of his vanquished enemies.
Kúfit never met an Elf he did not want to turn into a stew.
Durnákh, a powerful Gorthorog, wanders the Outer Bailey at night, staring up at the stars, dreaming of his next squirming meal.
Gúlheryn has never been able to make her hair look as pretty as that of the Elves, and for that she has pledged to defeat every last one.
Unlike many of his kind, Afglu enjoys walking the ramparts and staring down from the dizzying heights above the fortress of Dol Guldur.
Zánurz likes his dwarves raw....
Norchador has wandered Dol Guldur since it was originally built.
Mornákh looks down on all other uruks...they are not even worthy to bow before him.
Defeat Faelathron
Defeat Mazaukgrat
Defeat Kúfit
Defeat Durnákh
Defeat Gúlheryn
Defeat Afglu
Defeat Zánurz
Defeat Norchador
Defeat Mornákh
Assault on the Ringwraiths' Lair
The Ringwraiths' Lair provides the final defences for the inner fortifications.
The baileys of the Ringwraiths' Lair are the final line of defence before the interior of the fortress.
This isolated hill in the Dourstocks is a rallying point for the wolf-packs of Mirkwood; mournful howls can often be heard upon the wind from this direction.

Gorogrod is a deep and evil den of the spiders of the Scuttledells, filled with perilous snares and sticky webs. Even the most seasoned traveller should be wary before treading here, for spiders are among the most deadly foes in Middle-earth. The spiders of Mirkwood's broods are certainly no exception.

Even trees can be corrupted by evil influences, and the Huorns of Mirkwood live out their long days growing ever blacker and ever more corrupt. Their home of Sâd Meryrn is a sad and lonely place, filled with the malice of the trees.
The fell waters of the Drownholt are polluted by many long years of corruption, and the heart of sickness in the swamp is the Pool of Creeping Death, home to many corpses and nasty creatures.
The Tree of Suffering is a place where the Orcs display the bodies of their victims for all to see as a warning to all who would bring light to the dark forest.
Foul things cause the water of this pool to ripple, bringing dread and disgust to those who happen upon it.

The Wind Stones are impressive in their formation, jutting high from the forest floor, shaped and beaten by the elements. But evil has settled here, and many cruel Wargs prowl about, spoiling the land.
Discover the Pack-howler's Hill
Discover Gorogrod
Discover Sâd Meryrn
Discover the Pool of Creeping Death
Discover the Tree of Suffering
Discover the Crawling Water
Discover the Wind Stones
The Wilds of Mirkwood
There are many wild and forsaken places to be stumbled upon as the wary wanderer passes through Mirkwood.
There are many wild and forsaken places to be stumbled upon as the wary wanderer passes through Mirkwood.

Danneglor was once a stronghold of the Elves of Greenwood the Great, but it fell beneath the onslaught of the Necromancer of Dol Guldur long ago. Now vile merrevail out of Angmar have taken refuge there, bringing dread to the fell ruins.
Malledhrim seeking to strike into the heart of Dol Guldur have encamped in these foul ruins, hoping to avoid detection long enough to carry out their plans.
This tower once watched over the river Anduin and the passage to Lothlórien, Mirkwood's sister on the western banks.
These ruins have become home to Black Númenórean sorcerers and fell spirits in service to Dol Guldur.
The outlying ruins of Ost Galadh have become the lairs of wild beasts, corrupted by the foul power of Dol Guldur.
Discover Dannenglor
Discover Mithechad
Discover Tirnhirion
Discover Sâd Morangol
Discover the Wild Ruin
Uncovering the Ruins of Mirkwood
Mirkwood is home to many places that were once great, but have fallen into ruin after long years of corruption and disrepair.
Mirkwood is home to many places that were once great, but have fallen into ruin after long years of corruption and disrepair.
Garmadh-maudhûl is one of many Orc-camps in the Ashenslades where the forces of Dol Guldur muster to begin their invasion of Lothlórien.
This evil place is the source of the blight upon the Ashenslades, summoned by the fell spirits and sorcerers who dwell there.
Ânghum-maudhûl is one of many Orc-camps littering the wastes of the Ashenslades, acting as a mustering hall for the forces of Dol Guldur.
Búrzkala is an Orc-fort in Gathbúrz, where the Orcs of Dol Guldur have established a foothold.
This hill was once a look-out for the Elves of Greenwood the Great before the coming of the Necromancer.
This Orc-camp was established to prevent an attack upon Dol Guldur from the forest of Lothlórien.

Evil Strongholds of Mirkwood
Many foes have settled throughout Mirkwood, striving ever to make it the fell and hopeless stronghold of evil that it has since become.
Many foes have settled throughout Mirkwood, striving ever to make it the fell and hopeless stronghold of evil that it has since become.

These maddened goblin overseers sned their boggart slaves ahead to distract their foes, while they bring their fire-pots to bear.

Stand against the growing darkness
Smoke Before the Fire
The One Ring has been found. The forces of Mordor are on the move. War is coming to Middle-earth....
The forces of darkness are beginning to march, striking wherever the Free Peoples seem weakest.
The Eglain have heard your name and speak well of you.
You must achieve Acquaintance standing with the Eglain
Known to the Eglain
You have become known to the Eglain -- people who have shunned accepted society, choosing the meagre life that the Lone-lands will support.
The Eglain consider you a trustworthy and valued friend.
You must achieve Friend standing with the Eglain
Friend of the Eglain
You have become a friend to the Eglain -- people who have shunned accepted society, choosing the meagre life that the Lone-lands will support.
There are few among the Eglain who are not aware of your deeds. You have become an invaluable ally to them.
You must attain Ally standing with the Eglain
Ally of the Eglain
You have become an ally to the Eglain -- people who have shunned accepted society, choosing the meagre life that the Lone-lands will support.
The Eglain count you among their number. Your efforts to help the people of the Lone-lands have gone far to endear you to them. They will ever more call you kindred, a true member of the Eglain.
You must obtain Kindred standing with the Eglain
Kindred to the Eglain
You have become an honourary member of the Eglain -- people who have shunned accepted society, choosing the meagre life that the Lone-lands will support.
It is time to execute Lord Celeborn's daring plan: an attack upon the fortress of Dol Guldur, in the depths of Southern Mirkwood.
Begin the Siege of Mirkwood
The Siege of Mirkwood
Lord Celeborn and Lady Galadriel have devised a daring plan: to cross the river Anduin and attack the fortress of Dol Guldur in the depths of Mirkwood.
It is time to execute Lord Celeborn's daring plan: an attack upon the fortress of Dol Guldur, in the depths of Southern Mirkwood.
Shrewdness will be needed to stem the tide of pesky pests in Duillond, and your efforts against these animals has demonstrated just such a quality.

The Festival Garden of Duillond is rife with pesky pests, and some very practical help is needed to rid the garden of its problems.

The Festival Garden of Duillond is rife with pesky pests.
You should defeat as many shrews as you can to help the Elves cleanse their garden of chaos so that the young plants may have a chance to grow.
So impressed by your prowess are the Elves that they have bestowed yet another title upon you: Tamer of Shrews.

The Spring Festival -- Season of the Garden
Spring has made its presence known throughout Middle-earth.
The good peoples of Middle-earth take some time to celebrate the beautiful new growing season.
The fire spirit Narubras was one of the remaining servants of Morgoth still dwelling in the deeps of Middle-earth.
The Angmarim sorceress Gormalith sought to summon the servants of Thaurlach to the aid of the Iron Crown.
Gháshglob was a mighty captain of the Ghâshfra.
The Nameless things which dwell in the depths of Nûrz Ghâshu are terrible to behold.
The Ghâshfra have brought with them a new breed of troll created to traverse the molten depths of the Rift.
Lúgryn is one of the lesser spawn of Scátha the Worm.
Nurnor is the mightiest of the spawn of Scátha the Worm, dwelling now within the Rift of Nûrz Ghâshu.
Fire spirits and earth spirits in the service of the Enemy dwell now in the deep places of the world, not the least of which is the Caerog Cefrog.

A new story begins: a dangerous chapter in the lives of those who seek to bring about the return of a long-awaited king.
Welcome to Volume III: Allies of the King!
Volume III: 'Allies of the King' Foreword
You have received a message from Pethelen, an Elf of Imladris, asking for you to see him at once about some urgent matter.
A new story begins!

Surprising messages have come from Lothlórien, and Master Elrond of Rivendell has done what he can to respond by asking you to gather the Rangers, that they may ride to the aid of Aragorn in the wide lands to the south.
You travelled the wilderness of Eriador, bringing word to the Dúnedain: it is time to fulfil their oath of loyalty to Aragorn son of Arathorn.
You rode south with the Rangers of the Grey Company, through Eregion and into Enedwaith, where you encountered a mysterious dwarf who has unexpected knowledge about the road ahead.

You have finally received truth from the dwarf Nár: the Wizard Saruman has fore-knowledge of your road, and the passage through Dunland will not be easy. Rangers of the Grey Company have fallen already on this journey, and the heart of Halbarad is heavy with grief.

You have escaped from the clutches of Saruman and rescued the surviving members of the Grey Company from the prison-caves of the Falcon Clan, but the future of your quest remains uncertain. Many foes remain between the Rangers of the Grey Company and their chieftain Aragorn.

The Fords of the Isen have been held by the Rohirrim under the command of Théodred, but the Prince of Rohan lost his life in the battle. For how long can this passage into Rohan remain secure from the ravages of Saruman?

You tracked down the Nazgûl that stalked through the mists along the shores of Anduin, but Nona was wounded. You and Horn, a man of Rohan in service at Stangard, brought her to the Elves for healing. Galadriel saved her life, but the Lady of Lórien refused to speak further of what awaits you.

You tracked the Fellowship of the Ring south along Anduin to Parth Galen and the Falls of Rauros, where you encountered signs that they were set upon by foes. Two hobbits, most likely Frodo Baggins and his servant Samwise Gamgee, crossed the river and continued on their quest. The surviving members of the company crossed into Rohan, and if you are to find them and help them, you will need war-steeds of your own.

You have journeyed into the Riddermark, helping the people of East Rohan and tracking the remnants of the Fellowship of the Ring. Your travels brought you through the Wold, the Norcrofts, and finally the Entwash Vale, where Nona vanished and Horn realized his feelings for her.
You journeyed throughout West Rohan, aiding its people as they prepare to face the perils of war.

You stood with the Rohirrim at the fortress of the Hornburg, in Helm's Deep, and survived the long night of battle with Saruman's armies. When dawn came, impossibly, Théoden and his people looked out over the Deep in victory.
The Grey Company has completed its mission to find Aragorn, and the threat of Saruman has been ended.

Allies of the King
Unravel the Epic Story for Allies of the King.
Complete 'Volume III Book 9: The Third Marshal'
Complete 'Volume III Book 10: Snows of Wildermore'

You encountered Éomer, the nephew of the King and Third Marshal of the Riddermark, and travelled with him through the Entwash Vale and the Sutcrofts. When he brought you before the King, however, you witnessed the extent of Saruman's hold on King Théoden. The King ordered Éomer imprisoned and banished you, ordering you never to cross the Entwash under pain of death.
You journeyed to the land of Wildermore, beset by unnatural winter and endangered by pawns of the Wizard Saruman, and did what you could for its people.
You returned to Edoras and witnessed the restoration of Théoden by Gandalf. You also helped Éowyn prepare for the evacuation of the city, while the King and his riders departed for Isengard, and war.
The road goes ever on and on...
...Down from the door where it began...
...Now far ahead the Road has gone...
..And I must follow...
...if I can.
Pursuing it with eager feet...
...Until it joins some larger way...
...Where many paths and errands meet...
...And whither then...?

You found the Elf-ruins of Minas Elendúr and should explore the sprawling ruins.

This central courtyard in Minas Elendúr was taken early by the forces of evil when war came to Eregion. The statue was untouched by the Orcs, but its sad countenance witnessed a great deal of pain and death on the grass below.

The south-west corner in Minas Elendur contains two platforms of raised steps and a great deal of debris. None of the columns reach the ceiling any longer, and this section of the ruins feels particularly unstable.

This enclosed porch looks out over one of Minas Elendur's several large courtyards. Valuables were left here, overlooked by the forces of evil that hunted the inhabitants here when war came to Eregion.

This courtyard, once a place of reflection for the Elves that lived in Minas Elendur, is now home only to bears driven mad with hunger. From above, the windows of an enclosed porch look out over the crumbling stones.
The pillars of this room in the south-east corner of Minas Elendúr are covered with ivy and crawling vines. The corners are shrouded in darkness, as so much of these ruins are.

This aisle, open to the skies of Eregion, was once the home of much greenery. Now only a few trees and bushes stand atop a raised platform here. This place is a junction of sorts, and passages lead away in three directions.

This isolated chamber, reachable only by stairs from Delotham, was one of the last places held by the Elves of Minas Elendúr when war came to Eregion. Their sad end left a mark on this grim chamber that time has not erased.
Pillars still reach to the ceiling in this dimly-lit room, despite the debris and fallen stones piled in the corners.

This bend is illuminated by shafts of light from above, one of the few places within Delotham where shadow does not lie heavily upon the stones.

This chamber within Delotham is centrally-located, but must see very little in the way of explorers. Bats nest here in the dark corners, and treasure too can be found if the shadowy curtain is drawn aside.

This corner in the western area of Delotham is partially collapsed, as the ravages of time buckled the south wall. As the Orcs spread throughout Minas Elendúr and Delotham in search of survivors of the initial assault, Elves came to hide wherever they could stay ahead of the marching footfall of the Orcs. This corner may once have sheltered such an Elf, though what became of any who tried to stay here is unknown and unknowable.

This sunken chamber, hidden for some days following the initial assault of the Orcs, is where the last three Elves of Minas Elendúr made their stand against the Enemy, when war came to Eregion. No tales tell how long they may have held out against the overwhelming force of the Orcs, but it is the tradition of Elrond of Rivendell to say that they held out until the end -- and beyond it -- and only when those who had escaped were safely out of Eregion did these last three fall.

The northernmost room of Delotham was built a distance from the other rooms, but none can say for what purpose it may have been. It seems to have not been for defensive reasons, for time alone is responsible for the decay in this chamber, and the war that came to Eregion and destroyed the Elves of Minas Elendúr seems to have left this chamber alone.

From this windowed chamber, the Elves that lived in this place watched as the forces of evil marauded through Minas Elendúr, slaying its meagre defenders. This elevated chamber bears the mark of their grief and despair, waiting as they did for the end to come.

After the first assault of Orcs attacked Minas Elendúr, many of the Elves that remained within were scattered and had to fend for themselves. They made their way through the maze-like interior, avoiding patrolling Orcs wherever they could. Rooms such as this one enabled many of the Elves to escape from their pursuers, but not all were successful.
This room has been marked by terrible evil, and the very stones cry out against the stain. What can have happened in this place to leave such torment in its wake?
Three passages lead away from the northernmost room in Minas Elendúr, passages down which the heavy tramp of Orc-feet carried even on the still air when war came to Eregion.
This upper balcony overlooks a courtyard in the southern area of Minas Elendúr and is home to treasure forgotten -- or ignored -- by the Orcs.

Part of the wall has crumbled away in this south-west corner of Delotham, the basement of Minas Elendúr. It is patrolled now by Ninkoth uruks, their heavy footfalls bringing to mind that of the Orcs that stalked these passages when war came to Eregion.
Stone-lizards scamper along the floor of this chamber in Delotham, perhaps drawn by the illumination that breaks through the ceiling from above.
Treasure can be found among the fallen rocks and debris of this junction in Delotham, where long ago Elves fought to defend their home from attack by the forces of evil.

This chamber, accessible only by stairs from Minas Elendúr, served as a final hiding-place for the Elves here when the Orcs came for them. The Enemy has more than just Orcs in his service, and this chamber still bears the mark of the evil that happened between these buried walls.

A diverse range of creatures make their home now in Delotham: stone-lizards and insects that have come to this place from hidden cracks within Khazad-dûm. The four passages that meet here ensure that it once saw much foot traffic in time of peace and much hurried panic in time of war.

Echad Dagoras is the encampment of Dagoras of Esteldín and his companions. It is here that the Grey Company entered Enedwaith and went their separate ways, hoping to pass through the region unnoticed by Saruman's spies.
Echad Saeradan is the encampment of Saeradan of Bree-land and his companions.
Echad Idhrenfair is the encampment of Idhrenfair and his companions, who had aided the Malledhrim in Southern Mirkwood.
Echad Daervunn is the encampment of Daervunn of Esteldín and his companions.
Harndirion is the ruin of an ancient fortress built by the Men of Gondor long ago.

This hut is the home of the shepherd Duved. Along with his daughter Avanen, he tends his flocks in Fordirith.
This stead belongs to a herdsman named Emlun. Recent troubles in the lands of the Uch-lûth have caused him to abandon his home for a time.
This stead belonged to a herdsman named Rurith until raiders from the South butchered him and his family and burnt it to the ground.
This stead belonged to a herdsman named Matho. Raiders from the South burnt it to the ground while Matho was away.
This Uch-lûth farmstead is one of the few that survived the attacks of the half-orcs.

This rough-hewn arrow either belonged to a small child or hobbit -- the make indicates a hobbit.
These boots, while crude and rustic in design, are clearly of Stoor-make.

This skeleton is clear evidence that hobbits live or once-lived in the Gloomglens.
This mining pick is certainly an implement of hobbit-make.
Hobbits were once known as great archers, but now they are better known for gardening...this bow suggests that there are still hunters among them.

A relic was placed in the middle of Bungo Grubb's pipe-weed field. The plants all died, ending his chance for a first-place finish in the annual festival.

A relic was placed outside the cottage in which Ted and Burt Farmer were dwelling, and the cottage was set aflame. They escaped with their lives, but could not understand who would do this to them, or whence the relic came.
A relic was left before the sealed door in the depths of the Laenan caves.
The relic was left among the walls of the Ironspan that connects Forochel with the land of Angmar. The Lossoth believe it signals the return of the Witch-king.
The relic was left among the slopes of Thrór's Coomb, and the creatures nearby, including the mighty gwiber, seemed hesitant to stray too near.
Barliman has not heard news of the relics, but he has promised to keep his ears open and will let you know if he does.

Lost Temple: One Ill Turn....

The grounds of the Lost Temple are being desecrated by mercenaries working for Ferndúr the Virulent.
The illness the mercenaries have contracted will soon be the end of them, but it would be best if you defeat them and ensure a quick and painless end to their suffering before they spread this dangerous illness beyond the temple's bounds.

The sellswords foolish enough to follow Ferndúr into the depths of the Lost Temple have succumbed to disease or have been slaughtered by the Gaunt-lord himself. Now spirits of plague have possessed their corpses and stalk the crypts, preparing to unleash pestilence and death upon the North.
You must destroy as many of them as you can before they escape to spread Ferndúr's deadly plague.

Swangeir Goldstealer is a Dourhand thief who infiltrated the Iron Garrison's expedition, but was discovered and escaped into the vast halls of Moria.
Morûrz-kala is a cave-troll in service to Mazog. He has been tasked with destroying the Iron Garrison's armouries throughout Moria.
Kalus is among the finest archers of Mazog's horde. Many dwarves have fallen to his bow.
Little escapes the notice of Throqûm, one of Mazog's most trusted scouts. Wherever he goes, death follows.
Fodhroval and his chittering pets wander the halls of Moria, outcast from the morroval-tribes which haunt Jazargund.
Many dark creatures dwell in the deep places of the world, not the least of which is the creature known as the Shadow from the Heart of the World.
Helchnaeth, a fearsome Frost-worm, has wandered into Moria from the slopes of Zirakzigil in search of fodder for her brood.
Goblin thieves will find any means they can of breaking into the vaults of the Iron Garrison and claiming their treasure for Mazog.
Defeat Swangeir Goldstealer
Defeat Morûrz-kala
Defeat Kalus
Defeat Throqûm
Defeat Fodhroval
Defeat the Shadow from the Heart of the World
Defeat Helchnaeth
Extinguish the goblins' fire-pot
The Battle of the Twenty-first Hall
The Twenty-first Hall of Moria is vital to the success of the Iron Garrison's expedition to reclaim Khazad-dûm.
Complete everything in the Battle of the Twenty-first Hall Skirmish
Many creatures wander into the Deep-way from the Water-works, including the glass-spider Lhenathronil, who has built a nest in a dark corner of the passage.
Gâmûrz-ash is only one of many of the mysterious, fungus-infested Orcs known as the Globsnaga who have begun appearing in the deep and dank places of Moria.
The deep-claw Earthbreaker tunnelled long from the Great Delving to find the passage known as the Deep-way.
Forktongue and her brood are among the denizens of the Water-works which have wandered into the Deep-way.
The glow-worm Foulscum has crept into the Deep-way to spin her nest. An infestation of glow-worms could wreak havoc upon the store-house of the dwarves.
Gredbyg have infested and overrun many parts of the Great Delving and have now begun to spill into the Deep-way.
Salamanders are a vicious, though fairly insipid draconic breed. Burntail is quite average for his kind.
The Mad Croaker is one of the toads which infest the Water-works... what madness caused the creature to wander into the Deep-way is unknown.
Defeat Lhenathronil
Defeat Gâmûrz-ash
Defeat Earthbreaker
Defeat Forktongue
Defeat Foulscum
Defeat the Gorged Queen
Defeat Burntail
Defeat the Mad Croaker
The Battle of the Deep-way
The Deep-way lies upon a hidden passage between the Water-works and the Great Delving. The Iron Garrison uses this passage as a major store-house.
Complete everything in the Battle of the Deep-way Skirmish
Durin's Bane commanded many fell things in the depths of Moria, and since his defeat, spirits such as Fire-heart have begun to establish their own authority.
Durin's Bane commanded many fell things in the depths of Moria, and since his defeat, spirits such as Ice-heart have begun to establish their own authority.
Durin's Bane commanded many fell things in the depths of Moria, and since his defeat, spirits such as Shadow-heart have begun to establish their own authority.
The mighty drake Celebarch has made her lair beneath the Heart of Fire, building a nest in which to nurture her young brood.
Fikûhom serves the Wizard Saruman with utter devotion and seeks to prove his worthiness to his master by claiming Moria for the White Hand... alone.
The spider Durbrennil hunts for prey to nourish her brood within the caverns of the Way of Smiths.
The nearly mindless cave-troll Sadâuk wanders the halls of the Way of Smiths, maddened by the fungal plague that has stricken the creatures now known as Globsnaga.

Defeat Ice-heart

The Battle of the Way of Smiths
The Way of Smiths bridges the caverns between the Redhorn Lode and the Silverdeep. Within lies the famed forge of the dwarves known as the Heart of Fire.
Complete everything in the Battle of the Way of Smiths Skirmish
Two milky-white fields on either side of a mountain Suddenly turn red as if fuelled by a fountain.
Total submission is what I require, Say my name, and you shall have your peace.
An unappreciative gesture am I. With my yelling and pointing, you are liable to cry.
I am a casual word with the purpose of play. Men use me, abuse me, then throw me away. A woman may blush at the feel of my touch, But I am just words. Do not think of me much.
Thirty white horses on a red hill, First they champ, Then they stamp, Then they stand still.
I am in the middle Of every great riddle When the one being riddled Would rather be fiddled.
My home is dark caves where colour lacks, Distant sounds and slight odours are where I come back. I am found in the hearts of all cowardly Men. I will make you fall down and damage your chin.
Sleep is the thing to which I must succumb. Open your mouth, and out I come.
A cheerful salute or an icy shower be I, If you shout my name out, thy friends shall not say bye.
When I take hold, men may dream or stamp their feet, Women may laugh or sometimes weep.
A rumbling growl if ever I was, I don't want to be here, and that is my cause. If you were to hear me, though my sound be not quaint, You have nothing to fear, ‘tis my master's complaint.
Where I go, often illness will follow me, Simply open your mouth and try not to swallow me.
I am an opinion that spreads across boundaries, An undulating current, An army marching towards its aim. I am hot or sometimes cold, A signal delivered by hand.
A meaningless montage of muttering mum, Close your mouth to speak, and out I shall come.

I am an expression of mirth and of merriment and pleasure, I can be shared with others, or alone at your leisure. Should you use me with others, I have only one plea: Please use me with them, not at them you see.
A simple word to say am I, Without me, kiss yourself good-bye.
Do it to my belly and watch me chuckle, Do it to my eye and taste my knuckle.
I make you weak at the worst of all times. I keep you safe, I keep you fine. I make your hands sweat and your heart grow cold. I visit the weak, but seldom the bold.
No matter how much you feel me, do not show me, Because when someone else sees me, Their slowness will not accept me.
I am a tool of deadly precision, As well as a ribbon of looping division. I am part of a ship, but that is not all. Bend over to spy me, but please do not fall.
I am the word that all men dread most, For when said by a woman, to their friends they shant boast.
I kill Men every day in their homes, But all Men require me to live. I am small enough to fit in a glass, Yet large enough to drown you.
I come bearing news of impending disaster. No one is immune to my heart cloaking plaster. I destroy lives both great and small. When I overcome you, I fear you may bawl.
Five pointers make I, Of all different sizes, When they all come together, A weapon it comprises.
I bring great joy to all whom I meet, And the happier they are, The more I will repeat.
I am the ocean during a terrible storm. I gain strength from fights and heated words. My greatest enemy is calm.
An affectionate feeling I always do bring, For when you feel me, to me you will cling.
Use me on yourself, and you are acting rudely. Use me on others, and you are being choosy.
I am the place that all refer to, but none may head, For when you have passed inside me, you are already dead.
A girl is taught to use me from youth, When meeting a man, to refuse is uncouth.
Four brothers live peacefully together as one, Two of them swinging, while two of them run. If their roles were to switch, what chaos ensues, For those on the ground now have no shoes!
Once I am uttered, I demand you an answer. Be it ‘yes’, may you lose, and your soul be devoured, Be it ‘no’, best you run! You are surely a coward.
Always a helping hand am I, Use me and aid your greatest ally.
I am the sound that many are releasing, Ever loud, never ceasing. Made by Man and nature alike, My sound warns all of an impending strike.
Hotter than dragon's fire am I, Yet colder than the winds of the north. The poor man has much of me, The rich man wants for me, And those who dine on me must die.
I am an action of luck if used on a coin. I am sudden and jerky and seldom adjoin. A man may perform me if he be athletic, But if he were to fall, I shall not be sympathetic.
I hatch eggs, look after of children. Never moving, always still.
I am shared by many. Sometimes I am up. Sometimes I am down. Sometimes I am over. Sometimes I am out. Sometimes I am at you, Or behind your back. And often I am cheap.
Use me on your belly, then follow by toasting, Use me on your back, and clearly you are boasting.
I am just two and two. I am hot. I am cold. I am the parent of numbers that cannot be told. I am a gift beyond measure, a matter of course, And I am yielded with pleasure—then taken by force.
I overcome you like a terrible drought, A shroud that covers you inside and out. You show me to friends as they come to be fed, But the one I am meant for is already dead.
An unwelcome guest, from your mouth I will be seeping. I may sneak out at night while you are happily sleeping.
I show the way when directions prove confusing, keep track of the winner and who is losing. I am the business end of a sharpened knife. Men seek my existence in their daily life.
I travel inside of a bitter wind, Make my way down your spine and demand that you bend.

On a face, I say much, without even speaking, I am useful for searching and watching and seeking. Use me well, and there is naught you will not find, Do not use me at all, and alas, you are just blind.
I betray the thoughts of women and men, Their yearning and sorrow sounding time and again.
I am the black child of a white father, A wingless bird flying to heaven. I birth tears of sorrow in pupils that meet me, And at once on my birth, I vanish like a spark.
Once you say my name, You will not see me Until we meet again.
I am heard in battles of all shapes and sizes. I emerge from all things who dislike surprises. Children all over use me as a tool, To get what they want, make their parents the fool.
Two brothers live in two houses On opposite sides of the hill. One brother shuts then opens his blinds, While the other brother stays still.
The only thing that can match my piercing sound, Is the feeling of my terrible blow.
My colour is white, my hope all but vanished. Let those that see spare me, or perhaps just banished.
I am the sound of happy birds. If you wish to hear me, Simply put your lips together… And blow.
When found in the ocean, I am a sailor's best friend. When found in a man, he be one to befriend. You may think me grand no matter my wallow, But be I in sky, a storm might then follow.
I say much, but have no mouth, Bringing words of hatred or love to those that I meet. Children are scolded for letting me take hold, But all shall succumb whether young or old.
A sparkling gem falls forth from the watch-tower. When it reaches the ground, for an instant it is a flower.
I am the tool of poor and the hungry alike, But those that are asked are sure to dislike.
I am a duty entrusted, Or a currency demanded, An accusation of guilt, Or a rushing blow landed.
I weaken all men for hours each day. I show you strange visions while you are away. I take you by night, by day take you back, None suffer to have me, but do from my lack.
I am spoken of often, but never directly, Simply speaking my name shows your gratitude correctly.
If you do me to others, you are being a pain. If done to yourself, you should not complain.
You are using me always day in and day out. Sometimes for better. Sometimes for fitness. Sometimes twice. Or even for nothing.
I corrupt your thoughts, your manners and actions. When I take hold of people, they are assured a reaction. You may think me anxious or odd or insane, And in fact I am all and cannot explain.
To the ears, I sound like a constant grating. To the eyes, I appear as a simple scrawl. Your skin desires me, All things start from me.
I am the moment that never comes, Idle time wasted. When my time has elapsed, I cease to exist.
Forgetful Francis Foresby was tired as can be, But alas he had forgotten what to do next. He marched off to bed and began counting sheep, But what must he do before he can sleep?
A biting insult can be defended, By a simple gesture of indifference.
I am that gesture which Can silently summon you To my master's side.
I am required for every good painting, But I may only be a wolf in sheep's clothing.
In people, I am scorned. In structures, I am feared. In sounds, I am harsh. But in strength, I am king.
When one makes preparations, I am always what they seek, If one does not have me, they will surely be weak.
I measure in time, but also in tension; I am the last bit of track before your ascension.
Listening to me will bring visions to mind, Of dragons and castles and kingdoms declined. Am I fact or just fancy? It is up for debate. But one thing is for certain: I am unlikely sedate.
Only the penitent man shall pass.
I am a child and a simpleton at once. All Men are born with me, But few possess me at their death.
Two workers live separately, But sometimes do meet. When they meet quickly, A great sound they excrete.

Some do me to be social, still others for fun. I am not just the action, but the object as well. I make your feet sore, but still do you stomp me. Only that which can stop me is the sound of the bell.
I am a respectful act in certain situations, Formally executed before important operations. A soldier's greatest honour am I, With no greater use than the day that he dies.
Through tears and through pain, they utter my name, Whether through anger or sadness or unbearable shame.
A terrible mass of pain you must swallow. When diplomacy fails, 'tis I who will follow.
A terrible force of nature am I, Flowing and soaking all I pass by. If I get cool, I may start to waver, But even in death I leave you my flavour.
I am a mirror of the truth. I am used for ridicule and derisiveness. I am a fake, a charlatan. But I can also be constructive.
Up and down, I carry my host. My number of times shall be what he boasts.

The Old Forest is a place best avoided as the dangers there can be found around every corner. You have obtained a copy of a map of the Old Forest.
A small village in Bree, Archet recently was burned by the Blackwold brigands. You have acquired a map of the town and surrounding areas.
Bree-town is the main city of Bree-land. Such famous places as Inn of the Prancing Pony and the Boar Fountain are found within the city. You have found a wonderful map of Bree-town.
Once the home of the Kings of Men, Annúminas is now a flooded city on the southern bank of Lake Evendim in the region of Evendim. This is the map of the city.
The Ettenmoors is a forgotten area of the world where evil has crept into nearly every part of the land. This is a map of the area.

The Men of Bree try to steer clear of the old burial mounds of the Men of Cardolan, for it is rumoured that terrifying creatures come out of the ground to stalk those among the mounds. This is a map of the northern part of the Barrow-downs.
Rivendell is the hidden valley where the Elves dwell on the border of the Misty Mountains and the Trollshaws. This is a map of that valley.
Eregion was a home to the Elves in ages past; now, ruins cover a harsh landscape. This is a map of that land.
A section of land leading south between Eregion and Dunland, Enedwaith is a harsh land of stone and wild. This is a map of the region.

Cold wind and the bite of goblin-wrought blades await travellers in the Misty Mountains. This is a map of the area.
The harsh land where the Witch-king once ruled. Now, the land is ruined and evil spreads freely and nearly unchecked. This is a map of the area.
This small community of dwarves rests in the shadow of Thorin's Hall. This is a map of that area.
A cold and forbidding land claimed by the Lossoth, Forochel lies far to the north. This is a map of those frozen lands.
A town of rich and poor needing assistance in the wintry months. This is a map of the town.
The southern section of the Barrow-downs houses more ruins and mounds of ancient Men. This is a map of the area.
A fertile land where many Men make their homes. This is a map of the area.
A place which most hobbits call home. The Shire is a collection of many smaller territories that make up the large land belonging to the hobbit-folk. This is a map of the area.
Ered Luin is home to both Elves and dwarves, and each is none too fond of mixing with the other. This is a map of the area.
The Lone-lands is a lonely stretch heading east through the ruins of Men. This is a map of the area.
War has come to the Men of the North Downs, and they are in need of aid. This is a map of the area.
The land here is forbidding and grim with trolls wandering through the wild lands day and night. This is a map of the area.

The Journal of Captain Rabghul

Beneath The Forsaken Inn stretches an expanse of natural caverns. It seems that people lived here at one time. One such person, the apparent leader of the group, left behind a journal. Who were these people, and what were they doing here? Collect all the pages and discover for yourself.
Note: Not all journal pages can be found in Tier 1 difficulty.
Captain Rabghul has not made it easy to locate the pages of his journal. He has left some of them in hidden areas where only a well-balanced party may venture.
Lhaid Ogo is a series of tunnels beneath the Lich Bluffs, in Enedwaith. Its passages are clogged with mud and not entirely stable.
Trapped behind a wooden wall in the depths of Lhaid Ogo, you found the body of an ancient unfortunate. Did he die there in the wall or was he moved to that spot to languish for all the ages?
The wooden bridge was of ancient construction, but the damp rotted some of the railings away. The gap could then be used to drop down to the lower passage, but it would be a one-way journey.
The discarded pouch within Lhaid Ogo was filled with small, bird-like bones, stripped of their meat. Tooth-marks on the bones revealed that someone or something had been gnawing on the collection.
Someone was eating a rat in the depths of Lhaid Ogo, but who? And what caused him not to finish it?
Mud-eater has stalked the passages of Lhaid Ogo for many years and makes his lair in the deepest chamber. He drags prey back to his lair before feasting on it.
Deep within Lhaid Ogo, you found signs of something heavy being dragged up a muddy slope, and it filled your heart with worry.
You found the remains of a luckless unfortunate
You found a gap in the wooden bridge and could jump down to the lower passage
Filled with a sense of revulsion, you leave the pouch where you found it
You found a partially-eaten rat. Who was eating it? And why didn't they finish it?
You found Mud-eater's lair, the deepest chamber in Lhaid Ogo
The earth on this slope has been disturbed, as if something heavy was dragged up it
Delve into Lhaid Ogo and unravel its mysteries
Find the ancient, unlucky explorer
Find the gap in the bridge
Find the discarded pouch
Find the unfinished dinner
Find Mud-eater's lair
Find the disturbed earthen slope
Lhaid Ogo Exploration
You have entered Lhaid Ogo, a series of tunnels beneath the Lich Bluffs. The passages are clogged with mud and feel quite unstable.
Lhaid Ogo is a mysterious place. Who knows what you might find down here?
The winding passages of Lhaid Ogo are clogged with mud, and its layout seems to shift as if on a whim.

The force of a blizzard compacted into a small mobile form, frost grims often terrified the Lossoth.
This powerful mammoth has trampled hundreds beneath his feet.
The sharpest teeth and claws belong to the leader of the sabre-tooth pack.
The worms of Forochel may live on the glaciers, but they breathe hot fire.
A powerful Guaradan spirit-caller, Crantok was in line to lead the tribe.
A rare drake in the frozen north, Túgarch terrorizes from the skies.
Terrors live in the snowy hills of Forochel. Ones that take children at night and feast on their bones.
Bears in the frozen north will fight to the death for a meal.

Many Dunlendings have chosen to heed Saruman's promises of revenge against Rohan.
Defeat hostile Dunlendings in Dunland
The evil Men of Dunland exist to give a bad reputation to the folk of these lands, good and bad alike.
You have proven a great hunter of beasts in the eyes of the Dunlendings.
Defeat wild beasts in Dunland
The wild creatures of Dunland pose a great threat to the people who try to survive in these harsh lands.
The Uruk-hai that roam the lands of Dunland and the Gap of Rohan are servants of Isengard alone, carrying out the will of Saruman with deadly precision.
Defeat Uruk-hai in Dunland
Uruk-hai Slayer
The mighty Uruk-hai are loyal only to Saruman. They are more clever and cruel than even the vile Orcs.
The origins of the half-orcs are many, but one truth remains constant: they are evil.
Defeat half-orcs in Dunland
Half-orc Slayer
The half-orcs in Dunland all hail from Isengard, where they strive to carry out Saruman's plan to oppress his neighbours.
The Orcs of the White Hand march through Dunland unhindered, which begs the question: Why do the Dunlendings suffer them?
Defeat Orcs in Dunland
Orcs are always evil, no matter whom they serve. The Orcs of Isengard are no better than those who come from Mordor.
Defeat many Orcs in Dunland
Though Morgoth and Sauron were responsible for bringing the Wargs into being, Saruman has not hesitated to put the fell-beasts to his own uses.
Defeat Wargs in Dunland
Wargs hunt and howl in greater numbers as the shadows of evil stretch their dark fingers across all of Middle-earth.
You have slain enough crebain to make a coat of their feathers.
Defeat crebain in Dunland
Spying crebain serve Saruman as loyally as Orcs and Men, bearing messages to and fro, giving Isengard an advantage in the coming war.
What dark power has caused the Dead to walk again? Whatever creature summoned them forth, it is certain that the Dark Lord had no small part in it.
Defeat the Dead in Dunland
Slayer of the Dead
It is an evil sign when the Dead wake from their long slumber to walk the earth again.
From bugan to the Nâkhmau, goblins have started to pour out of the Misty Mountains into Dunland.
Defeat goblins in Dunland
Wherever war and violence lash out, goblins are there to cackle while they reap the plunder from the chaos.
You must be careful not to purge the wilds of Dunland of the game that helps sustain the Dunlendings.
Defeat wild beasts in Dunland
Beast-slayer (Advanced)
The wild creatures of Dunland pose a great threat to the people who try to survive in these harsh lands.
The Uruk-hai that roam the lands of Dunland and the Gap of Rohan are servants of Isengard alone, carrying out the will of Saruman with deathly precision.
Defeat Uruk-hai in Dunland
Uruk-hai Slayer (Advanced)
The mighty Uruk-hai are loyal only to Saruman. They are more clever and cruel than even the vile Orcs.
Saruman's half-orcs are loyal... as long as their foes are weaker than they are!

The half-orcs in Dunland all hail from Isengard, where they strive to carry out Saruman's plan to oppress his neighbours.

Orcs are always evil, no matter whom they serve. The Orcs of Isengard are no better than those who come from Mordor.
The hounds of Saruman have been made to suffer at your hand.
Defeat Wargs in Dunland
Warg-slayer (Advanced)

Saruman's spy network has been drastically reduced at your hand.
Defeat crebain in Dunland

Spying crebain serve Saruman as loyally as Orcs and Men, bearing messages to and fro, giving Isengard an advantage in the coming war.
The servants of Saruman quake at the mention of your name.

Quests in Carreglyn
Undertake quests within Carreglyn.
The Fanged Lair is the den of a pack of evil wolves which prowl Pren Gwydh.
This is the den of Old Bloodtusk, a boar who is said to have migrated all the way from Archet in Bree-land.
This lumber-camp is worked by the people of Galtrev, the closest thing to a bustling social centre in Dunland.
The Draig-lûth, Dragon-clan, established this encampment to harry the peoples of Galtrev.
A pack of Wargs has established this den from whence to harry the enemies of the White Hand.
Rook, a former craban-keeper for Saruman, is a Bree-land native who aspires to become a great wizard...an unattainable goal he yet fails to grasp.

Exploring Pren Gwydh
Pren Gwydh, home of the city of Galtrev, has many places to explore.
Lower Barnavon is the district of the village of Barnavon where the remnant of the Turch-lûth, the Boar-clan, now dwell.
Upper Barnavon is the district of the village of Barnavon inhabited by the ruling Uch-lûth, Ox-clan.
Naur-maudhûl is an encampment of goblins and Wargs established to allow Saruman's Nákhmau scouts access to Carreglyn.
This mine, currently being worked in the name of Saruman the White, has been overrun by vicious bugan.
This watch-tower was built atop the ruins of an ancient Gondorian tower.
This pond is rumoured to be the home of the Great Avanc, a creature of Dunlending legend.
This shrine was erected by the Uch-lûth long ago as a place to commune with Munfaeril, a spirit of ancient days worshipped as the Uch-gwirod, the Ox-spirit, by the people of Barnavon.

Exploring Carreglyn
Carreglyn has many places to explore.
This great, rune-marked tree is the place where a Dunlending hero of old sacrificed himself to hold off the advance of his people's enemies.
This rune-marked tree is a place where the Dunlendings once mustered their forces to battle against Gondor and Rohan.
This camp was established by Théodred, Prince of Rohan, and his party of scouts to watch the movements of the Dunlending forces.
This slade of three rune-marked trees houses the Dutegelh, a relic of great power wrested from Dol Guldur when the White Council drove forth the Necromancer.
The Draig-lûth, Dragon-clan, established this temporary encampment on their journey south out of Enedwaith to Wulf's Cleft.
The Uch-lûth, Ox-clan, established this temporary encampment on their journey from Barnavon to Wulf's Cleft.
Orcs of the White Hand established this camp to clear-cut the Gravenwood to supply wood for their master's war-efforts.

Exploring the Gravenwood
The Gravenwood has many places to explore.
Avardin is a trading post and village of the Uch-lûth, Ox-clan, in the Starkmoor.
Flam-cadlus is an encampment of the Draig-lûth, Dragon-clan, in the Starkmoor.
This is the home of the merchant Andras, to whom you have lent aid in a time of need.
The Hound's Rest is so named because the Wargs of the Enemy like to sun upon the rock.
The Culling Pit is an arena where Dunlending warriors are trained -- or trimmed -- and merchants wager on the battles.
The Overlook gives a vantage of the great valley of Wulf's Cleft, where warriors from across Dunland muster to invade Rohan.

Exploring Starkmoor
Starkmoor has many places to explore.
This is the encampment of Grimbold of the Grimslade, one of the Horse-lords of Rohan.
This great hill is of strategic interest to both the Rohirrim and the White Hand.
This contested encampment is where Théodred's forces have fortified to block approach both by the southern road, and up the River Isen.
The Pit of Iron is a great mine beneath Isengard where the Orcs and their prisoners extract ore for use in making weapons for the White Hand.
These cells are where the prisoners of Isengard are housed.
This is where the iron-ore drawn from the Pit of Iron is smelted for use.
This is one of the mines that makes up the Pit of Iron.

Exploring the Heathfells
The Heathfells have many places to explore.
These gates bar the passage through the Ring of Isengard to Orthanc beyond.
This gruesome pillar points the way to Orthanc, the stronghold of Saruman the White.
This goblin-encampment is also home to many Warg-riders.
This stronghold houses many Uruk-hai in service to the White Hand.
This grove is the home of the Ent Bregalad, also called Quickbeam.
The Ranger Dagoras established this camp to keep an eye on Nan Curunír and the Vale of Isengard.

The Bone Quarry is an old stone-quarry in the Bonevales where the Dievlig have erected many cairns.
This massive cairn is the central tomb of all the Dievlig's leaders.
This is where the Ranger Naeglanc and his Dunlending allies have set up camp.
This Dievlig village suffers under the oppressive rule of their Brenin, Trehéarn.
Lhan Gogledh is the central village of the Dievlig in the Bonevales.

Exploring the Dunbog
Dunbog has many places to explore. As you tread through the swamps, be careful to stop and smell the sulfur.
The Rohirrim have established Forthbrond as a forward encampment in the Gap of Rohan against the Dunlendings who are threatening to invade.
This village is one of many where the Dunlendings are ramping up for the invasion of Rohan.
Many of Saruman's Wargs have inhabited this large warren, awaiting their master's commands.

Brôntrig overlooks the Gap of Rohan and provides the Dunlendings a choke point against any incursion from the Rohirrim. It is one of several villages where the Dunlendings are ramping up for the invasion of Rohan.

Exploring the Isendale
Isendale has long been on the edge of border skirmishes between the Rohirrim and Dunlendings, and has many places to explore.
The Bonevales are an extension of the Lich Bluffs of Enedwaith, but a section where evil had never stirred until now.
Carreglyn is controlled by the Uch-lûth, the Ox-clan, who operate a significant mine in the service of Saruman.
The Dunbog is home to a number of backwater clans and refugees from the Boar-clan.
The Gravenwood is a sacred place of the Dunlendings, both honoured and feared.
The Heathfells are a wide stretch of land in the Gap of Rohan which lie between Nan Curunir, the Isendale, and Rohan.
The Isendale lies at the entrance to the Gap of Rohan, leading into the Heathfells.
The wide vale of Nan Curunír is home to Isengard and the tower of Orthanc, stronghold of Saruman the White.
Pren Gwydh is the cultural centre of Dunland. Here, representatives from many clans come to trade.
The Starkmoor is a territory controlled by the Uch-lûth, the Ox-clan, and is home to Avardin, a major trading outpost.

Commanders of the Foundry, Tier I
The Foundry of Isengard is commanded by Saruman's most trusted lieutenants.
To earn this deed, you must defeat Dhâr, Gurbák, and thwart the plans of Saruman within the Foundry.
TBD To earn this deed, you must defeat Dhâr the Smelter, Gurbák, the Bellows Master, and The Ring-forge of Orthanc and it's protectors.
Rhodri is one of Gwyllion's chief lieutenants. A captain of the Draig-lûth, the Dragon-clan of Dunland, Rhodri is a savage and dangerous warrior.
Budant is one of the Brenin-lhud, the great ape-like creatures which inhabit the hills and mountains of Dunland. Gwyllion has called Budant and many of his kind to her cause.
Among the great evils that Gwyllion has summoned to aid Saruman is the wight Maru Brenin, lord of the Dead of Dunland.
Saruman has sent Garzog, one of his trusted lieutenants, to keep an eye on Gwyllion...just in case she decides to turn on him.
The giant Caur wandered into Dunland from the mountains above Thrór's Coomb in Enedwaith and pledged his service to Gwyllion, the Old Woman of the Mountain.
The fell spirit Helechúl is among the many fell spirits and ancient evils summoned by Gwyllion to lead her army of terror into Rohan on behalf of Saruman of Many Colours.
The Rogmul Núrvor and his twin Dombor were once servants of Durin's Bane, but following the demon's death answered the summons of Gwyllion, the Old Woman of the Mountain.
The Rogmul Dombor and his twin Núrvor were once servants of Durin's Bane, but following the demon's death answered the summons of Gwyllion, the Old Woman of the Mountain.

The Caerog Daeharn emerged from the depths of the Misty Mountains in answer to the mystical summons of Gwyllion, the Old Woman of the Mountain, and now serves the witch as one of her terrible lieutenants.

Storm on Methedras

The dwelling place of Gwyllion, the Old Woman of the Mountain, lies atop Methedras, overlooking Isengard. The witch has allied herself with Saruman the White and seeks to bring a great army of ancient evil down upon the Rohirrim.
Defeat all of Gwyllion's lieutenants in the Storm on Methedras Skirmish.

Helping Hand
Many are the needs during the Farmers Faire.
Be helpful during the Farmers Faire.

Maggot's mushrooms, some of the finest mushrooms in the Shire, grow in his fields among the other crops, and young hobbits throughout the land gather to challenge each other to acts of daring and bravery whilst avoiding the nip of Farmer Maggot's dogs, Grip, Fang, and Wolf.
Earn victories in Maggot's Mushrooms (${NUMBER}/${TOTAL})
Maggot's Mushrooms Victories (Tier 1)

A group of mischevious young hobbits organizes a yearly secret raid of Farmer Maggot's fields, seeking to snatch wild mushrooms that grow among the grain -- and each year Farmer Maggot sets his dogs loose in the field to chase them off -- can you prove your worth as a mushroom-hunter?
You have proven yourself a fine mushroom-hunter. The hobbit-youths look up to you in reverence and awe, as you nimbly avoid the pursuit of Maggot's dogs.

Traits enable you to specialize your character. Visit a Bard in any major town to change Traits and enhance your character further.

The Vanished Rider
The Nazgûl that rode upon the fell-beast, which lies now dead in the Brown Lands, is missing somewhere along the Great River. Perhaps the residents of those lands have seen some sign of its passage.
Some of the Rohirrim beheld a mysterious shadow falling from the sky not long ago. Is this event of some significance for your strange dream in Dunland?
Search the lands alongside the Great River for sign of the Nazgûl's passage.

This is the camp of the Rohirrim warden Idmar.
This great field is where the Battle of the Field of Celebrant took place, when the Men of Gondor and Men of the North drove forth the Easterling Horde, and Rohan became a nation.
Hordfierd is a fortress erected by the brigands who stole into Parth Celebrant to thieve the relics there... only to be swayed by the servants of Mordor.
Ost Celebrant was once a great fortress of Gondor before it fell to the treachery of Oathbreakers. Now it houses the shades of the betrayers and their evil allies.
This place has become the den of a pack of ravenous wolves, which have turned to cannibalism for the lack of food.

Parth Celebrant is an old cross-roads and battlefield that holds a long significance to the Rohirrim as the birthplace of their kingdom.

The small camp-site is held by Aculf and his companions... a small patrol to watch over what was supposed to be uninhabited territory....
This encampment was established as a waypoint for the brigands of the Brown Lands who seek to plunder Parth Celebrant for ancient relics.
This place is the breeding ground for the avanc of the Rushgore... a dangerous place for the unwary.
The Creeping Mud is, in fact, a nest of vile gredbyg which dwell in the Rushgore.
Tik Botokh is an encampment of scouts for an Easterling tribe called the Khundolar, descendants of the Horde who battled Gondor and the ancestors of the Rohirrim at the Field of Celebrant.
Turtles of great size inhabit the Rushgore, and this is their nesting place.

Rushgore Explorer
The marshes of the Rushgore have long been uninhabited... or so the border-guard of Rohan believed. Besides wild beasts, villains of a two-legged variety have recently come....
Discover the camps and sites of the Rushgore.

The Stone of Friendship, where Cirion, the Steward of Gondor, and Eorl, the first King of Rohan, met on the battlefield as victorious allies. The monument commemorates their oath of friendship and service.
A small group of Rohirrim, led by Frithstan, guard the south of the Wailing Hills. Their primary task is to keep safe the Cuthstan monument.
This is a recently constructed Orc-encampment. The Nink-hai have boldly abandoned their mountain homes to live in huts and tents along the northern edge of the Limlight River.

The Mor-hai Orcs have grown in number and tenacity. They have begun constructing war-camps beyond the safety of their dark mountain dwellings, in order to more directly provoke the Men of Stangard along the road.
Landroval and Meneldor, two of the Great Eagles in service to Gwaihir the Windlord, selected this secluded clearing as a safe location to regroup, after splitting up to search the area.
This large cave in the mountainside is the central breeding grounds for the Venom-bite spiders, a breed renowned for their venomous fangs.
Named for the bright star-shaped flowers that blanket each ridge, this hilltop has become a favourite grazing spot for the wild goats native to the region.

Etheburg is a way-post of the Rohirrim border-guard. It is the last bastion of defence for the Rohirrim before entering the Riddermark itself.
Long have brigands and ruffians used the Brown Lands as a hideaway. Helstor is their last refuge in that desolate place.
The Khundolar, Easterlings descended from the Horde that fought the Lords of Gondor and the ancestors of the Rohirrim at the Field of Celebrant, have returned, prepared for war....
These ancient and ruined gardens once blossomed at the caring hands of the Entwives before war ravaged them.
This network of caves houses a tribe of wild trolls, who have chosen to inhabit the Brown Lands

Eorlsmead Explorer
Eorlsmead is on the distant northern border of Rohan, a watch-post against the evils of the north.
Discover the landmarks of Eorlsmead.

When the last inhabitants of the Limlight Gorge were driven out by the arrival of trolls from the Misty Mountains, the Rohirrim erected this guard-post to keep an eye on the entrance to the Gorge and ensure that nothing came out of it unseen. Luckily, the trolls dare not stray too far from the caves and ledges they take cover beneath during cloudless days, and so they have made no attempt to come up out of the Gorge.

The Limlight Falls mark the bottom extent of the foothills leading down from the Misty Moutains as the rushing river empties out towards the plains to the south.
The cold rushing stream ensures a steady supply of fresh water for the community of Stangard.

The northernmost extent of the forest of Fangorn ends here, at the banks of the Limlight River.
The Ents have long had a small gathering place here, where they would long ago meet with the Elves of Lothlórien and learn news of the outside world.

This ancient Gondorian tower once watched over the Limlight Gorge.
To what purpose, or against what threat, no-one today remembers, for it fell into ruin long, long ago.

This old river pothole remains from time long past when the Limlight's course ran further up the Gorge. It left this oddly smoothed pit behind as it shifted course.
Now, alas, it seems that trolls have taken up residence within its deep shadows.

This may once have been a homestead or hunting-cabin down in the Gorge, but more recently it has been the way-post for a band of prospectors and treasure-seekers exploring the Gorge for valuable minerals.

This old sawmill was built some years ago by the Men of Stangard, before the trolls arrived and drove them away.
More recently it appears that a band of hard-working but obstinately foolish dwarves have been trying to restore the mill to working order.
Discover the Limlight Gate-house
Discover Limlight Falls
Discover the Ent-grove
Discover the Fallen Watch-tower
Discover the Pothole
Discover the Prospector's Shack
Discover the Old Sawmill
Limlight Gorge Explorer

The Limlight Gorge has always been a wild and sparsely inhabited area, but since a band of trolls came down from the Misty Mountains, what few inhabitants there were have fled its rocky slopes. Massive creatures now inhabit the Gorge, making travel through the area perilous, and it is said that even the trees themselves sometimes move about, perhaps thanks to some strange magic from the neighbouring forest of Fangorn....
Explore the Limlight Gorge in Great River.
A few Ancient stones remain here among the rocks. It is hard to say, but they may be of Elf-make.
The few remaining chunks of masonry and stonework you found suggest that the Elves once lived here...but it must have been an age of the world at least since that time.
Covered with ancient lichens, you find the final crumbling remnants of an Elf-ruin. What purpose could the Elves have had so long ago that brought them here?
These ruins look even older than the rest, if that is possible. You cannot even begin to guess at what their purpose might have been.

These old Elf-ruins appear to have some strange markings carved upon them. You have some considerable difficulty deciphering the odd runes, until finally you realize that they are rather recent additions, likely made by Men or dwarves surveying the Gorge long after the structure fell to ruin.
These ruins are so ancient that there is no sign of what brought them to this state, whether it was war, calamity, or the passing of some vast span of time that crumbled them to all but nothing.

A spirit of the Limlight Gorge spoke of her mistress' long ago protection of the Gorge and of how the trees once learned to speak.
One of the spirits of the Limlight Gorge claimed that they act as the custodians of memories of long ago, but it seems impossible to guess at what she meant by that.
This spirit spoke of a time when the forests of Lórien and Fangorn met, and the Elves spoke often with the Ents, though she did not reveal the name of her mistress. Could she mean the Lady Galadriel?
An ancient spirit spoke of the songs of the Elves which could once be heard echoing through the gorge in times long past, and wondered if they might one day return.
This spirit spoke of a time when they helped teach the Elves how to speak with the trees of the forest. But she mourned that most of these things had long been forgotten by the trees of the Gorge.
A strange spirit wondered what would become of them, when at last the final traces of the Elves faded from the Limlight Gorge.

Haldirith, a ruined garden of the Elves, is where the sentinels of Thinglad have made their home.

Orcs have begun to settle in Thinglad for the first time in many a year. This is surely a sign of evil days to come.
Orcs seem to be everywhere these days, even in the once-peaceful woods of Thinglad, so near to Lórien's edge.

Saeradan, Amlan, and Andreg are searching the Gravenwood for clues to the whereabouts of the Old Woman of the Mountain.
Help Andreg deal with the threats of the <rgb=#FFFF00>South Gravenwood</rgb>.
The Mead Hall of Stangard is where Stanric and the other Rohirrim conduct the majority of their business.
The lockhouse is guarded closely by Cynred, and none may enter without strict permission from the leadership of Stangard. Here are all things that must be locked up, from food-stores to prisoners.
The Skirmish Hall is where all skirmish-related business is done.
The Auction Hall is rarely used by the Men of Stangard, but the Auctions of Middle-earth can be viewed here.
The Stangard Vault offers only the most secure place to store your cherished items.
When the burdens of the day become overwhelming, the Stangard Tavern serves as a place to relax and quench thirsts.
This house near the Mead Hall is home to Stanric, the lord of Stangard.
Athulf alone cares for the gentle dogs that inhabit the kennel of Stangard.
Undesired weather can force the horses of Stangard indoors. This stable helps provide warmth during the winter months.

Sabert is your friend. He guards the front gate of Stangard, and greets you whenever you come and go.
This is the home of the workman Wada, an overworked and underfed resident of Stangard.
The Legendary Item Store employs the only two soldiers in Stangard that have mastered the Forging and Imbuing of Legendary Items.
The Supplier lives here, but the supplies in this house belong to him, not to you.
The Provisioner lives here, but the provisions in this house belong to him, not to you.
Byrnstan is a loyal guard of the Mead Hall, and does his work with little compensation.
Dunstan's home is now unoccupied, for this brave hunter was slain by Orcs in Thinglad. He will never sleep in his bed again, for his grave is under the eaves of the great trees of Thinglad.
Uthrad is a guard loyal to Sithric. It is best not to cross him.
Tatwine is a gentle farmer who tends the horses of Stangard, day in and day out. He wants nothing more than some land to tend, but he is not permitted to do any farming.
Long Abandoned, this home strikes fear into the hearts of any man living in Stangard. All those that enter are never heard or seen from again.
Adalbert is a guard loyal to Stanric. It is best not to cross him.

The people of the Wold need a great deal of aid in these troubled times.

This camp of Rohirrim hail primarily from the Wold, but there are representatives from throughout the kingdom of Rohan. They came to the East Wall under the command of Mansig. Their purpose was to investigate the fresh gathering of Orcs and Uruks that crossed the river, but they were ambushed upon arrival and still work to recover from that attack.
More than a dozen Orcs lie dead in a glade not far from Amon Hen. What happened here?
The grassy lawn of Parth Galen would serve as a good location for the camp-site of any travellers forced to disembark the river, but it is in full view of the far shore and could be dangerous.
The Tindrock is a great spur of rock that divides the waters of the Anduin as they rush towards the Falls of Rauros. Called Tol Brandir by the Elves, it is said to be unclimbable.
The great Falls of Rauros descend from the cliffs with a booming roar. To follow the river over the edge means death.
Amon Hen is one of the two hills that rise on either side of the Anduin at the Falls of Rauros. The kings of old once sat upon the Seat of Seeing at its summit and saw many things of use to them.
The Orcs in the East Wall have erected a barricade to keep travellers from coming into the East Wall from the Sutcrofts.
The North-guard is a chamber dominated by the Orcs of Moria in the tunnels beneath the East Wall.
This chamber is full of gredbyg. It is possible other tunnels beneath the East Wall are infested with the creatures as well.
You discovered Mansig's encampment of Rohirrim in the East Wall

You have discovered Langhold, the northernmost city of the Wold. It stands guard against invading brigands and Easterlings.
Harwick is a large city of the Wold, home to Harding, the stern Aldor.

The Silkenhold is overrun with evil spiders who snuff out the light with their webs, much to the displeasure of the trees who live there.
Deep in the deepest reaches of Fangorn's eaves is a dark stretch of forest covered by shadows old and strong.
A mossy set of tall stones runs along the edge of the Entwash River in Fangorn, the rocks green and lovely from the clean water they drink.
The meadow of Sweetmead is appropriately named, for in the midst of the thick trees is a meadow, smelling of gentle honey and sweet sunlight.

A large, deep pond stands still in the midst of Fangorn, treacherously hiding under its thick veil of fog. You cannot help but wonder how many unsuspecting creatures have drowned in the hidden depths.

The Stinging Bog lies just beyond the walls of Harwick in the Wold.
Cracabor is the highest hill in the Wold, looking out over the grassy plains.
The Croft-watch is rumoured to be the fairest and most scenic place in the Sutcrofts.
The Wódfen is a wetland in the Entwash Vale, plagued by salamanders and madness-inducing draugar.
Wild horses run free in the lands of Rohan, and one particular herd of these impressive beasts can be found in the Entwash Vale.

The Wilds of the Eastemnet
Explore the wilds of Rohan.
Explore the wilds of Rohan.
The Undeep Watch is where the Rohirrim of Langhold keep watch upon the ford against the crossing of Easterlings.
Feldburg is a defence outpost of Harwick, presided over by Captain Agelmund.
Wakenflood, a Rohirrim outpost of the Wold, has nearly fallen to Easterlings. Soldiers lie wounded as they struggle to uphold the defences.
Twickenburg is the Rohirrim watch upon the cross-roads in the Wold, ensuring that the roads are held by the Free Peoples.
North-torr is the Rohirrim's last defence against Easterlings in the enemy's march upon Floodwend.
The huntsman Caddabrand has set up camp within a rock formation to hunt on behalf of Reeve Athelward.

The men of the western watch-tower are the vanguard of defences for the city of Cliving. From their outpost, they are able to identify enemy forces approaching from the plains and are able to halt their intrusion.
Reeve Athelward's men have converted a secluded farmstead in the north-east into a training ground for aspiring soldiers. The relatively hidden location offers some protection from Orc-assault.

The merchants and traders at this outpost sell much-needed supplies to travellers along the road and to those fleeing from the invading Orc-armies. Their location is a dangerous one, but hired guards help to protect the traders from wandering enemies.

Olghakhósh is a small Easterling-camp in the Wold.
Jóshkhin Orda is the large Easterling-encampment of the Wold, where Súth-torr was captured by the Nazgûl to pave the way for the enemies of the Rohirrim.
The Orcs of Nîn-stazg rally for an attack on Floodwend.
The brigand-leader Eastmund has been exiled many times, but his lair always seems to reappear somewhere in the northern Wold.
The shallows of the Anduin present a vulnerable spot for the Wold, for Easterlings attempt to creep across the river at such places.
A company of Uruk-hai warriors, who had marched west with a larger force, has recently returned and made camp south of Elthengels. What could have caused them to flee eastwards?
A group of White Hand Orcs, the Nink-hai, have established a war-camp in the mountain-passes between the Norcrofts and the East Wall, planning to assault the farming-village of Faldham.
The Orcs that have escaped Walstow's spears at the East Wall have set up camp at Ash Durub in the Sutcrofts, blocking Walstow from receiving any aid from Snowbourn.
Along with Ash Durub, the Orcs of Ufum-mau prevent Walstow from receiving aid from Snowbourn.

Half-orcs of the White Hand have been actively trying to sack Garsfeld, having met minimal resistance from Gísil's men.
The Orcs and Uruks of Maustazg pose a dire threat to the people of the Entwash Vale.
You have come across Thrug-unur, an encampment of Moria goblins in the Entwash Vale. Having goblins as neighbours is a situation that is less than ideal for the Rohirrim here.
Explore the encampments of Rohan's enemies.
The Howling Wood is a Warg-den in the Wold that was once a strategic worksite for Floodwend, but is now overrun with the filthy, deadly beasts.
Fang Point is a Warg-camp that threatens the Men of Feldburg, who stand watch on the road.

Âmbal, the renowned and feared wolf-matron, makes her home in a circle of cliffs and rocks near the stream that runs across the Norcrofts. She and her offspring have caused no shortage of suffering to the nearby farmers.
A once-peaceful valley, spanning from west of Faldham into the East Wall, has become overrun with dangerous Láthbears.
You have discovered Wyrmdelf, a cave teeming with evil drakes in the Entwash Vale. Such places are deadly even for the hardiest and bravest of warriors.
The Wyrm-father of Wyrmdelf lives upon the high rock of Fang Tor in the Entwash Vale.

Where Evil Creatures Dwell
Explore the dwellings of evil creatures in Rohan.
Explore the dwellings of evil creatures in Rohan.
This small farm belongs to the farmer Randgar, who has refused to evacuate despite the growing danger of the Orc-threat.
This estate was once home to a prosperous farming family, but it has fallen into the greedy hands of the invading Orcs.
The crofts of Walstow, ravaged almost completely beyond saving, are held by Orcs, so what few crops remain are far too dangerous for any crofter to harvest.
Bradcroft is the largest croft in the Sutcrofts and lies south of Garsfeld. It is currently overrun and has been destroyed by a number of half-orcs and Orcs.
Wyrthing is a largely untouched spread of croftlands surrounding Snowbourn. The Orcs have made attempts to besiege them, but so far their efforts have been repelled by the forces of Snowbourn.
