The first four pages of this book can be found on enemies scattered across Angmar, Eregion, and Moria. The last four pages of this book can be found on enemies scattered across Forochel, Moria, and the Misty Mountains.
This book contains a number of genealogical charts professing to document the various lines and branches of your family, but some of the pages are missing.
You do not know who prepared this book, but perhaps Bilbo Baggins, currently staying in Rivendell, knows something about it. He has an interest in such things and knew your relative Beorn.
Collect the missing pages of 'Genealogy of the Beornings' and add them to the book.
On this page, the author claims that most skin-changers can assume the forms of many animals, and acquire their most fundamental characteristics. You have never known this to be true.

On this page, the author describes his belief that the power of the skin-changer is passed through the male line. The power does seem to be hereditary, but there are many women in your family who also share that power, including your own sister Langhár.

On this page, the author notes that when a skin-changer assumes the form of an animal, he may grow to several times his normal size. You have known this to be true, and wonder if the author has based this portion of his account on actual encounters with your family or pure supposition.

On this page, the author says that every skin-changer is uniformly more ferocious than other folk, which you know to be an outright fabrication. Many members of your family are introspective and thoughtful. You wonder what the author would make of your brother Sterkist, who is given to day-dreaming of adventure but would never hurt anybody.

On this page, the author describes the skin-changer's love of honey-cakes. This, at least, is accurate. Your cousin Varthmath is particularly skilled at the baking of honey-cakes, and now you want one. You silently curse the mysterious author for reminding you of such deliciousness without any near at hand.

On this page, the author describes the expansive bee-pastures which your family have tended for years. The bees grow to incredible size and produce some of the most delicious honey you have ever tasted.

On this page, the author poses a question he finds undeniably frightening: are there skin-changers among us? You know that your people are not as numerous as he believes, nor are they as skilled at blending in as he thinks they are.
On this page, the author supplies a surprising confession: he claims that he himself is a skin-changer! Judging from the rest of his book, you find this a difficult thing to believe.

This curious manual seems to describe the nature of your family's ability to take the shape of animals. It is a description of skin-changing over the years, written long ago by someone with very little actual understanding of the ability. You wonder if there is any truth hidden within its exaggerated and mostly-untrue account.
Several pages are missing, but a small, much more recent, bit of parchment tucked into the front cover contains the inscription 'Ask Bilbo.' Is this a reference to Bilbo Baggins, currently residing in Rivendell?

Complete the epilogue of Central Gondor.

The Ruthless Dead found themselves hopelessly bound to their oath, and banished far from their Master.
Drugât grew weary, and asked your aid in reclaiming gifts once given Isildur and his men. In exchange, his cursed folk would return to the Paths of the Dead and never again trouble the lands of the Living.
You held your word and for once, Drugât upheld his. He and the Ruthless Host have left Gondor in peace, hoping that one day, they shall finally be at rest.

In the end, the Sister of the Gilrain played a tremendous role in shaping the fate of Gondor.
Her command over the river Gilrain not only banished the Ruthless Dead from Dor-en-Ernil, but also had the curious power of saving Garvir during the attack on Linhir.
Reunited with their brother once more, Erchar and Herion have a renewed sense of hope for the future, and have prepared themselves for any troubles that lie ahead.

In the aftermath of the attack on Hata Kebir, the folk of Lebennin have grown curious about what became of the strange Corsair that aided the Men of Linhir.
You found Jajax and Daxamat on the shores of the Anduin where they planned to set off... on a stolen ship. Indeed, Jajax and his brother were true Corsairs to the very end. You shared strong drinks with the mischievous pair, but by the time you awoke from your antics, they had sailed off.
You wonder what will become of Jajax, and you hope your paths cross once again.

Walk the path of Aragorn and his men from Ringló Vale to Pelargir.

You have discovered the village of Ethring, which stands on either side of the main fords of the Ringló. It is a rustic village of lumberers and fisher-folk with a mighty hall upon a nearby knoll. Timbers hewn in its woods are sent downstream to Amroth and south, overland, to the Ethir and Pelargir.
Discover Ethring
Path of the Grey Host
Discovered Ethring
Walk the path of Aragorn and his men from Ringló Vale to Pelargir.
You have discovered Calembel, This is home to Angbor, who commands great forces for Aragorn.
You have discovered the Stone of Erech, where Aragorn called upon the Dead Men of Dunharrow to honour their oath.
You have discovered the Camp of the Grey Host, a stop for Aragorn and his men before they march on Pelargir.

You have discovered the city of Pelargir, one of Gondor's oldest and greatest cities. It has long stood in direct opposition to the city of the Corsairs in Umbar. It stands at the mouth of the River Sirith as it flows into the Anduin just above the delta of the Ethir; it is a city of wharves, bridges, and canals, with a palace built on pilings out in the Anduin itself.

You have discovered the city of Linhir which straddles the river on either side, guarding a ford and bridge. Part of the town belongs to Lebennin, and part to Belfalas. It is normally a quiet harbor of fisherfolk, but has been assailed and partially destroyed by the Haradrim and Corsairs of Umbar, who besieged it and fought long against its defenders, led by Lord Angbor of Lamedon and Comeldir, a Swan-knight entrusted by Prince Imrahil with guardianship over the far reaches of his province.

Reach Level 15 as a Beorning
The Line of Beorn, Part One
Your journey continues in Eriador.

Descendants of Beorn have not traditionally left the skin-changer's home-land, but your journey has brought you to Eriador in defence of the Free Peoples. Your quest continues at Adso's Camp, in the Bree-land.
Reach Level 45 as a Beorning
The Line of Beorn, Part Three
Your journey continues in Eriador.

Descendants of Beorn have not traditionally left the skin-changer's home-land, but your journey has brought you to Eriador in defence of the Free Peoples. You should now go to meet your brother Sterkist, at the Spire of Meeting in Rivendell.
Reach Level 58 as a Beorning
The Line of Beorn, Part Four
Your journey continues in Moria and Rhovanian.

Descendants of Beorn have not traditionally left the skin-changer's home-land, but your journey has brought you to Eriador in defence of the Free Peoples. You should now go to meet your cousin Varthmath in Moria, at the Orc-watch in the Redhorn Lodes.
Reach Level 30 as a Beorning
The Line of Beorn, Part Two
Your journey continues in Eriador.

Descendants of Beorn have not traditionally left the skin-changer's home-land, but your journey has brought you to Eriador in defence of the Free Peoples. You should now go to meet your sister Langhár at Ost Guruth, in the Lone-lands.

Goblins have always been the enemy of Beornings ever since they drove Beorn from the Misty Mountains.
You have begun to repay them for their villainy.
Defeat goblins
Enmity of the Goblins
Goblins have always been the enemy of Beornings ever since Beorn was driven from the Misty Mountains.

It is clear the goblins have some greater force backing them, otherwise they would lack the courage to attack Grimbeorn's lodge.
You have defeated many of these loathsome creatures, but as they pour out of their hiding places it becomes evident they number more than anyone fathomed.
Defeat goblins
Enmity of the Goblins II
Your might can easily match several goblins at once.

Grimbeorn said that in time, the goblins would come to fear his children as they fear himself and feared Beorn before him.
That time has come.
Defeat goblins
Enmity of the Goblins III
Fear spreads throughout the ranks of goblins. Far and wide, they whisper in hushed tones of the wrath of the line of Beorn.
You have started to cull these foul creatures from Middle-earth.
Defeat spiders
Enmity of the Spiders
Living near Mirkwood, you and your kin are no stranger to monstrous spiders twisted by darkness.
Defeat spiders
Enmity of the Spiders II
These creatures have taken root in the once pure woods of Middle-earth. You have made some progress in clearing them out.
After your efforts, sightings of these monsters have lessened.

You have defeated spiders hither and thither, bringing a greater sense of security to the populations they once plagued.
Though these creatures persist, their numbers are far more manageable and less threatening.
Defeat spiders
Enmity of the Spiders III
In your travels, you have found that spiders plague more than just your humble home. They are a threat that needs to be answered across Middle-earth.
Bred solely for war, Orcs form the bulk of the enemy's forces. Every one that is defeated makes Middle-earth the slightest bit safer.
Defeat Orcs
Enmity of the Orcs
Orcs are clever, skilled, and brutal in combat. They do not however, anticipate their enemy changing into a massive bear and mauling them.
Your experience with fighting Orcs has taught you that, though more formidable in single combat, Orcs are much like goblins in that they are both susceptible to a claw to the head.
Defeat Orcs
Enmity of the Orcs II
Some Orcs are aware of Beornings' unique ability. They have yet to figure out how to stop the mauling, though.

You have discovered The Great Bridge. Destroyed by Faramir and his elder brother Boromir to hold the western shore, The Great Bridge has been rebuilt in recent days by the Orkish forces occupying Osgiliath.

You have discovered the Palace of Eldacar, named after the king who ended the kin-strife and returned the throne to Osgiliath.
You have discovered The Dome of Stars. It was once the hall of the kings and Osgiliath's greatest structure.
You have discovered the Osgiliath Culverts. These ancient tunnels and waterways form a network of unmapped passages under the entire city.

Friend to Minas Tirith
All you have done within the bounds of Old Anórien has made the folk who live here friendly to you.

Ally to Minas Tirith

You must earn Acquaintance standing with Minas Tirith
Known to Minas Tirith

There is nowhere you can travel within the bounds of Old Anórien where you are not known. The people feel a deep kinship with you.
You must earn Kindred standing with Minas Tirith
Kindred to Minas Tirith
You may not have been born among the people of Old Anórien, and you may not make the great city of Minas Tirith your home, but you are welcome wherever you go.

Also known as Tham Pethgyl, it is the location through which all messages to and from Minas Tirith pass, and headquarters of the city's errand-riders.

Also known as Bâr Haust, a guest-house for visiting merchants.
Also known as Sennas Vrand, a small inn catering to the wealthy.
Stables carved into the wall of the Seventh Circle for those few who ride to the top of the city. Also known as Rochbar Raud.
This building contains a group of guest-rooms for visitors to the Citadel. The lords of the fiefs reside within, including Lord Forlong.
Also known as Sennas Forn, an inn that quarters traders from far-off lands.

Also known as Sennas Hedyr, the dwelling for soldiers visiting from outside Minas Tirith. The soldiers of the fiefs are quartered here, as well as being billeted in guest-houses and evacuated homes throughout the city's lowest three circles.

Also known as Bâr Mírath. This well-guarded dome contains the treasury of Gondor, holding all the wealth belonging to the Steward. Many locked chambers beneath the building house gold, silver, jewels, and heirlooms from ancient days.

Read the plaques of taverns and wine-shops within Minas Tirith.
Also known as Lond Veriannen, a cozy ale-house.
Also known as Alph ’Elir, a tavern favoured by the hostellers of Minas Tirith. It boasts of having the finest wine cellar in the city.
Also known as Drafn a Gwedgeph, an ale-house catering to the builders of the city.
Also known as Falf Falthol, a wine-shop where minstrels and their wealthy patrons gather.
Also known as Dol Rachrohir, a wine-shop for soldiers.
Also known as Dring a Mebir, an ale-house that caters to the city's smiths.
Also known as Narthan Ereb, a wine-shop of refinement and beauty whose establishment is marked by the large brazier atop its portico and a central garden.

Also known as Cenir Faug, it is a warm, friendly, and collegial tavern nestled into a nook in the side of the Mindolluin. It has been beloved for centuries by the students and masters alike in the Houses of Lore.
Also known as Thoron a Cerch, a tiny wine-shop next to a larger lawn and garden where poets often come to recite their odes. Its name comes from two of the greater constellations.

Also known as Tham Baudh, the main courthouse of the city. It is where magistrates pass judgement against all but the highest lords in the city.

Also known as Gadorost. Dug into the side of the Mindolluin, it houses many cells where common folk are held after judgement is passed.
Also known as Bâr Caun, the city's public auction hall.
Also known as Sammath Oston, it contains offices of city clerks, heralds, records-keepers, and so forth. It is the heart that keeps Minas Tirith alive.

Also known as Rond Anor, the great meeting-hall of Minas Tirith. It is where the city councilors hold court, and high magistrates hold trials for prominent citizens or the highest of crimes.

Also known as Bâr Menel, a tower for gazing at the stars. Soothsayers and natural philosophers congregate here, and artisans craft navigational tools for the mariners of the Falas.
Teachings of the White City
You have discovered the House of the Heavens plaque
You have discovered The Black House plaque
You have discovered the Houses of Lore plaque

Also known as Gobeth Iaur, the original library of Minas Anor which delves into the pier-rock in the middle of the Sages’ Neath. It is dark, dusty, and little-used; its books and scrolls have no semblance of order.

Also known as Gobeth Vorondil, named for the last Steward not to serve as Ruling Steward. This library was built when Minas Anor was renamed as Minas Tirith. It is a brighter, more orderly place filled with works penned within the past thousand years, as well as transcripts of major texts from ages past. Sometimes called Gobeth Wain, or the New Archives, though this name has fallen out of favour for obvious reasons with the passage of centuries.

Also known as Bâr Vorn, named for the dark stone of which it is built, as well for the ink used within. This is the chief scriptorium of Minas Tirith, where scribes write, copy, and translate texts both old and new. It is part of the Houses of Lore, and its tower houses the school's Warden.

Find The Old Archives plaque
Find The Archives of Vorondil plaque
You have discovered The Old Archives plaque
You have discovered The Archives of Vorondil plaque
Read the plaques of buildings used for the advancement of knowledge within the city of Minas Tirith.

Also known as Bair Istoth, a collection of halls and towers where the wise gather to teach, learn, argue, and think. Younger sons and daughters of the nobility are often sent here to become sages; teachers from the Houses also work throughout the city, teaching rich and poor children alike to read and write, as well as numbers, history, and other lore.

You must earn Friend standing with the Galadhrim
Friend to the Galadhrim
The Elves of Lothlórien now consider you a dear friend.

The minds of Orcs are weak and easily befuddled, and the greatest of the Elf-refuges have long been protected by magical wards that turn away such evil, allowing the Elves havens of relative safety from which to strike against their foes with surprise and precision.
Thus it has been that in these later ages their dark armies are oft turned first against the fortresses of Men or dwarves, rather than the Elves whom are hated most of all by the Enemy of old. So it has often turned to you and your people to strike at their flanks, cutting them off and sowing confusion and fear in their well-ordered ranks so that the larger armies of Men may smash their vanguards.
Defeat Orcs
Enmity of the Orcs II

Unlike the goblins, the Orcs have been raised with a martial outlook and form the backbone of the Enemy's armies. They are neither cowards nor weaklings -- though they cannot hope to match the martial prowess of the Elves -- but their numbers and war industry are vast when motivated by their shadowy lords.
The Elves stand against the Enemy and their allies.
Defeat Dourhands
Enmity of the Dourhands
Some can fall to the Shadow, but these dwarves have allied themselves with the Enemy by choice.
The Elves stand against the Enemy and their allies.

Enmity of the Dourhands II
Some can fall to the Shadow, but these dwarves have allied themselves with the Enemy by choice.

It has been said of late that endless clouds have descended again upon the hills of Angmar. This can only bode ill, for it heralds the gathering intentions of the Enemy. They strive to claim the North, even as rumours of war spread from Mordor in the South.
You and your brethren must continue to fight as you have ever before to contain their growing might, until the greater forces of the Free Peoples of Middle-earth can be rallied to battle.
Defeat Orcs
Enmity of the Orcs III

While Orcs dislike the sun nearly as much as their lesser brethren, the goblins, they have more tolerance for it and can be forced to endure it for a time when necessity -- or the lash of their masters -- demands. Despite this, it has long been an artifice of the Enemy to conjure forth vast clouds of smoke or darkness both to protect their troops from the rays of the sun and to conceal their movements from spies and scouts.

The Elves and Orcs have clashed for ages, but with many of the Elven people leaving across the Sea to the West, fewer remain to carry on the battle.
It seems that in the end it will fall to Men to eradicate the Orc-menace once and for all -- but it remains to be seen if they are strong enough for the task. In the meantime, you remain to carry on the battle in the name of your people.
Defeat Orcs
Enmity of the Orcs

Bred by the Enemy for war over land, the Orcs are larger and tougher than their goblin cousins, but their origins remain the same. Militant and brutish, they retain some native talent for the clever working of wood and metal, though they only apply this to the construction of weapons and other machines of war.
You have hunted down and defeated many High Elves foolish enough to come to the Ettenmoors and Osgiliath.
Defeat High Elves in the Ettenmoors or Osgiliath

The Black Book of Mordor - Where the Shadows Lie
Unravel the story of 'The Black Book of Mordor - Where the Shadows Lie'.

At the behest of King Thorin you brought Khîl Tale-spinner, a trouble-making Zhélruka, back to his father's home in the Ironfold. You also brought word to Thorin's own son Durin that the time had come for him to learn what it takes to lead. But even as Durin prepared to return to the Lonely Mountain, Khîl discovered a hidden chamber within his father's house, and in that secret room was revealed a black-bound book covered in evil sigils and bearing the Eye of Sauron: the Black Book of Mordor.

On your return to the Lonely Mountain you encountered a band of Zhélruka on the border of the Dale-lands. Aggrieved that the messenger they dispatched to King Thorin had not yet returned, they threatened to cross by the base of Erebor, in war if need be, and Durin stayed behind to ease the tension. After bringing the Black Book of Mordor to Gandalf and delivering word of his son to King Thorin, you learned that the Zhélruka passed into the Grey Mountains; unwilling to shed dwarf-blood, Durin followed them instead, vowing to protect the Men of Dale from the possibility of Zhélruka aggression. When you finally caught up to Durin, his heart had been moved by the chill air of the mountains, and he desired to prove himself a worthy son and heir to King Thorin, though it mean risking the ire of Karazgar, the Weeping Warrior.

An excursion to the Anvil of Winterstith and a quest for vengeance embroiled the Dwarves of Skarháld in further conflict with Karazgar, the Weeping Warrior, and only the timely intervention of Gandalf staved off disaster. His study of the Black Book of Mordor has borne some fruit, but Karazgar's interest in that forbidding tome has convinced the Wizard that it must not remain in the Grey Mountains.

At Gandalf's suggestion you journeyed to the house of Grimbeorn in the Beorning-lands. While you helped his folk make safe their homes and those of their neighbours in the vales of the Anduin, the Wizard continued his study of the Black Book of Mordor. Before long, Elrond and much of his household arrived in the vales on their way to Gondor for the wedding of his daughter Arwen to Aragorn Elessar. They also sought out Grimbeorn, who found his hospitality, and his patience, tested by the arrival of the Elves. Meanwhile, the presence of the Weeping Warrior can still be felt in the vales, and his desire to obtain the Black Book has not lessened.

In the wake of Sauron's defeat, the Gúrzyul Ugrukhôr seeks information about a mysterious artifact known only as the Bugdatish, and he sends his minions in search of Karazgar the Weeping Warrior, another of the Gúrzyul who may possess the secret of it. Meanwhile, the Lord and Lady of the Golden Wood come to Dol Guldur, the former stronghold of the Necromancer, and raze it to the ground.

The search for Karazgar continued into Eryn Lasgalen and the Dale-lands, bringing you into the confidence of the surviving dwarves of Thorin's Company, who sought answers for the apparent decline of their people's craft-skill. Gandalf came to believe that the Gúrzyul might be experiencing a similar decline, and they seek a means to reverse or counter it.

Gandalf sent you from the Vales of Anduin to Imlad Morgul, where you joined the warriors of Gondor seeking to cleanse Imlad Morgul and Minas Morgul at the command of King Elessar. But his were not the only eyes turned on the Dead City, and the Masters of Mordor also sought to take advantage of the Morgul-sorceries laid bare by the defeat of the Witch-king.

Hoping to gain insight into the life of the Elf Magoldir, whose name appears within the Black Book of Mordor, Gandalf prevailed upon the shade of Isildur to recount the tale of the Siege of Barad-dûr that concluded the Second Age.

The shade of Isildur concluded his tale of the Great Alliance of Elves and Men that brought about the defeat of Sauron at the conclusion of the Second Age, but their victory was bittersweet, for Sauron endured and his evil persisted.

Within Barad Cúron, the Tower of the Crescent Moon, you confronted the wraith Gothmog and put an end to his evil designs and those of another of Mordor's Masters. But your victory within the tower raised further questions, and the mystery of the Black Book of Mordor remains...

You delved beyond the Black Gate into the vale of Udûn, where Sauron's armies were equipped for war. The Dark Lord may be gone, but his lieutenants remain and vie for power in the absence of his unifying evil. Chief among these is Ugrukhôr, the Captain of the Pit, who seeks to maintain his command over Udûn from the fortress of Durthang.

With the unlikely help of the Khundolar war-leader Ayorzén the Wily, you obtained an heirloom corrupted by its long stay in Gorgoroth. You were able to cleanse it of the evil that encircled it, and Elrond imbued it with the Light of Eärendil, a powerful force for Good that will light your way in the Black Land. You met with Dulgabêth, the former Mouth of Sauron, and listened to his offer of peace. Aragorn deemed it unacceptable, but believes you learned information of use from he who hopes to rule Mordor as Sauron's heir.

The search for information led you further into Gorgoroth, and you learned more about the Gúrzyul and the uneasy alliances they have formed in order to solidify their own domains. More troubling for Gandalf and for Middle-earth is your discovery that Lhaereth the Stained, the Lady of Blight, has returned to Mordor and seeks to perfect her pestilential master-work. She was responsible for the Great Plague that swept Gondor and the lands to the east earlier in the Third Age; does she now hope to finish what she started?

Your infiltration of Amon Thaur has revealed a troubling development for Middle-earth: the Masters of Mordor have set aside their differences and come together beneath the rule of Lhaereth the Stained, Lady of Blight. A unified Mordor endangers all the Free People: Men, dwarves, Elves, and hobbits alike.

Like a thousand malevolent eyes, the many furnaces of Udûn burn amid the shadow and fog. What tally of crude arms and amours have been wrought in them, during the time of the Dark Lord's reign?
Forge-fires of Udûn
Discover the forging furnaces in Udûn.
Discover the forging furnaces in Udûn.
This road drives like a rod of iron from the Black Gates on into Gorgoroth, where it splits to encircle Orodruin.
Thousands of rough pairs of feet have marched, stood, and camped upon Udûn's broad central basin.
The heights above have been used for many purposes over the centuries; most recently to host a contingent of Easterling forces.
From here, a wary eye was kept on Anglach and the high bridge leading to it.
It is no coincidence that directly before Anglach affords the best view of all eastern Udûn.
An overseer may watch over the works below from here and, also, the road.
The doors were somehow wrenched asunder in the chaos and struggle that directly followed the fall of Sauron.
For what strange purpose was this platform used?
The lord of Durthang could survey his domain from this height -- and more.
Many fell weapons and great war-works have winded their way down this road, out of the great forges of Anglach.
Atop this steep ascent, countless rough, cruel weapons were wrought to arm the Dark Lord's immeasurable armies.
Servants bore goods and messages up this way to the fastness of Durthang.
Comings and goings along the Iron Road can be viewed with ease from this spot.
Being nearer to Barad-dûr, this path to Durthang was used for purposes of state and ceremony.
Great steam and water works were controlled from this point, which looked down onto the waste reservoirs below.

Discover Cirith Ungol
You have discovered the Silent Watchers of Cirith Ungol. Within their conjoined bodies and vulture-faces, some dreadful evil still resides.
You have discovered the courtyard of Cirith Ungol. Even now, you can see grisly evidence of the great skirmish that broke out when Shagrat and Gorbag battled over Frodo's mithril-coat.
You have discovered the Tower of Cirith Ungol. Long ago, the Tower of Cirith Ungol was held by the Men of Gondor, but now it has become a grim fortress under the control of Mordor.

You have discovered the top chamber of the Tower of Cirith Ungol. It was here that Frodo Baggins was kept prisoner and stripped of his belongings after he was found by Shagrat and Gorbag near Torech Ungol.

You have discovered the Under-gate of Cirith Ungol. It was here that Samwise Gamgee became separated from Frodo Baggins as the Uruks of Cirith Ungol sealed the Under-gate behind them to ward against Shelob's children.

You have explored Kâm Lagúrz, also known as the Brokencleft, a ruined cavern where one of the Queensbrood was felled and where vile creatures now dwell.
You have explored Amon Rûth, a crag shattered by the eruption of Mount Doom, which now spews foul water into Dath Nethryn below.
You have explored a cavern leading into Torech Ungol, the dark caverns home to the ancient daughter of Ungoliant, Shelob.

The Abyss of Mordath -- Tier 1

Determined to wield the lost Ring of Power Manthríf once more, King Váskmun Greytooth has led his Firehorn Dwarves into the Abyss of Mordath, where the sunken foundations of Barad-dûr now rest. Meanwhile, the Order of the Eye has made haste to pursue the Firehorns, eager to avenge their fallen and contest the dwarves' claim to the greatest artifacts of the Dark Lord. Unbeknownst to any of them, greater still are the terrors Sauron hid away in the shadows of the Mordath.

Discovered Murpraush, the Hall of Spoiling
You have discovered the Lithannon, the Ashen Gate, of the Mordath. Once the main entrance into the Mordath, it has been sealed in the wake of Sauron's defeat.

Although it has been shattered, Durshnúl, The Black Bridge, once spanned the sunken Abyss of Mordath and was a great highway for both the damned of the Black Pits and the imprisoned creatures of the Dark Lord.
Discover the Lithannon
Discover Durshnúl, The Black Bridge
Discover Glurnákh, The Pit of Greed
The Abyss of Mordath -- Explorer of the Black Pits
Discovered the Lithannon
Discovered Durshnúl, The Black Bridge
The Abyss of Mordath is home to both the condemned of Mordor and the Dark Lord's most carefully-guarded secrets.

Murpraush, the Hall of Spoiling, is where Sauron conducted the most vile of his sorceries. It was there he sought to equal the horrors of the first Dark Lord, Morgoth, and bring forth new and terrible creatures of his own imagining.

Thol Shíkug is a fortress of terror and death built into the very foundations of Barad-dûr. For those condemned to the Black Pits, it is known as the Screaming Deep -- for many an Orc, Man, and beast have met their ends at the hands of the Dark Lord and his most powerful servants within. What lies within this grim structure, none have ever returned to tell.

The Mordath, the Black Pits of Mordor, is a place devoid of hope. It is the foundation of Barad-dûr, an ever-deepening mine, and a pit of punishment for those that have failed the Dark Lord. Those who are cast into the Black Pits will never again behold the light of Middle-earth.

Glurnákh, The Pit of Greed, has long been the home to Fingar the Greedy, an ancient Worm of Angband. After devouring two of the Seven Rings, Fingar was captured and imprisoned beneath the Dark Tower to suffer evermore.

Glúrakul, The Pit of Frost, was once home to Hrímil Frost-heart, a cold-drake of the Grey Mountains. After Hrímil came to the dwarf-halls in the East and devoured one of the Seven Rings, she was captured and imprisoned beneath the Dark Tower. However, when Barad-dûr fell and the Mordath was shattered, she flew from her prison and escaped from Mordor.

Glúrghash, The Pit of Flame, was once the prison of Thostír the Rank, a great fire-drake of the East. After devouring one of the Seven Rings, he was captured by agents of Mordor and imprisoned beneath Barad-dûr. However, when the Mordath was split asunder, he flew from its shadowed depths and escaped the Land of Shadow.
You must explore the deepest depths of the Mordath to uncover all that was hidden away by Sauron.

Experience the events of the Lay of Rust and Rime.

You learned of a series of intertwining rumours that confounded the Men of Lake-town and Dale. Who or what is the Herald of Winter? Has Vethúg Wintermind grown weary of his hoards in the Ered Mithrin, or does another of the Gúrzyul come to spread fear and destruction in the North?
Complete 'Heralds of a New Age'
The Lay of Rust and Rime
Late in the Third Age, an old conflict stirred between the Weeping Warrior and the Herald of Winter.

Like the coming of a great storm, Vethúg Wintermind descended upon Erebor in rage and vengeance. Many peoples of the North battled and fell, but in the end, Vethúg sustained a grave wound and flew for the Grey Mountains in defeat.

The raven-chief, Arcah, called back her ravens from their spying, but not all made the return journey safely. You rescued a wounded raven from swift cold-drakelings that pursued it onto the slopes of Erebor, and soon after, it was able to fly to Ravenhill. However, the tidings it brought did not bode well for the peoples of the North. Vethúg Wintermind had begun his flight from the Grey Mountains, and he would soon lay his vengeance of upon the North.

After the darkness of Mirkwood at last began to recede, Tárasánë, the Green Lady, revealed herself in Caras Tilion. In a powerful vision, Tárasánë revealed that Vethúg Wintermind will come to Erebor, but as merely a harbinger of the true Herald of Winter. Although Tárasánë would not speak of the Herald of Winter's name, she told you that the Herald of Winter once served the will of Morgoth and has dwelt in Middle-earth since the Elders Days. You returned to King Thranduil with these troubling tidings, and he sent word to the Queen Regent and King Under the Mountain.

After King Thranduil travelled to Caras Tilion, he was beset by the forces of Karazgar. King Thranduil battled Karazgar in single combat, but before the tide of battle turned, he found himself awoken outside Felegoth as if from a trance. Fearing that Karazgar sought the power of the mysterious Green Lady, King Thranduil sent you to Caras Tilion to challenge Karazgar. You discovered the aftermath of a battle between Elves and the Men of Mordor, but Karazgar left only rust in his wake. The Green Lady was revealed, but her intentions remain unclear. What powers does she possess? Is she of the same kind as the Huntsman of Dunland?

At long last, Karazgar revealed his designs in Esgaroth-of-old. The broken remains of the cold-drakelings his agents captured from the furthest reaches of the Ered Mithrin had been laid bare among the bones of Smaug the Golden. It was a deception to enrage the greater drakes in the service of the Herald of Winter and turn their ire against the Elves, Men, and dwarves of the North. A dying cold-drake revealed that one of his kin escaped Karazgar's wrath in Esgaroth-of-old and made for the Ered Mithrin to deliver a warning to the Herald of Winter. Despite the efforts of the leaders of the North, it seems the vile plot of the Weeping Warrior has succeeded.

You learned that the agents of the Weeping Warrior have been gathering cold-drakelings in Lake-town under the cover of night. After eavesdropping on a conversation between a smuggler and one of Karazgar's servants, you learned that not only does Karazgar hope to use the drakelings to bolster his strength, but also to send a message to the Herald of Winter and the North itself. You also discovered that Karazgar travelled into Eryn Lasgalen, but his purposes remain unclear.

After you revealed to King Thorin that Vethúg Wintermind seeks to set siege to Erebor, he prepared to rally the forces of the North to repel the legendary cold-drake. Fearful that Vethúg does indeed serve one greater, he has resolved to slay the cold-drake and avenge his ancestors who dwelt in the Ered Mithrin. After an ill-advised attempt at humour, King Thorin requested that you deliver word to the leaders in the North. Although some offered help only begrudgingly, it seems the North remains united against the servants of the Enemy.

At King Thorin's request, you sought an audience with King Thranduil. You offered him a token of peace from the dwarves of Erebor, and delivered a warning that Karazgar now stalked the realm of the Elves. King Thranduil prepared his scouts and you aided in directing them to seek Karazgar among the forest of Eryn Lasgalen. What will their searches reveal?

Despite learning that Karazgar may have returned to Caras Tilion, King Thranduil was forced to turn his attention to another matter. The Old Mother, Iphantemel, was revealed in Torech Emel, and the time had come at last to claim vengeance upon her for the destruction of Caras Tilion and the blighting of Mirkwood. Far from the hale foe Thranduil once faced, Iphantemel was old and bloated in her excess and she seemed to welcome her death. The spiders were at last purged from Eryn Lasgalen, but only because Ungwetári called her children to the Ephel Dúath for some terrible purpose. King Thranduil became suspicious of Karazgar's intentions in travelling to Caras Tilion and vowed to seek him with a small company of Elves.

Fearing that you were misled by the visions of the Green Lady, King Thorin III advised you to seek the counsel of King Thranduil. In turn, King Thranduil suggested you seek the counsel of Lady Galadriel and the power of the Mirror. After travelling to Caras Galadhon, Lady Galadriel did not believe that Karazgar could have come so far south to enter the ruins of Dol Guldur beneath the notice of the Galadhrim. Lady Galadriel consulted the Mirror, but again saw no sign of Karazgar in Dol Dhannen, the name now given to Dol Guldur. Still, she felt that something remained beyond her sight and thought long on what was to be done.

After much deliberation, Lady Galadriel travelled to Dol Dhannen with Lord Celeborn, King Thranduil, Sigileth, and you. Your exploration of the ruins of Dol Dhannen nearly proved fruitless until you discovered a small passage leading down into the shadowed tunnels of Gostador. As Lady Galadriel expected, you did not find Karazgar in its depths. However, a great evil still lingered in Gostador and you witnessed shadowy impressions of Karazgar's final dealings with Sauron in Dol Guldur. You learned that Karazgar was promised the entirety of the North once the peoples there were driven out, and that the Weeping Warrior could subjugate or destroy any of the dragons that remained in that realm. You also learned that Hrímil Frost-heart defied Sauron and devoured one of the Dwarf-rings in spite. Following these revelations, you returned to Erebor and informed King Thorin III that Karazgar may still lurk nearby.

After learning that Vethúg Wintermind flies for Erebor, the peoples of the North began to ready their defences in earnest. You aided the peoples of Dale, Lake-town, and Felegoth in preparing for battle and defending their homes.

In the aftermath of the battle at Erebor, it was revealed by the ravens that Karazgar pursued the wounded Vethúg Wintermind into the Grey Mountains. Much to the dismay of his kinfolk, King Thorin III decreed that no expeditions shall be made into the Grey Mountains for he, Erna, and Thranduil think it wise to remain uninvolved in the conflict between Karazgar and Vethúg Wintermind now that they have left the North.

Despite his edict, King Thorin III has heard troubling rumours regarding the forming of an expedition to reclaim Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep, from the dragons and Orcs of the Grey Mountains. Every dwarf you spoke to denied such an expedition, but King Thorin III remained unconvinced. After talking to the adventurous Dori and learning that he has no intent to defy the King Under the Mountain, he asked you to talk to Nori about a group of dwarves who came to the coffers in the night. To the surprise of all in Erebor, Nori departed and led an expedition into the Grey Mountains. King Thorin III was furious, but he would not violate his own edict. The fate of the expedition to Thikil-gundu is Nori's burden to bear.

While the rest of the North braced for the coming of Vethúg Wintermind, Dís summoned King Thorin III to Ravenhill. To their surprise, the raven-chief, Arcah, had returned from far-off lands and wished to speak with the new King Under the Mountain. After agreeing to honour the old ways between their peoples, Arcah sent her ravens far and wide to spy on both Karazgar and Vethúg Wintermind.

The Elves were making a raft of the barrels, with the dwarves still inside, and would soon be steering it downstream to Lake-town.
\qIf you want to go on with this silly adventure, you had better slap your arms and rub your legs and try and help me get the others out while there is a chance!\q

From Ravenhill, they could see the grey ruins of ancient houses, towers, and walls.

A gleam of light came straight though the opening, and then there was a loud crack. A hole appeared suddenly about three feet off the ground. Thorin put the key from his grandfather's map into the hole. It fitted and turned! A door five feet high and three broad was outlined, and slowly swung inwards.

Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep -- Tier 1

In the wake of Vethúg Wintermind's defeat at Erebor, Nori set forth with a small company to reclaim the lost hoards of Thikil-gundu. However, great wealth is not all that remains hidden in its frozen halls, and the Dwarves of the North shall soon have to contend with the true master of Thikil-gundu.

You have discovered Durûz-mazal, the Chamber of Faces. Erected to honour the Dwarrowmoot of old between the Seven Kings of the Dwarves, the many faces of this chamber watch over Thikil-gundu.
Discover Durûz-mazal, the Chamber of Faces
Discover Bekâr-mazal, the Arming-chamber
The halls of Thikil-gundu delve deep into the Wrathhorn.
Discovered Durûz-mazal, the Chamber of Faces
Discovered Bekâr-mazal, the Arming-chamber
Long before the great cold-drake Vethúg Wintermind froze the halls of Thikil-gundu, the Longbeards delved the Steel Keep in the depths of the Grey Mountains.

You have discovered the Smithies of Kall-khebâb. Once a great craft-hall of Thikil-gundu, the old smithies of the Steel Keep have been seized by the Orcs of Gundabad in service to the brood of Vethúg Wintermind and his forebear, Hrímil Frost-heart.

You have discovered Bekâr-mazal, the Arming-chamber. Despite housing many weapons and tools of war, the great armoury of Thikil-gundu did not avail the Dwarves of the Steel Keep in the battle against Vethúg Wintermind.

You have discovered Balb-gundu, the Frostdelf. One of the only remaining delvings of Thikil-gundu, the Frostdelf once comprised much of Thikil-gundu until a great portion of it collapsed into the Depths of Akhatâr. It now serves as the lair of Athramóth, the mate of Vethúg Wintermind and mother of countless dragon-kind in the Grey Mountains.
You have discovered Zashar-tûmun, the Ruin-dwellings. Once a great dwelling-hall of the Dwarves of Thikil-gundu, Zashar-tûmun has fallen to ruin.

You have discovered the Feast-house of Amrâg-zahar. In the course of many long years, both the Longbeards and Zhélruka enjoyed great feasts and merriment in Amrâg-zahar before the fall of the Steel Keep. When Durin's Folk sought to return to Thikil-gundu, it was there Vethúg Wintermind waited in ambush and descended to slay Dáin, Frór, and countless other Longbeards.

You have discovered the Lore-trove of Afhân-binnîn. A great hall of lore lost to the Longbeards and Zhélruka. Many of its works have been brought to ruin, either by time or by the breath of cold-drakes, but a few pieces of note may still remain in the shadows of Afhân-binnîn.
You have discovered the Depths of Akhatâr. These shadowed pits have not been mapped by any living dwarf, but who knows what could dwell in the depths of the Grey Mountains?
You have discovered Razûkh-zahari, the Room of Rain. A great underground river travels beneath the Grey Mountains, and passes through a carefully-delved crack above the Room of Rain.
You have discovered Thikil-nesad, the Steel Seat. Once the seat of countless Kings of the Longbeards and Zhélruka, Thikil-nesad was abandoned when the Steel Keep fell to Vethúg Wintermind.

You have discovered the Hoarding-vault of Immêsh-khalt. Frozen beneath a layer of impenetrable ice, the Hoarding-vault of Immêsh-khalt is lined with the combined wealth of Durin's Folk and the Zhélruka.
Where Death Lies In Wait
A lingering evil has long remained hidden in the Steel Keep, and it now threatens to overwhelm the dwarves of the North.
The fate of Thikil-gundu remains uncertain, but your efforts have banished the evils that sought shelter in the halls of the Steel Keep.
Banish the curse upon Thikil-gundu
A lingering evil has long remained hidden in the Steel Keep, and it now threatens to overwhelm the dwarves of the North.
Lost Lore of the Dwarf-holds: Thikil-gundu
You have learned the history of Thikil-gundu from the perspective of Karazgar, the Weeping Warrior.
Discover and compile the lost lore of Thikil-gundu
Built by the dwarves and stolen by dragons, Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep, has borne witness to a tragic and terrible history.

Reclaimer of Thikil-gundu

Before the coming of Hrímil Frost-heart and her spawn, Vethúg Wintermind, the Steel Keep was home to both the Longbeards and Zhélruka over the course of many long years. In the wake of Vethúg's defeat at Erebor, Nori set forth with a small company to reclaim the lost hoards of Thikil-gundu. However, great wealth is not all that remains hidden in its frozen halls, and the Dwarves of the North shall soon have to contend with the true master of Thikil-gundu if what was lost might still be reclaimed.

Try an apple goblin
You donned the costume and went from door to neighbourhood door. But have you tasted each kind of treat?
An apple, baked until soft and sweet, then imaginitively decorated.
Based on third-party accounts of the Beornings' famed honey-cakes, these bear but the slightest resemblance.
Many assume 'twist' describes what one's mouth does upon tasting these.
Hobbit children hold that there is a real midge hidden in every one.
A secret medley of Shire berries. Sticky fingers, guaranteed.
Not too minty, and the nuts inside are superb.
What began as a bit of a joke became, over time, one of the Harvest Festival's most prized treats.
Of course it isn't made of actual Ents! Don't believe everything Prisca Boffin's children tell you.
Rest is for after the Harvest Festival ends.

Complete Treats or Trickery: Second Helpings
You have sampled wide and eaten deep of the Harvest Festival treats, but can you truly say you know each of them as well as the back of your own teeth?
Your mouth becomes so dry, it might just be tree-bark for all that you can say.
You may be somewhat queasy from all the treats you have eaten, but you have not yet made yourself properly ill.
You could almost swear the little thing sneered at you.
Too sweet... too sweet to possibly bear.
Your mouth has twisted so far around it has nearly become a grin.
The more you cram into your mouth at once, the less you notice... whatever those specks might be.
Some are tarred and feathered. You are to be jammed and crumb-flecked.
After about the eleventh, you begin to suspect their little suspicious eyes watch you as you raise them to your mouth.
It suddenly strikes you that you know where the actual gold must be. It is beneath the party tree, of course. Or no, in Gamgee's garden. Or here, here in your pockets all along.

How they jumped! Gandalf was astonished, as they all shouted with surprise and delight.
'This is not my adventure. I may look in on you again before it is over, for I have some rather pressing business to attend to.'
'A very good tale!' said Beorn. 'The best I have heard for a long while. Let's have something to eat!'
The dwarves' beards quivered as they listened, for they knew that soon they must venture into the Mirkwood.
'I hope you like the look of it. Now you must send back Beorn's ponies that you have borrowed.'
There, far away was the Lonely Mountain on the edge of the horizon. Snow remaining on its highest peak, unmelted and gleaming.
<rgb=#33BEFF>'And here is the burglar!' exclaimed Bilbo stepping into the middle, and slipping off the ring</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>'Up the trees quick!' cried Gandalf. They ran to the trees at the glade's edge</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>The wizard and the eagle-lord appeared to know one another, and to be on friendly terms</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>'Well, now there are fifteen of you. Perhaps we can finish this story without any more interruptions.'</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>Beorn in his deep rolling voice told tales of the wild lands and of the dark and dangerous wood</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>'Well, here is Mirkwood, the greatest of the forests of the Northern world!' said Gandalf</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>'So comes the snow after the fire. Adventures and even dragons have their ending!'</rgb>

<rgb=#33BEFF>'I always meant to see you all safe over these mountains,' said Gandalf</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>There was a buzzing, humming, and a droning in the air. Such bees were busy everywhere!</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>'The horses have gone to tell Beorn of the arrival of strangers,' said Gandalf</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>'May the wind under your wings bear you where the moon strides and the sun soars.'</rgb>
<rgb=#33BEFF>Bilbo's heart leaped into his mouth as he wriggled. Buttons burst off in every direction</rgb>

Follow the path of Thorin and Company through the Vales of Anduin.
They were bigger than your thumb, much bigger, and the bands of yellow on their black bodies shone a radiant gold.
'Here they are! They don't look dangerous.' Beorn laughed a great, low laugh, and put down his axe.
He was through, with coat torn, running down the steps, while confused goblins were still picking up his buttons at the gate.
You would have laughed, if you had seen the dwarves, up in the trees with their beards hanging down, like old gentlemen.
Gandalf, had once kindly assisted the eagles and healed their lord from an arrow-wound.
'Farewell! Wherever you fare, until your eyrie receive you at your journey's end!'

'Wargs range far and fast. They could be on you before you even knew they were there. If you travel at night, you might be wise to keep a camp-fire going. It would give away your position, but the wargs could smell you out anyway. They do not fear fire, but they do not like it, and it might deter them from testing you. Then again it might not. I will speak true: it is a tough decision. Perhaps it is best to travel only by day, after all.' - Ragnild of the Bear-folk

What lies within the Warrens of Tûn Melen? Only by venturing within can you know for certain, but soldiers that serve the White Hand might already have done so, searching for treasure if not information.
Enemies of the Vales
Conquer the many enemy encampments in the Vales of Anduin.
Conquer the many enemy encampments in the Vales of Anduin.

Ugúrz established his camp of Brafulug to prey upon traders on the road, believing his Orcs would be far enough from Lothlórien to escape the notice of the Elves. This would prove to be a miscalculation.

Wargs have often ventured into the Beorning-lands over the years, but those that dwell at Ylgraf today are larger and more ferocious than others of their kind. These wargs come from Gundabad, and they slink among the rocks to the north of the Beorninghús, waiting to attack Grimbeorn and his kin.

Côs Braen stands along the southern edge of Laerlad, home to the Ungoledain and their venomous kin. They hate Grimbeorn and his folk with a sickly passion, and would wipe out Beornings and Gauredain alike if they were given the chance.

Dredging machines stand in the mud of the Gladden Fields, once manned by Orc and half-orc, but now abandoned. A great hole was delved at Sharkey's Slough, and rumour has it that some prize was found in its depths. The half-orcs remain, seeking further treasures for themselves and not for their master. He remains silent, his thoughts elsewhere, and his servants at the Slough have received no message from him in some time.

Orcs searched the marshland for many weeks, operating from their camp of Lúlstrok in the north-western reaches the Gladden Fields. One of the great dredging machines stands there now, silent and still, but it once churned the earth during both day and night. Weapons, pieces of armour, and other trinkets were brought to Lúlstrok, but wherever these prizes may have gone in the time since is unknown.

The forester camp of Tríubad provided timber and other necessary supplies with which the Woodmen built their homes and the walls of their villages, but then the Taurogrim came. The Woodmen name them 'Thyrsir,' wood-demons, and they fear their blighted touch.
The Woodmen know Tríubad may be lost, but they do not spend time in mourning. Instead they seek adventurers to stop the Thyrsir from spreading the blight to other villages in Woodsedge.

A wet mist soaks the stones that lead to Shathur-munzu, the southernmost outpost of lost Khazad-dûm. The fortress is broken now, and dwarves have not lived there for many years. Shathur-munzu was the site of one of the bloodiest battles in the War of Dwarves and Orcs, and King Thráin did not hold it long.

The Beornings keep one eye on the Goblin-gate, for on this side of the mountains it is the primary way into, and out of, Goblin-town. During the last days of the War of the Ring, Orcs and goblins streamed through the Goblin-gate into the Vales of Anduin, raiding and burning peaceful Woodmen villages. Led by Grimbeorn the Old, the Beornings and Woodmen stood against the goblins and finally turned them back.
Now Goblin-town is quiet and there is little activity at the Goblin-gate, but the Beornings have not forgotten. They watch it still.

The peaceful Woodmen village of Waldfast has been destroyed by a goblin-host. Sentries are posted throughout the village, but their numbers are too few to explain the scope of the destruction. A cave behind the village might hold answers.

Following the final battles of the War of the Ring, a company of Orcs has established a tenuous foothold among the hills of Woodsedge. These are the Shapag-hai, and they have discovered they prefer to prey upon traders and travellers rather than warriors and soldiers. From their camp of Fil Sulmog they practice the art of pillaging, and have become quite good at it.
Defeat many goblins in the Vales of Anduin

Defeat many goblins in the Vales of Anduin.

'They called it Orchost, but it is better known by another name: Goblin-town. Indeed, once it was a dwarf-delving, the High Hold of Zudrâligal. But the dwarves were driven out and the goblins made it their own. They stripped out most remnants of the dwarves, leaving only the barest traces of its former ancestry.' - Gandalf the Wizard

Once a beautiful lake, the Gladdenmere was wracked by upheavals during the War of the Last Alliance, and the land all about became a vast marshland, a perilous waste of dark pools and tangled grasses. The Gladdenmere has once again become accessible, but the path that allows curious travellers to reach it also allows passage for dangerous foes who might threaten the Wilderfolk of the Vales....

Protectors of the Vales

Home to Grimbeorn the Old and others of his family, the Beorninghús is generally closed to outsiders. During the final weeks of the War of the Ring, the Beornings found it necessary to take a more active role in the protection of the Vales of Anduin.
The sound of birdsong and the buzzing of dumbledors greet all who do approach the Beorninghús, but if they fail to ask Grimbeorn's permission, those are not the only sounds they will hear; Grimbeorn's wrath will be both loud and swift.
Explore the settlements of the Wilderfolk who live in the Vales of Anduin.
Explore the settlements of the Wilderfolk who live in the Vales of Anduin.

Located not far from the lost dwarf fortress of Shathur-munzu, the village of Arhaim is occupied by both Woodmen and Beornings. Together they maintain trade with the Elves and live a simple life in Duskenvale.
Gudule keeps a homestead in the Wolf-denes. 'This land has never been safe,' he says. 'We live too near to the mountains to sleep very soundly at night. But this is home.'

The Woodmen town of Hultvís was attacked during the closing weeks of the War of the Ring, but the Orcs and wargs were pushed back and eventually defeated by a united force of Beornings and Woodmen at the Battle of the Old Ford. Now the town seeks to rebuild and refortify, and seeks adventurers willing to assist with the recovery effort.
The Woodmen are a superstitious people, and at Hultvís you are sure to hear many legends and tales. These concern the beautiful and forlorn Maiden of Gladden, the spectral Vagári the Wanderer, hunger-crazed Old Mad Ubb, and the vanished Hól-budlan.

The village of Blómgard is found in Laerlad, not far from the fens of the Gladden Fields. The Woodmen there speak in hushed whispers of an unnatural darkness and a scuttling sound on the roofs of their homes. The leader of Blómgard, Odahild, has a reputation for honesty and she is not one to speak falsely, but others in the Vales of Anduin question if the tales from Blómgard are true. An adventurer might get to the bottom of it.
This Beorning watchpost guards the road into Duskenvale. Elves also keep watch on the southern road, but neither trusts the other to do it alone.

At Glándir, the Elves guard the road into Lothlórien, maintaining the safety of the Golden Wood. Lady Galadriel and Lord Celeborn have been known to visit the Elves here on occasion, seeking reports from the Vales of Anduin and bringing food and cheer with them to relieve the burden of those Elves who stay outside the bounds of Lórien.

The outpost of Vegbár allows the Beornings to keep watch over the road between the High Pass and the Old Ford, and to charge their toll of travellers and traders who go that way. Skalla commands at Vegbár, and despite his gruff exterior he cares deeply for his neighbours and worries for their safety.

The forester Ainhard keeps a homestead in the Wolf-denes, and his closest companions are his three hounds. He lives in fear of Orcs, goblins, and taurogrim, for he is no warrior. He relies upon the nearby Beorning outpost of Vegbár for protection.
Hodver keeps a homestead in the Wolf-denes, but he is ever ready to make for the Beorning outpost of Vegbár at the first sign of Orcs or wargs. 'I am no coward,' he says, 'but I am no fool, either.'

'That was the largest warg I have ever seen, and the smartest. I have heard that they grow even larger in Mordor, but that does not concern me. Now, if those were to possess the wits of those we've seen in the Vales, then I would be worried.' - Skalla, Captain of Vegbár

'The Vales of Anduin are home to many varieties of beast and insect that will do you no harm. But there are others that have been seized by the darkness that crept out of Mirkwood, or have been tamed by the Orcs and goblins of the Misty Mountains. Oh yes, there are some that will do you a great deal of harm, if you let them! Show those foes no mercy, to save the rest!' - Radagast the Brown

Much like Enedwaith on the far side of the Misty Mountains, the Vales of Anduin consist primarily of untamed wilderness, home to simple villages, hermits’ shelters, and only few roads. Most attempts to rule this wilderness have been short-lived and have long since fallen to ruin. You have done much to aid the Wilderfolk who live here, and made more secure a traditionally unsafe region.

Sites of the Vales

The Eyrie of the Great Eagles can only be reached by flying. It is the home of Gwaihir the Windlord and his folk, perhaps the oldest denizens of the Vales of Anduin. They have ranged far and wide from this high perch, and their coming has always signaled a change in the tides of fate: during Bilbo's adventures with Thorin and Company, when Gandalf the Grey suffered imprisonment by Saruman the White, and during the concluding hours of the War of the Ring.
If you should come to the Eyrie, it is always to your benefit to be as polite as you can be to your hosts. Not all of the Great Eagles are friendly with outsiders or unwinged folk.
Explore the many interesting locations to be found within the Vales of Anduin.
Explore the many interesting locations to be found within the Vales of Anduin.

The old keep of Avabárg stands on a low islet in the river. Once home to the Horse-folk that would come to be known as the Éothéod, Avabárg now stands empty except for a gloom that has seized the island, and the occasional Orc or goblin that thinks to fortify the island and make it his own.
Woodmen have tried to reclaim it over the years, but each attempt ended in failure, and now they treat it with superstitious fear.

The village of Rhosgobel, once the northernmost settlement of the Wood-elves and later the southernmost, is now home only to Radagast the Brown, one of the five Wizards. For a time he chose a nomadic life and dwelled in Ost Guruth, the Ruin-hold in the Lone Lands, but now he has returned to Woodsedge and seeks to combat the encroaching darkness.

The course of the Gladden did not always run as it does today. During the fighting at the close of the Second Age, Sauron sent forth his dark thought, attempting to rouse great evils to his cause. Whether such calamities responded to him is unknown, but around this time there were massive quakes in the Misty Mountains, shaking the dwarf-halls as far north as the High Pass.
The upheaval changed the course of the river, carrying sediment downstream and choking the Gladdenmere until its banks overflowed. Water poured over the cliff, flooding the valley and submerging its roads. In this way, the Gladden Fields became a wide marsh of reeds and dark pools. In time the level of the lake was restored, and the Gladden Falls became the narrow torrent it is today.

The High Pass through the Misty Mountains was treacherous and difficult to cross for many years, for both goblin raiders and stone-giants haunted the stones and crags and made travel difficult. When the Beornings arrived, the High Pass was cleared and they made an effort to push back these dangers. In return they charged a toll for passage, which other folk considered an unfair cost.
The High Pass was blocked during the War of the Ring, but today the Beornings have cleared it once again. Some say friendly stone-giants aided in this effort, but Grimbeorn's people will not say if this is so.

Hadhodiant was a mighty dwarf-bridge that served as the primary means of crossing the Anduin in the north, but it was broken shortly after the fall of Shathur-munzu in the Second Age. It was rebuilt, and indeed when the Great Alliance marched south to besiege Mordor, it was by way of the Hadhodiant that they crossed the Anduin.
But the bridge would not last. It broke in the middle, and when artisans from the Iron Hills were summoned to repair it, they were set upon by Orcs and every dwarf was slain. Over the course of centuries, stones of the bridge continued to fall into the river, until at last a tremendous flood swept away much of the ruin.
With the Hadhodiant destroyed, the Old Ford has come back into service as the primary means of crossing the Anduin in the north.

The Lost Lore of Rhovanion
You have discovered a very old song about the woods and waters of Rhovanion. Perhaps this is what the ancient Elves heard when they listened to the water cascading over the many falls.
Complete all of the Lost Lore of Rhovanion.
Complete all of the Lost Lore of Rhovanion.

You found every stanza for a bit of doggerel the Woodmen of the Vales of Anduin tell to their children: the song of Old Mad Ubb. He sounds like a rather unpleasant creature... and also a little familiar.
You have learned much about the difficulties the Dwarves of Erebor faced in the North, and how those troubles often took a familiar shape: Dragon!

The lure of the ancient, lost city of Thafar-gathol has entranced the Zhélruka for much of their history, but despite many expeditions into the Grey Mountains it remains hidden, if it ever existed at all. You learned eight stanzas of a song extolling its virtues and its great wealth.

As you discovered in Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep of the Grey Mountains, not all of Sauron's servants gave up hope at the defeat of their master. Karazgar, the Weeping Warrior, devised a plan to ensnare the Herald of Winter, claiming he would not suffer defeat as Sauron did.

You have learned a song which tells the history of Járnfast. Like the Dwarves of the Iron Hills who dwell there, its fortunes were built almost entirely upon the material that gives that region its name, and the song its refrain: iron hard, and iron cold.

You discovered a number of curious scratches in the hard stone of the Grey Mountains, and with much diligence you uncovered the full story. It is a cruel record of the dragon Smaug, and it tells of his growing fury and his desire for vengeance against the Dwarves of the North.

You have learned about the tradition of the Black Arrow, a tradition which was kept alive by lords of Dale for hundreds of years. How fortunate that it was so! For it was Bard's Black Arrow that at last slew the dragon Smaug.

You have learned a tale of the North that is all-too-familiar, for there are others like it. It is a tale of the enmity between Elves and dwarves, but in this case the tale goes further, to the healing between those folk, and that is a welcome difference.

These were the burial-houses of Minas Ithil, where the bones of the dead were laid to rest in solemn state, but that was long ago. Now this place has fallen to darkness and evil, and it is called Gorthad Nûr, the Deep-barrow. Vengeful shades and foul kergrim have been drawn to the tombs, and they will not allow any incursion into the domain they have taken for their own.

Gorthad Nûr was once a place of solemn rest and peace, but without the maintenance of upkeep and cleaning provided by its keepers, it fell to filth and pestilence. Tombs throughout Middle-earth have long proven impossible for the vile kergrim to resist, and in Gorthad Nûr the creatures had time enough to develop their own rituals among the forgotten bones. They became the keepers of the Deep-barrow, and very few among the Free People remembered the place it once had been, before the desecration, before the rot.

The first Men of Mordor to serve the Dark Lord became known as the Mordorrim, but as more and more Men fell under his sway and the breadth of his dominion grew greater, the Men who gave themselves into his service came to bear fearsome and strange titles.

Throughout the history of Middle-earth, there have been Men who have shunned the rule of Kings and forsaken their own heritage. Far too often they fall under the sway of the Dark Lord, who plays upon their distrust of the great Kingdoms, threatens them with hidden force, or sways them with false riches and power. However, there are some Men who freely offer themselves into his service and swear unerring loyalty to the Dark Lord.

Complete \qThe Witch-king, Lord of the Nazgûl, Scourge of Mordor\q
Complete \qThe Woe of Khand, Scourge of Mordor\q
Complete \qThe Black Blade of Lebennin, Scourge of Mordor\q
Complete \qThe Cursed Rider, Scourge of Mordor\q

From the distant south he came, bringing fear and fire to every coast he spied with his glass. His was a reign of blood, and he drew it from all who lived in sight and scent of the Sea. Was that the reason Sauron gave to him the ring Khânto, which is Pain-giver? With the power of it, the Forsaken Reaver could not be stopped, and his laughter carried inland on fell winds; he was among Sauron's swiftest servants, and the cruelest.

None can say what ship bore him hither to Middle-earth before Númenor was lost, but once he accepted Sauron's gift he could no longer be counted among the Men of that land. He dwelt in Thaurband, a fortress in southern Mordor, not far from the inland Sea. It was from that keep that the fear of him spread, giving him a new title to replace the name he no longer needed. He became the Gloom of Núrn, though he did not stay there, and roved far and wide at Sauron's command.

Few among the living ever heard him speak, but his visage was well-known, and feared. They called him the Grim Southron, and while Men quailed at his approach during the Second Age, during the Third the legend of his malice had only grown. In later days it was he that Lhaereth the Stained followed in secret to Dol Guldur, where she discovered Sauron and helped him recover, for a price. Did the Dark Lord deal out reward or punishment for his Nazgûl's lapse? But that was much later. During the Second Age, the Grim Southron was known only to be patient, loyal, and silent.

They called him the High Sorcerer of Harad, but for most of those who fought against Sauron it was just a name. He rarely left the dungeon fastnesses of Mordor, for he delighted in the working of foul rituals and the mastery of fell magics, and gave his thought to little else. But when the Dark Lord saw fit to send him forth, Men and Elves knew to give him a wide berth, or suffer. It was Mêbat he wore, the Mirth-eater, and wherever he went there was an end to laughter, and only the onset of grief.
The Nine

Once he was a great king in lands far to the east, accustomed to rule and unwilling to bend the knee to any other. But then came a giver of gifts and a promiser of power, and upon accepting these lures, the great king changed. No longer did he rule his lands with mercy, and neither did he remain in his own kingdom. He became Rhûn's bane, and by that name came he to be known as the Bane of Rhûn, and elsewhere.

The Great Alliance of Elves and Men stood in defiance of Sauron for long years of siege, but even their greatest heroes came to fear his deadliest servants. These were the Nazgûl, and their number was Nine.

He moved at speed across the battlefield, running down the warriors who dared stand against him, fewer as the siege went on. He was the Cursed Rider, and the sound of his approach turned even courageous blood to water. In later years he would command armies from within the walls of Dol Guldur, but during the Second Age he preferred to fight from the back of his black steed, alone.

Greatest and most feared of the Nine, the Witch-king stalked the battlefield but rarely, leaving the fortresses of Mordor only at Sauron's most pressing command. In later years the Lord of the Nazgûl would raise from nothing the Land of Angmar, wielding it in furtherance of the Dark Lord's aim to destroy the northern kingdom of Arnor, but at the close of the Second Age that was still far off in the mists of Time. During the Siege of Barad-dûr, the Witch-king could be found testing the weaknesses of the armies arrayed against his master, seeking the most valuable prize of all: information.

He was the Woe of Khand, and with the blessing of Sauron he strode across the unconquered lands and claimed them for the Dark Lord. The ring gifted to him was called Adâsh, and many were the foes it made, many the proud warriors he brought low. He found great joy in the bringing of war, and always had done so, but with the power given to him by Sauron, the Woe of Khand became ever more deadly, more relentless, and more unforgiving.

In later days, the Black Blade of Lebennin was oft-seen stalking among the hills and forests of Western Gondor, striking fear into the hearts of Men with both deadly countenance and fearsome sword. For those few who did not flee, his words poured like honey into their unwilling ears and drove them to terrible acts of evil. This may have proved his worst and most effective weapon.

The Great Alliance of Elves and Men stood in defiance of Sauron for long years of siege, but even their greatest heroes came to fear his deadliest servants. These were the Nazgûl, and their number was Nine.
Discover the entrance to Ghashan-kútot - the Hall of Black Lore.

This was once the great lore-hall of Minas Ithil, the store-house of Númenórean knowledge and learning prized by Queen Valardis, but no longer. Now it is Ghashan-kútot, the Hall of Black Lore, and someone... or something... stalks among its shelves, seeking to acquire the dark knowledge of all things.

Long was Minas Morgul considered the dominion of the Lord of the Nazgûl, and it will not easily break free of that heritage. For that stain to be wiped clean will take much effort on the part of adventuring heroes.

Complete quests in Thuringwath.

At the end of the Second Age, a force of Galadhrim commanded by Galadriel and Celeborn drove the Nazgûl from Minas Ithil. The Lord sought to secure the tunnels of Torech Ungol, and the Lady attempted to cleanse the city of its corruption; in both endeavours they met with success, but for all their foresight and their wisdom, they could not pierce the sorceries of Sauron. Thuringwath remained hidden, and they did not find it.

'If I see one more spider,' Atli Spider-bane began, when a horrible chittering noise erupted behind him. 'Ah, nevermind!' he chortled excitedly. 'There will always be more spiders around Cirith Ungol! I do not know what I expected!'

'They call it the Harrowing,' one young soldier in Echad Uial whispered to his captain. 'The Orcs battle for control of the lowest level of the city, and neither faction can wrest the upper hand away from the other.'
'The Harrowing, eh?' his captain answered. 'What do you call it?'
The young soldier looked first one way and then the other, and lowered his voice.
'Orc fight,' he whispered. His captain nodded, and handed the soldier a whetstone.
'Good enough for me,' he said.

'She fled from the destruction, and then from the Elves that hunted her but could not end her life, and she came at last to the Mountains of Shadow. There she found a crevice high above Imlad Ithil and crept from there into a deep, dark pit. How do I know this? For I went and sought her there.' - Celeborn of Lórien

'The ceremonies conducted within Thuringwath were unspeakable. That means we will speak of them not, and I ask you not to press the subject!' - Gandalf
'Treasure? Aye, if you find it, I say keep it. Consider it your reward for helping us keep the road clear, and as safe as may be.' - Captain Beregond
'These treasures are very old, relics from another Age. How long did they lie hidden within the Valley of the Secret Shadow, and should they have remained there?' - Gandalf
'Treasure? I have no need for treasure. All I want is an end to the war, and to return to our homes. That is the only treasure I seek.' - Tárandil of Gondor
'They say it was a beautiful city once. I do not know if it will be again.' - King Elessar of Gondor
'It is the Pass of Shadow, the Rath Dúath. The road runs by Minas Morgul, and many are the evils that watch us from the heights.' - Faramir, Prince of Ithilien

Years of grinding war and siege reduced the arid but fertile plains of Mordor to a wasteland, and with the continued threat of Sauron's evil during the Third Age of Middle-earth, they never recovered. Many were the fortifications devised by the Great Alliance during the closing years of their war, but three thousand years later only ruins and remnants remained of them, a reminder that all glory must fade, and even victory may not last.
'The real treasure, if you ask me, was the spiders we slew along the way!' - Atli Spiderbane
'You can find treasure anywhere! It might not even look like treasure, and still be valuable.' - Covadil, Scholar of Gondor
'What did you find? Spiders? Ah, tell me more. It sounds to me as if our work is not yet finished, my friend!' - Atli Spiderbane

Explore the Song-house of Lindalírë
Explore Roz Dagalur, the Fiend-house
Explore Barad Angarth, the Gate-wardens' Keep
Explore Barad Orhant, the Tower of the Treegarth
Explore Barad Elenath, the Star-gazers' Spire

The baths of Minas Ithil were once a place to rest and relax, and the people who lived here scrubbed away the dirt and the grime of their daily lives, sinking into waters of contentment. Now the baths are empty of all good folk, haunted by shades of evil.
'Is there anything more sad to the heart than a garden dead and twisted? So it was with Ithilien, and already we work to restore my land's beauty. Perhaps it can be the same here.' - Prince Faramir
The Dome of Evening has been sealed away for years uncounted, and for purpose unknown.

Most of Minas Ithil's treasures were already looted, either by good folk fleeing from the city in advance of its several falls, or by forces of evil in search of artifacts and gold. The relics that remain have been corrupted by the long residence of the Nazgûl and their minions, and now Bâr Maenath holds only ill fortune for the few treasure-seekers who dare explore there.
Once a place of feasting and good cheer, the Wracking-hall has not known a meal free of terror for countless years. Now it is a den of evil, and only horrors sup there.
The Shadow-roost of Gath Daeroval is home to Khatlob, the great brood-mother who birthed the vile flying mounts used by the Nazgûl in pursuit of the aims of Sauron.
Barad Cúron rises from the top of the city, a place of mystery much-coveted by each of the Masters of Mordor.
Ugrukhôr's forces have pushed into Minas Morgul and established the encampment of Zhar Skator upon the Circle of Wrath.
The sprawling encampment of Zhar Dushgoi was established by Gothmog's Orcs who gather what defenses they can to hold the Circle of Wrath from Ugrukhôr's forces.
