Explore the Gloomwaters

Barad Angarth has been reclaimed from the Orcs, and now it serves the White Company as a foothold in the city. Further such towers may better serve the reclamation, but they will first need to be taken from the foes that hold them.
Explore the many places of fear and dread that can be found within Minas Morgul.
Explore the many places of fear and dread that can be found within Minas Morgul, the Dead City.

The Circle of Mirth above which stood Barad Arthir has become the Circle of Despair, haunted by spirits and a place of great danger for Faramir's White Company, which seeks to restore the city. That goal remains far-off, but every step taken is a step closer, and with the spirits driven out of Barad Arthir, perhaps more victories will soon follow.
The gauntmen walk in Roz Dagalur, and few only know the way inside. Fewer still know the way out.

They say the forge works still, but the hands of men touch it not. In Búrzangh some ghostly power takes command, seeking to craft some relic of ancient days, but none among the living can say what artifact the spirits desire to create.
The smell of decaying flesh fills the Hall of Rot, and wights stalk among chambers once home to light and life. But those days are gone, and King Elessar is uncertain if they can ever return.

The dusty paths between the shelves of Ghashan-kútot are walked by an unnatural force. It answers to the name Dolguzigir, but few only have seen the Accursed Sage. It is said he can drape himself in whatever form he wishes, but he is not a Man, and if he appears so it is only in answer to his whim. He is eager to learn the story of any who stray into the Hall of Black Lore, eager almost to the point of sickness, and he does not wish for any to leave... uncollected.

Minstrels and poets flocked to Minas Ithil when Gondor was at its height, and the lamps were lit in the Song-house of Lindalírë long into the night. But the Night proved darker and more insidious, and with the coming of the Witch-king the theatre is host only to the Dead.

Barad Orhant once overlooked the Circle of Skill in Minas Ithil, but now the view has changed. That tier is now the Circle of Sorrow, and it is home only to the Dead. So too was the Tower of the Treegarth, but it has been seized for the use of the White Company. Perhaps it will be the same for the Circle of Sorrow.

Barad Elenath, the Star-gazers' Spire, was once a place of study and learning. From its great height the scholars of the city spent night after night studying the moon and the stars, but that was long ago. The merrevail of Lhaereth the Stained claimed this tower, and have only just been driven away. The tower serves now as a foothold for the White Company's reclamation of Minas Morgul.

'No one expected the siege to last as long as it did. We thought Sauron must soon emerge from his tower, but we were wrong. Many were the foes he sent against us, but never did he approach us directly... not until the end.' - Isildur

'Lhaereth the Stained, Lady of Blight. She is still out there, even if fewer of her winged servants live to trouble us.' - Culang, Ranger of the Grey Company

'The Orcs hold sway over their part of the city, but do you know something? I think they may be a worse threat to each other than we are to them; perhaps they will fight amongst themselves and do us a favour!' - Culang, Ranger of the Grey Company

'The upper tiers are stalked by horrors, tormented wraiths that remember nothing but the evils of the Witch-king and his master Sauron. They are dangerous foes, but you have proven you have the courage to face them, and to rid the world of their menace.' - Gandalf

'I remember the banners waving above the arid plains, and the lives that were lost, and even if the defeat of Sauron did not last, still it was worth the fight. There was victory, but there was sorrow too. I remember it all.' - Elrond of Rivendell
'It will be the Dead City no longer. That is my king's command.' - Faramir, Prince of Ithilien
'You slew how many spiders? Save some for me, will you? I don't want you appropriating my epithet, now!' - Atli Spiderbane

Explore Ufurok
Explore Laugdursh
Explore Falch Gurth
Explore Torgris

It was at Bâr Nírnaeth, the Houses of Lamentation, where the Nazgûl worshipped their master Sauron. Many were the dark and profane rituals that were conducted here in his name, and the mark of those terrible evils remain still upon every one of their buildings and courtyards.
Scouting Thuringwath
Explore Bâr Nírnaeth

Falch Gurth, the Deathly Cleft, was a secret path leading back into the southern Ephel Dúath. It was hewn by the Nazgûl when they first conquered Minas Ithil during the Second Age, and hidden by concealing spells that could not be broken while Sauron survived. It was visible only to the Dark Lord and his servants, but now, with its master defeated, it is revealed to all as the passage to the long-hidden gorge of Thuringwath.
Explore the dark and dreadful sites that lie within Thuringwath.
Explore the dark and dreadful sites that lie within Thuringwath.

Atop a massive underground tomb rests Aufaltor, the Fane of the Eye. Without number are those counted amongst the Dead of Aufaltor, for it was here the servants of the Nazgûl laid the lifeless bodies of those they deemed unworthy of the dark rites of Agath-kali, Mistress of Lamentation, in Bâr Nírnaeth.

Long before Ufurok became a monument to the Gaunt-lords, it was a fortress erected in defence of Bâr Nírnaeth. It was Laugdursh, the Dire Span over which the Nazgûl and their most unfortunate victims travelled to the Houses of Lamentation. It fell into disuse once the Nazgûl adopted fell-beasts as their winged mounts in the Third Age of the world.

It was to Ufurok, the Dreadfast, that the Witch-king of Angmar drew five of the mightiest Gaunt-men of the Elder Days. It was his will to empower them, crafting them into terrible, twisted reflections of the Wizards whose arrival in Middle-earth threatened the Dark Lord. The fell sorceries of the Witch-king unmade them and reshaped them into the Gaunt-lords. These were their names, and their number was five: Ivar the Blood-hand, Thadúr the Ravager, Ferndúr the Virulent, Drugoth the Death-monger, and Gortheron the Doom-caller.
With many of their number too fearful to press into the shadows of Thuringwath, the Rangers of Ithilien make camp at Torgris, the Hidden Cleft, a small crack in the heart of Falch Gurth.
Learn of the many battles fought by the Great Alliance in Mordor Besieged.
Learn of the many battles fought by the Great Alliance in Mordor Besieged.

'Ours was the Great Alliance, and it was formed with bonds of friendship against a common foe. But Sauron's forces were also united, taken from many different pits of evil, and forged into a singular fighting force. Their bonds were made not of friendship but of fear... fear of their dark master. Still it proved effective.' - Isildur
Learn of the many battles fought by the Great Alliance

Isildur has much to say about the deeds of heroism accomplished on behalf of the Great Alliance during the Siege of Barad-dûr.

'Many were the triumphs of the Great Alliance. They bring a smile to my face even now, despite the years and the knowledge they did not last. We fought to save the world from Sauron, and for a time we did. For a time we did.' - Isildur

'Can Minas Morgul ever truly be cleansed of its evil? I do not know, but my king has commanded it, and therefore we will try to see it done.' - Faramir, Prince of Ithilien
'The roots of the tale begin more than three thousand years ago, and span even unto the present. But to the Great Powers that is only a small portion indeed.' - Gandalf

'These lands have changed over time, as is the nature of all things. But for the Black Land and the Morgul Vale, that nature is evil, for Sauron and his servants had a hand in it. I do not know how these lands might have fared had Sauron not come to this place and taken it for his own, but things might have been otherwise.' - Gandalf

'Sauron ruled his armies through fear, even before his defeat at the hands of the Last Alliance, and that fear remains though he does not. It is a lash both cruel and effective, and still it drives his servants against us.' - Gandalf

'Sauron paid little heed to the pass of Cirith Ungol, for it was guarded by a dark shadow that paid him no homage, but would prove a more deadly obstacle than any he might think to set there. Still the tower was occupied, and kept watch over the pass in the rare event that She might sleep too deeply to feed.' - Gandalf

'The city was not always thus. Once it was a place of beauty. I know, for I remained there for a time during the war, keeping it safe from the assault of the enemy. The Nazgûl did not dare oppose me.' - Galadriel, Lady of Lórien
'A cabin, you say? In this land? Bah, I do not trust it.' - Captain Beregond
'The Last Alliance? Was it the last? We called it the Great Alliance.' - Isildur

'Few have passed beyond the Falch Gurth into Thuringwath, but you have done so. Fewer still would dare to do what you have done, my friend, and this Middle-earth is a safer place for your efforts. As always, I thank you, for that is my charge also.' - Gandalf
Complete quests in Rath Dúath.

'It was not called the Morgul Vale then, of course. No, it was named Imlad Ithil, the Vale of the Moon, and Elves did sometimes tarry there to admire its splendour, particularly when the full moon rose between the peaks and shone down upon the valley's length.' - Celeborn of Lórien

'I am grieved to hear that the Orcs remain still in this world. They were a fearsome foe when we fought against Sauron, cruel and deadly, without an ounce of mercy. Many of my friends and soldiers perished in their encampments. The one called Mokh Shapat remained for years, despite our attempts to eradicate it.' - Isildur

'Mokh Darga was a large encampment from which the Orcs launched many attacks upon Adambel. My father himself turned away several of these assaults, deeds which inspired not just the men under his command but also proved an inspiration to me and to my brother. Alas for Anárion!'
'Barthost, you say? I do not remember that name. Perhaps Gultháva's enchantment has not yet released me from its grip.' - Isildur

'It was a camp of evil men, sworn to serve Sauron. I never set foot inside, but I know the forces of Sauron festered in their malice within its bounds, and set forth with hatred in their hearts, intending to defeat the Great Alliance.' - Isildur
'Shades drifted within Angathrai, given cruel purpose by Mordorrim cultists and the will of Sauron. Let us not speak of them.' - Isildur

'Díngarth was the most secure location of the Free Peoples, built at the beginning of the siege and repeatedly assailed and rebuilt over the ensuing years. Near the end it was mostly emptied, kept as a last redoubt in the event that the forward forces of the Alliance were overwhelmed and forced to retreat. My sons greatly enjoyed making life difficult for Ontamo, the master of the fortifications at Díngarth, despite my chiding of them for it.' - Isildur
'Adambel was the forward encampment of Men, from whence my father Elendil and my brother Anárion and I commanded our armies. It was the nearest to Barad-dûr we deemed it wise to set camp.' - Isildur

'It was Amon Fuin, the Gloom-hill, the last remaining major fortification held by Sauron’s forces beyond the Dark Tower itself. The Mordorrim conducted sacrifices and other rituals behind the walls of that fortress, and many were the soldiers of the Great Alliance we lost to their deadly excursions.' - Isildur
'The shades and spirits of Matum Graz lingered alongside the dead that walk, and they nursed hatred for the living in their evil hearts. I do not wish to speak of them now.' - Isildur

'It was Ram Raedas, the Ensnaring Wall. We built that fortification athwart the Neck of Iron to keep enemies from crossing through from Udûn and attacking the Great Alliance from the rear.' - Isildur
Explore locations of bravery and heroism to be found within Isildur's tale of Mordor Besieged.
As Gultháva's enchantment fades, Isildur comes to remember the events at the close of the Second Age, when Mordor was besieged.

'Dol Naeg was the name of a rocky spur on the north slope of Amon Amarth. It is a place of great sadness for me, for that is where my father died. It is also where I obtained an artifact of Sauron that brought me only sorrow and grief. Would that I had never stood there!' - Isildur
'I know the tunnel of Halroth, but I never ventured inside. Glorfindel of the Bright Company knows of that place. Let him speak of it, if he will.' - Isildur

'Barad-dûr, the tower of Sauron, was built not by his servants but by Númenórean hands. He has bent it to his evil, and it stood as a cruel mockery to my people. He remained within for the long years of the siege, content to outlast us, but it was not to be.' - Isildur

'The wargs of Baur Kasak were feared by all the men under my command, for the beasts could move at incredible speed across the plains, seizing an unwary soldier with their powerful jaws and charging away in moments. Many of my soldiers insisted upon being accompanied on the plains by an Elf of Gil-galad's forces, for only their swift bows could dissuade the advance of such creatures.' - Isildur

'Echad-in-Edhil was the forward encampment of the Elves, and it was where Gil-galad and his household dwelt for much of the siege. From this camp, the High Elves of the Bright Company undertook many dangerous excursions on the plains before Barad-dûr and against Sauron's servants.' - Isildur

Vile and unpleasant kergrim have settled into Dáru Lagúrz, picking over the remains. Filth and disease have followed them into the Broken Houses, vile dangers to be faced by those few who must gain entrance to that one-time place of rest.
Few of the Rangers of Ithilien have braved the hills of Rath Dúath. There upon an overlook, those few have established the small encampment of Taen Orwath.
Scouting Rath Dúath
Explore Taen Orwath
Explore Râkh Mathán
Explore Banám Lugaun
Explore Shakam Moz
Explore Dáru Lagúrz, the Broken Houses

This western gate from the valley could be shut in case of trouble, preventing access to Ithilien. This proved a fairly frequent occurrence during the long and tumultuous history of Gondor. Annon Morgul has been damaged by war, and is now a ruin.
Explore the many locations where danger might lurk, and where good-hearted folk might oppose it, within Rath Dúath.
Explore the many locations where danger might lurk, and where good-hearted folk might oppose it, within Rath Dúath.

Countless bones fill the Deep-barrow of Gorthad Nûr, an unholy ossuary carved into the rock of the mountains. Tombs and shrines remain, but they have been desecrated by dark arts. Kergrim howl among the forgotten statues, hungry for flesh, but few other sounds can be heard.

Prince Faramir's White Company established the camp of Echad Uial on the eastern side of Rath Dúath, intending to marshal expeditions into Minas Morgul itself. But they have spent much attention maintaining the watch on the Dread Door of Fennas Gost, and there are never enough adventurers willing to face the Dead City.

The warg dens of Râkh Mathán extend up into the hills surrounding Rath Dúath, and the creatures' wailing howls strike fear even into the brave hearts of Faramir's Rangers. Especially the Rangers, for they have experienced much grief at the teeth and claws of the beasts during the last several months, as the wargs have ranged further from their dens at the command of their Orkish masters.

The Orc encampment of Banám Lugaun sees a great deal of activity during both night and day, serving as a waypoint of sorts for servants of evil on their way to one place or another within Imlad Morgul.

The merrevail roost of Shakam Moz watches over both Rath Dúath and Lhingris from the high peak, and the minions of Lhaereth the Stained prove a terror for all who are forced to travel in those valleys.

Anborn, Ranger of Ithilien, has established the camp of Estolad Lân on the western side of Rath Dúath. From there he seeks to carry out the commands of Prince Faramir of Ithilien, though the camp rests nearly beneath the very shadow of Minas Morgul.

This is the main bridge over the Morgulduin. It has been destroyed and rebuilt several times throughout the history of Rath Dúath, but now it stands anew, carrying the primary road to Minas Morgul across the rushing waters.

The Filth-well of Eithel Gwaur is located at the source of the Morgulduin, and appears to be the cause of that river's foul contagion. It is not known when the cavernous cistern first fell prey to its corruption and disease, but the river has not been called Ithilduin for many years, and its clean waters are only the faintest memory now.

Explore the Remmorchant
Explore the Straight Stair
Explore the Winding Stair
Explore Echad Taerdim
Scouting Cirith Ungol
Explore Taurlingol
Explore Kaslokroz

This is the first of the stairs climbed by Frodo Baggins, Samwise Gamgee, and the creature Gollum by which they intended to gain access to the Land of Mordor. The stairs are tall and steep, and while the climb is straight and without turns, the steps are uneven and treacherous. The stairs are cut into the flanks of the Ephel Dúath and climb from the floor of the valley up to the pass itself, on the western side of Cirith Ungol.
Explore the many dreadful and worrisome locations to be found within Cirith Ungol.
Explore the many dreadful and worrisome locations to be found within Cirith Ungol.

The Ungoledain have come a long way overland across Middle-earth, following a call only they can hear, and they have established the resting-place of Cadar Skûs in the mountains. Is their long journey finally near its end?

None have seen beyond the entrance to Remmorchant, the Net of Darkness, for that is the deepest and most subterranean of Ungwetári's tunnels, the pitted and sunless abyss into which she retreated after her unexpected injury at the hands of Samwise Gamgee and the point of Sting, the Gondolin-forged blade wielded by both Bilbo and Frodo Baggins, and later by the terrified but deadly gardener of Bag End.
Ungwetári knew nothing of those hobbits or the lineage of that blade, but she remembers the pain of that encounter, and it has built in her a white-hot and blinding rage. In Remmorchant she broods upon her wound, and festers in her hatred.

The forest of Taurlingol has become spider-infested, a place of webs and unnatural voices. If the Ungoledain can understand the chittering of their idols, they are unwilling to share its meaning. This is probably a good thing.

Uruks following the commands of Rukhor the Pale Herald have established this camp atop the Winding Stair, west of Cirith Ungol. It seems they have run afoul of the Ungoledain and spiders ranging out of Taurlingol and Torech Ungol, which is unsurprising. Expectedly, some uruks have also fallen to infighting among themselves and with other Orc-bands creeping down from the tower and through the pass.

The pass of Cirith Ungol was rarely left unguarded, but few only would dare to make the crossing while the Orcs of the tower could spy on them from above. The worse and far greater danger was spoken of only in whispers, for few good folk knew even rumour of it. Some dark terror dwelled in the tunnel of Torech Ungol, through which the path must lead. Even should a traveller make it safely through the web-haunted passage, the tunnel gave way to a chasm open to the sky but riddled with cave-mouths on each cliffside from which any foe might have the advantage of surprise. No tactician would advise taking that road.
It was the favourite hunting-ground of Ungwetári, last daughter of Ungoliant, and only the very foolish or the very desperate should go that way.

This second stair begins high above the valley floor, and unlike the Straight Stair it weaves back and forth along the cliffside, a great chasm yawning to one side. At the top of the stairs, a dark cleft leads onward to the entrance of Torech Ungol and the horrors within.
Mablung has established the small camp of Echad Taerdim at the top of the Straight Stair, and he intends to use it as a base from which to mount small expeditions into nearby Cirith Ungol.

Quests of Minas Morgul
Complete quests in Minas Morgul.
The Circle of Wrath is home to several warring Orc-factions, and by your efforts they have been dealt a serious blow.

The name may be of recent invention, for the Circle of Madness has become infested with merrevail sent by Lhaereth, Lady of Blight, and her madness is known to ally and foe alike. She commanded them with a single-minded purpose, and you stood against her minions with equal determination. In time, this tier of the city may reacquire its original appellation: Circle of Wisdom.

The Circle of Sorrow has not welcomed the living for many years and has become home only to the Dead. Through your efforts, you have brought the warmth of life back to this tier of the city. Such warmth will not stay, but you have wielded it as a weapon against the spirits of this place, a warning that the city belongs no longer to them.

It was the command of King Elessar that every tier of the city be cleansed of evil, and Faramir wished to see it done, but the continued presence of Gothmog's servants in the Circle of Despair proved especially troubling for the Prince of Ithilien. 'Once this was the Circle of Mirth,' he mused, 'but today the only laughter to be heard on this level is cruel and full of mockery. Will it ever be quieted? I cannot say.'

Many are the mysteries confronting Prince Faramir and his Rangers on the Circle of Death, uppermost tier of Minas Morgul. Still they stand against the forces of evil that seek to preserve the vile secrets of the Dead City.
Complete many quests in the reclamation of Minas Ithil.

For every difficult task you accomplished, servants of the Enemy sought to oppose it. But they were unable to succeed in these attempts, for always did you dare one more foray into Imlad Morgul, one more incursion to the Dead City.

Defeat many Acolytes of Lamentation within Bâr Nírnaeth, the Houses of Lamentation.

Acolytes of Lamentation were selected by their dark masters to serve within Bâr Nírnaeth for the span of their lifetimes, seduced by the promise of continued life beyond the moment of their deaths. But this was in truth unending servitude, and if ever the scales would fall from their eyes they might see the true horrors that awaited them.

Conqueror of the Dead City
Complete the deeds of the Minas Morgul Instances.
Stand firmly against the greatest evils of the Dead City and Imlad Morgul.
Behind the broken houses of Dáru Lagúrz, the kergrim conduct horrid rituals from within Gorthad Nûr, the Deep-barrow.
The Filth-well of Eithel Gwaur is the source of the corruption that has long tainted the flowing waters of the Ithilduin, giving to them a new name: Morgulduin, River of Sorcery.
Within the outer ring of Minas Morgul, Gothmog's and Ugrukhôr's forces are engaged in pitched battle. Encouraged by your own actions, the Harrowing of Morgul has begun!
It is said that the nine Nazgûl would assemble, in those days of battle, to best their greatest adversaries and to strike relentless fear into those who dared face them in combat.
Within Minas Morgul, a great repository of evil knowledge stands: The Halls of Black Lore. To gain the information you seek, you must enter and face Dolguzigir, the Dark Archivist.

Deep in the darkness of Thuringwath lies Bâr Nírnaeth, the Houses of Lamentation. There, within that great fane where the Nazgûl once worshipped and made sacrifice to Sauron, one of the Dark Lord's most mysterious servants prepares Dhak Thrakrut, the Rite of Returning.
High above the Morgul Vale in a cleft in the side of Achathras, Gath Daeroval is home to the Shadow-roost of the fell beasts.

Daughter of Shelob and queen of all Gredbyg, Thossulun the Massive is a formidable foe. You must defeat her to cease the endless tide of insects plaguing your allies.
With the defeat of Thossulun and her daughters, the endless tide of Gredbyg was abated.
Defeat Thossulun the Massive
Remmorchant, the Net of Darkness: Thossulun the Massive -- Tier 2
Daughter of Shelob and queen of all Gredbyg, Thossulun the Massive is a formidable foe. You must defeat her to cease the endless tide of insects plaguing your allies.

Within the deepest darkness of the Remmorchant lies Shelob the Great, the last child of Ungoliant. Known to Lord Celeborn and learned Elves as Ungwetári, it is believed naught but her final defeat can ensure the safety of the peoples of Middle-earth.

Although your victory came at great cost, you have triumphed over Shelob the Great, last child of Ungoliant. Although Ungwetári lives still, maimed and blinded in the depths of the Remmorchant, it is hoped she will never again trouble the peoples of Middle-earth.
Defeat Shelob the Great, Last Child of Ungoliant
Remmorchant, the Net of Darkness: Shelob the Great, Last Child of Ungoliant -- Tier 2

Within the deepest darkness of the Remmorchant lies Shelob the Great, the last child of Ungoliant. Known to Lord Celeborn and learned Elves as Ungwetári, it is believed naught but her final defeat can ensure the safety of the peoples of Middle-earth.
The Gúrzyul known as Rûkhor the Pale Herald stands poised to unleash Shelob's wrath upon the world. You must prevent his wicked plot from unfolding before it is too late.
Rûkhor's parting words were gloats that he had still triumphed despite his death. You must defeat Shelob herself and prove him wrong.
Defeat Rûkhor the Pale Herald

The Queensbrood, the horrific daughters of Shelob, lurk within the tunnels of the Remmorchant.
Gragarag of the Queensbrood, though she excelled at dexterously weaving webs to capture her prey, was unable to best you.
Guruthang, the Queensbrood of stealth and darkness, was unable to hide from your might.
Gamnagol of the Queensbrood attempted to overpower you with sheer size and strength, but was ultimately defeated by your ability to work together.

Prince Durin calls for Dwarrowmoot, where the fate of Gundabad will be decided. And yet even the most considered plans cannot stand against the might of a dragon unchained, and Hrímil Frost-heart leads her own armies against the dwarves before they are fully prepared. With an unexpected ally at your side, you climb the peak to face a most ferocious foe: the Lord of Gundabad herself, with the fate of Gundabad and of the dwarves hanging by a thread.
With Gundabad retaken, the prince gazes into the future, and conquests still to come...
Complete 'The Legacy of Durin, Epilogue'
Complete 'The Legacy of Durin, Chapter 1'
The Legacy of Durin and the Trials of the Dwarves
Experience the story of 'The Legacy of Durin and the Trials of the Dwarves.'

As the dwarves press on into Gundabad every member of the Gabil'akkâ is called upon to fight, but not everyone is well-suited to the task. Eskil Bloodthumb, apprentice of sculptor Stáli the Hewer, is one such dwarf, and when he runs into trouble in the depths of the Deepscrave he needs your help to escape not only the clutches of the Orcs, but his apprenticeship to Stáli as well.

Mysteries abound as you explore the further reaches of Gundabad, encountering strange enchantments in both the Pit of Stonejaws and the snowy heights of Câr Bronach. You and your allies bravely stand against the plots of both hobgoblin warriors and Angmarim cultists, but a strange and threatening power blankets the Mountain-home, and both its source and purpose remain hidden from you.

The Gabil'akkâ suffers a heartbreaking defeat as Gorgar attacks the primary foothold of the dwarves in Gundabad, but the deaths at his command are not the only weapon he wields against the Longbeard prince. He wields a mighty hammer made of mithril, and with it he strikes a crushing blow against the dwarves. 'Are you the same as I am?' he asks Durin before departing, and although the prince shrugs off the question, it still troubles him.
Durin asks you to venture further into Gundabad with dual missions: to avenge those lost at Gorgar's hands, and to stymie the efforts of the Angmarim as they delve into places held sacred by the dwarves.

The Gabil'akkâ captures a goblin named Glúrkub who served high in Gorgar's counsels before the onset of the War of Three Peaks. The words he speaks in captivity shake the very foundation of Prince Durin's belief in himself and his cause, but there is hope as well. If Glúrkub can be believed, Gorgar meets with Hrímil Frost-heart at a high place above the Welkin-lofts, and when he does he leaves the mithril hammer behind. Durin seizes upon this possibility, but he remains full of anger and distrust.
Deep below Gundabad, secrets are revealed that shake Prince Durin's resolve, but with your help he masters his feelings and comes to terms with the complicated legacy of his forebears.

Prince Durin marshals his troops for battle, and the War of Three Peaks begins! The fighting ebbs and flows as the Orcs mount a ferocious defence, but early successes on the part of the Gabil'akkâ are not enough to secure outright victory. Tensions flare between the various dwarf-clans, despite their common enemy, and arguments between Longbeard, Zhélruka, and Stout-axe threaten to undermine the war effort. At last Durin marches for the gates of Gundabad to face Gorgar in combat, but just as victory seems assured a terrible roar sounds from the heights: Hrímil Frost-heart has broken free of her icy prison behind the Anvil of Winterstith, and she claims lordship of Gundabad. Durin sounds the retreat, but he vows not to relinquish the Mountain-home to this new intruder, or any other.
The next chapter will begin with Prince Durin, located either in Zarkul-sulûn during the War of Three Peaks or in Annâk-khurfu in Elderslade.

Worrisome rumours that Gorgar the Ruthless, son of Bolg and brother of Mazog, has named himself 'Lord of Gundabad' compels Glóin to send a warning to Prince Durin Stonehelmson. The warning is appreciated but not heeded: nothing will stop Durin's assault upon Gundabad. He calls for armies of dwarves to descend upon the Elderslade in preparation for the upcoming conflict, including survivors of the Iron Garrison. These brave dwarves intend to secure the victory that eluded them in Moria, but not all of them are confident it will be possible.

Durin and Ingór, princes of the Longbeards and of the Zhélruka, command their combined forces to break through the ice with which Hrímil Frost-heart sealed the gates of Gundabad. Once beyond, the Gabil'akkâ begins its effort to seize control of the mighty court of Máttugard.

Durin has called for your help at the fortress of Skarháld in the Grey Mountains, where he seeks to unite the dwarf-clans there assembled: Stout-axes, Zhélruka, and Longbeards. Fearing that his own people will be outnumbered by the other clans, he sends for reinforcements from the Lonely Mountain; his father King Thorin Stonehelm responds by directing a large army of Longbeards, many of them veterans of the distant Great Orc War and the more-recent Battle of Five Armies to join his son. Tensions run high, but they do not prevent Durin from setting his sights upon a valuable and hard-to-win prize: Gundabad, sacred Mountain-home, currently held by Orcs.

In advance of Durin's stated purpose to seize Gundabad, the son of King Thorin Stonehelm sent scouts into the Wells of Langflood. They return with news of an Orkish raiding-party dispatched from the fortress, and Durin sends you to counter it before it can slay the inhabitants of the Wells, or hinder the plans for his army's assault upon the Mountain-home. You dispatch the raiding-party, but before its leader dies he speaks of Gorgar the Ruthless, new Lord of Gundabad, son of Bolg and brother to Mazog, who troubled the dwarves greatly in their attempt to retake Moria.

'Taurogrim? Wood-trolls? Whatever you call them, they fear the axe and they fear the fire, and that is enough for me. But I would not recommend using them for kindling. They burn with a vile, choking smoke, and it fills the lungs with poison.' - Runerik Knotbeard

'They are larger and more evil than wolves. Aye, it is true. You need not be a scholar of Rohan to know the hatred of the wargs for us, or that of my people for them.' - Léothred of Rohan

Dwarves once combed the Wells of Langflood for mining opportunities, but the markers they left behind remain the only record of what they found. Whether these markers indicate promising new veins or once-hopeful mines now shuttered is unknown to you.

Explore Reikfoss of Greylin
Explore the Twainmantle
Natural Formations in the Wells of Langflood

The Floodfells are riddled with caves, but the Beornings who live in this area prefer not to explore their dark, narrow depths. Vile insects, pestilential bats, and burrowers with sharp teeth make their homes in these places, and the folk of Limlók only wish to concern themselves with these unpleasant creatures if they emerge into the sunlight or moonlight.
Explore the various natural curiosities to be found within the Wells of Langflood.
Explore the several natural curiosities to be found within the Wells of Langflood.

The rocky slopes of Veithhól serve as a den for the hunting-cats that stalk Misthallow. What few travellers find themselves in this area report the sound of soft, padding feet somewhere in the fog. The natural consequence of these reports seems obvious to the wiser among us: the cats must not have been hungry, or these reports would not exist.

The rocky pass of the Cabed Rhimdath serves as a path for those of the holbytlan who dare to venture from the safety of their home in Lyndelby. For those few who have travelled into the Cabed Rhimdath, they have reported thick brambles and strange painted stones before turning around at the site of leering Eagles.

The narrow clefts of Scraper's Clough have been expanded by the tireless work of the cave-claws that live here, an industrious effort that is halted only when it is time for the creatures to feed. This they do on the hapless beasts that stumble into the Clough, and on adventurers who do the same. These latter meals tend to underestimate the creatures as \qmere cave-claws,\q a misjudgment the inhabitants of Scraper's Clough are only too pleased to encourage.

The great cascade of Reikfoss marks the location where the River Greylin flows out of the Elderslade into Misthallow to form one of the falls of the Three Sisters. Together, the vapours that rise from the base of Reikfoss and those of the Twainmantle blanket all of Misthallow in fog.

The two waterfalls of the Twainmantle are formed at the passage of the Langwell and a smaller stream out of Elderslade into Misthallow. Together with the Reikfoss, these three falls make up the Three Sisters, the combined vapour that rises from their bases enshrouding all of Misthallow in fog.

The question of these times, of great interest for Runerik Knotbeard and his people, not to mention the other folk who walk along the Wells of Langflood: are the Orcs and goblins who threaten these lands driven by the same hatreds and desires that have motivated them for hundreds of years, or is there a greater purpose that guides them to evil? It is a question that must be resolved, for it could mean the survival of those who live along the Langflood.

Settlements in the Wells of Langflood

After the death of their chieftain Bolg during the Battle of Five Armies, the Orcs of the Misty Mountains declined. This reduction in their numbers and their power would not last forever, but during this time the folk of Beorn were able to reassert their presence in the Floodfells, roaming the wilds more openly. In the Floodfells they built the village of Limlók, and it would be the most northern town of Beorn's folk.
Like the overgrown bushes and tangled roots in the low-lands, the Bear-folk are at their wildest in the Floodfells. Today the town's thane is Runerik Knotbeard, and he is distrustful of outsiders, believing his own people possess strength enough to turn away any chance raiding-parties from Gundabad or elsewhere.
Explore the various settlements to be found within the Wells of Langflood.
Explore the various settlements to be found within the Wells of Langflood.

Perhaps in years to come, when the history of the Éothéod has been expanded upon by Léothred's journey and his scholarly pursuits, the name Hlithseld will be held in high esteem. \qThis is where he camped on his journey for knowledge!\q folk may say... or they may not. It is not always easy to know what will be remembered.

The greatest threat posed by the wood-trolls of Grazadh-gropor is one of surprise, for the forested region that is their home creaks and sways with every breeze that troubles the settled fog. The sound of these tree-ish complaints serves to hide the approach of the wood-trolls until they are very near their victim, and then it is too late.

The Beornings of the Floodfells do not know if the wood-trolls of Shulgmokh are related to the Taurogrim of other lands, and do not much care. They are much more interested in how long it takes to tear out their vital heartwood, stopping their movements and the danger these creatures pose to Limlók.

The wargs of Ujâk-fulug would prefer to attack the weak and cowardly, but there are few enough of those in the Floodfells to begin with, for that land is hard and those who do live there are made tougher and stronger. The wargs content themselves with feasting upon beasts of the wild and goats who stray too far from their protectors, but these kills only sharpen their appetite for more challenging, filling meats.

This rustic hamlet of smials is nestled among steep cliffs, hidden until today from the eyes of the Wise and protected from discovery by the Eagle guardians who dwell atop the high peaks. Can this have been the last dwelling-place of the holbytlan who once thrived in Misthallow and the Floodfells, and who often appeared in the folklore of the Éothéod? If so, it would be home to the descendants of those Fallohides who did not cross the Misty Mountains on their eventual road to what would become the Shire.

Thokvist has been Skarding Wolfsbane's home for many years, but the small yard is often untended; the Beorning spends most of his time hunting for hostile dangers among the foggy vales of Misthallow. When he does return home it is only for a short time, perhaps to enjoy one of the apples that grows on the trees outside his home and to rest briefly before setting out again.

Dúnabrygg crosses the river, allowing passage between Misthallow and the Floodfells. The stonework of the bridge has crumbled, but enterprising dwarves repaired the span with sturdy wooden construction.
Ruins in the Wells of Langflood
Find Dúnabrygg

The history of Sundergrót is shrouded in mystery, for it has been long-abandoned. Longbeard tradition holds that this great cleft overlooking the Floodfells was made by the impact of Durin's axe sometime during the First Age.
Today the ruins are haunted by goblins, but they know nothing of the ancient events that there took place. For the goblins it holds only the memory of dwarf-work, and that is a sharp dagger-point of hatred to them, though they covet the treasures and gems their foes unearth.
Explore the various ruins that dot the hills and valleys throughout the Wells of Langflood.
Explore the various ruined structures to be found within the Wells of Langflood.
Whoever Hengi may have been, and the knowledge of why this broken dwarf-bridge bears his name, has been lost to time.

The dwarf-bridge of Skerabrygg once permitted passage across the Langflood for those seeking to explore Sundergrót, but today the bridge is destroyed. Someone has hastily-repaired the span with planks of wood, but it seems a temporary solution. The weather and rain of the Floodfells will doubtless cast this path into the river before many days pass.
The goblins of Stramvárth root among the ruins of Sundergrót in search of treasure, fighting among themselves for the right to hold the most precious pieces.

The goblins and Orc-kind of Egvárth quarreled with their kindred to the east for the right to camp nearer to Sundergrót. It is a decision they may come to regret if more than treasures can be found in the depths of that cleft.

The great keep of the Ai-thúda was called Fasthálla, and it was the seat of their chief Frumgar. When it was burned and destroyed by Scatha the Worm, and Frumgar gravely wounded, his young son Fram swore vengeance upon the great wingless dragon. Eventually it was done, and Fram became Fram Wormsbane. The Ai-thúda rebuilt Fasthálla and gave it a new name: Framsburg.
From its location high atop a rocky spur in Misthallow, Framsburg could not be easily-conquered by Orcs, though they tested its defences and the resolve of its inhabitants from time to time. After the departure of the Éothéod, Framsburg gradually fell into ruin through neglect. It was never sacked, but in time it stood empty and Orcs prowled the ruin.
Today, worms and drakes have built nests among the skeletons of ancient buildings, and Framsburg is theirs. In this way perhaps Scatha has at last achieved his revenge upon Fram Wormsbane and the memory of his people.

The hill-trolls and their unpleasant allies have erected a barricade at Lumrog, watching passage along the road and allowing none to pass. Whether this obstruction is motivated by selfish gain or has been mandated by more cunning powers with greater designs is unknown.

At some time during the residency of the Éothéod in these lands, they carved the White Mare into a hillside in the Floodfells. Whether its distinctive shape was intended to represent the mearas they found grazing on the strip of land between the Twainmantles and the Reikfoss is not known, but seems likely. The White Mare is today faded and somewhat overgrown, but it remains a reminder of the Éothéod's love of horses.

Goblin Bounties of the Langflood
Many particularly troublesome goblins still lurk in the Wells of Langflood.

Among the most curious of the pursuits of the goblin called Earth-splitter was his fascination with the gems buried in the mountain-stones. This by itself was not unusual, for indeed most of goblin-kind coveted such shiny treasures, but Earth-splitter desired to find such gems for the purpose of eating them. Thanks to your efforts, Earth-splitter has eaten his last meal, and will no longer trouble the mines of dwarves. Others might well applaud you for this as well, for his literal appetite for gems was considered distasteful by others of his kind.

The Gangly Slicer made his home among the cave-claws of Scraper's Clough. It was an uneasy alliance, and did not happen overnight; it took one horn-gouged goblin and several sliced cave-claws before these opponents learned to live in peace. Once they did, they each united in their hatred of those foolish enough to brave the Clough. That the Gangly Slicer was once one of these was left unspoken among the cave-claws, or so we must assume.

'Goblins do not like to come aboveground unless they must, so I do not know if this Forest-stalker is real. If he is, he may be desperate, and that will make him more dangerous. But perhaps you are more dangerous than he?' - Runerik Knotbeard

'Bear-cleaver? It is just a name. I do not believe this goblin has slain a single one of my people, or any of the bears that live in the Wells. Not by himself, at any rate! I will slay him myself for taking such a name, if you do not get to him first.' - Runerik Knotbeard

'You can hear Drudge-stomper coming from very far away, for he has unusually heavy footfalls for a goblin. It makes avoiding him quite easy, which is for the best, for I hear he is quite deadly with his weapon.' - Yrsa Spearwife
'Pine not for Pine-cleaver.' - Anonymous
'What does his name mean? What do you think it means? It means he cooks his meals in the skulls of his enemies! I'd have thought that was obvious.' - Yrsa Spearwife

The goblin called Blood-spiller has done his share of that during the weeks he has stalked the Wells of Langflood. Thanks to your efforts, not a drop more will he spill, and the lands along the river will be made safer.

The Wound-skewer is no more. This goblin preferred to leave his victims alive but bleeding, and delighted to follow them from a safe distance until they finally succumbed to other predators in the wild. Thanks to your efforts, this distasteful practice is now ended, as is the Wound-skewer himself.

None know what so-infuriated the Angry Chaser, and that makes the sound of him approaching all the more frightening. Thanks to your efforts, his anger and his chasing have both been quelled, and the folk in the Wells need fear his approach no longer.

'There are no bees in the dark places of the world, for they desire the sweet taste of nectar, and sunlight, and warm breezes, and those can only be found aboveground. But they are not the only creature with a sting, and if you are not careful, some among the goblins may have a deadlier sting than any you have felt before.' - Yrsa Spearwife

'He will smell you out well before you know he tracks you, and with knives and daggers he has skill unparalleled. The Tracking Dagger has slain none of my folk, but he has given a fright to more than one, and it is only their keen senses that have spared them.' - Yrsa Spearwife

Goblins prefer to remain underground, wrapped in the safety of their darkness, but when need drives them to hunt in daylight they are emboldened and made more dangerous. So it was with Marsh-reaver, who stalked the fens and forests of the Wells of Langflood. Harried by the Great Eagles who watched the hidden pass to Lyndelby, Marsh-reaver never found his way to the home of the holbytlan. Thanks to your efforts, now he never will.

Raging Mauler was a goblin of few words, and those he did speak consisted entirely of threats and insults. More than a few of his kind suffered injuries at his hands, for his was a careless ire. His short tale is now ended, thanks to your efforts, and none even among the goblins will mourn his passing.

Crag-slaver was the brother of the goblin called Blade-slaver, and while folk spoke in hushed tones of his infamous sibling, Crag-slaver rarely merited a mention. He will no longer threaten the folk of the Wells from the blanket of anonymity that enveloped him.
'I wonder what ever became of Blade-slaver?' curious children will ask. 'He was an only child,' the bards will reply. 'Let us be glad he had no siblings!'

Blade-slaver, one of the goblins that haunted the Wells of Langflood, is no more. Among goblins he had a reputation for cruelty matched only by his brother Crag-slaver. Thanks to your efforts he will no longer add to that fell reputation.

The Death-spear moved in darkness, but slowly. He preferred to remain immobile, hiding in pools of shadow deep within the caves that were his favourite haunts. Thanks to your efforts, he will no longer leap out upon unsuspecting victims.

'The goblin called Shadow-ripper is so stealthy he lives among the great cats of Veithhól, and they do not know they share their den with one such as he! It's true! Why, if he were to die there, I think he could go unnoticed by them even in death!' - Trygvar, son of Runerik
'The secret to escaping the Beast Master is to show no fear. Only then might you escape. The secret to killing him? Ah, I know of no such secret. Have you learned of such a way?' - Runerik Knotbeard

The Goblins of the Wells rely upon the weak and unsuspecting for their meals, but there is fewer such prey with each passing day. The goblin called Bone-chewer took his name for his ability to make one such kill last for as much as a week, and he was revered by others of his kind for his ability to ration such a meal for so long. Now that he is slain, one wonders if his own bones will be used to flavour a long-lasting soup for the others of his kind, and what he would think of such a happenstance?
Many particularly troublesome goblins still lurk in the Wells of Langflood.

Defeat many beasts throughout the Wells of Langflood
Wells of Langflood Beast-slayer (Advanced)
Defeat many beasts throughout the Wells of Langflood.
Defeat many beasts in the Wells of Langflood.
You have proven yourself an excellent hunter of the beasts that stalk the Wells of Langflood.
Defeat goblins and Orcs in the Wells of Langflood
Wells of Langflood Goblin and Orc-slayer (Advanced)
Defeat many goblins and Orcs in the Wells of Langflood.
Defeat many Orcs and goblins in the Wells of Langflood.

The question of these times, of great interest for Runerik Knotbeard and his people, not to mention the other folk who walk along the Wells of Langflood: are the Orcs and goblins who threaten these lands driven by the same hatreds and desires that have motivated them for hundreds of years, or is there a greater purpose that guides them to evil? It is a question that must be resolved, for it could mean the survival of those who live along the Langflood.
Defeat Trolls and Hobgoblins in the Wells of Langflood
Wells of Langflood Troll and Hobgoblin-slayer (Advanced)
Defeat many Trolls and Hobgoblins in the Wells of Langflood.
Defeat many Trolls and Hobgoblins in the Wells of Langflood.

'Trolls? Hobgoblins? I fear them not. Do not tell me you run from such creatures as this! Good. For a moment there it is true, I was afraid; afraid I was in the presence of a coward!' - Runerik Knotbeard
Defeat many wargs in the Wells of Langflood
Wells of Langflood Warg-slayer (Advanced)
Defeat many wargs in the Wells of Langflood.
Defeat many wargs in the Wells of Langflood.
'They are larger and more evil than wolves. Aye, it is true. You need not be a scholar of Rohan to know the hatred of the wargs for us, or that of my people for them.' - Léothred of Rohan
Defeat many Wood-trolls in the Wells of Langflood
Wells of Langflood Wood-troll Slayer (Advanced)
Defeat many Wood-trolls in the Wells of Langflood.
Defeat many Wood-trolls in the Wells of Langflood.

'Taurogrim? Wood-trolls? Whatever you call them, they fear the axe and they fear the fire, and that is enough for me. But I would not recommend using them for kindling. They burn with a vile, choking smoke, and it fills the lungs with poison.' - Runerik Knotbeard

Folk from lands both near and distant celebrate the marriage of King Aragorn II Elessar and Queen Arwen Undómiel, a union that promises to usher in a new era of peace for Gondor and all of Middle-earth. And yet Mithrandir urges you not to relax your guard, for such peace must be protected if the dream of it is to arrive.

After the fall of the realm of Grárik, dragon-kind spread across Ered Mithrin to the western reaches of Mount Gundabad. Although their numbers are fewer in the Third Age, their presence in Elderslade poses a constant threat to any who would dare to brave the North.

After the fall of the realm of Grárik, dragon-kind spread across Ered Mithrin to the western reaches of Mount Gundabad. Although their numbers are fewer in the Third Age, their presence in Elderslade poses a constant threat to any who would dare to brave the North.
Discover Shakal-atrâd
Discover Zudramdân
Discover Grálinvarth
Discover the Hárveg Bridge
Discover Annâk-khurfu
Discover Zarkul-sulûn

Despite the many long years it has endured, Annâk-khurfu continues to stand tall. The dwarves have rallied to these ruins and called their allies to arms, preparing for the inevitable.
Annâk-khurfu offers an advantageous view of the main roads leading into Elderslade -- from Ered Mithrin to the east, and Misthallow to the south -- where friend and foe can be spotted plainly.

The years have not been kind to Zarkul-sulûn, which now plays host to all manner of evil: Orcs, hobgoblins, wargs, and perhaps others.
The ruins sit too closely to Annâk-khurfu for the dwarves' comfort. They keep a wary eye on Zarkul-sulûn, understanding that it will be the first of many obstacles they must cross if they wish to retake Gundabad.
The forces of Gundabad have long held Shakal-atrâd within their grasp. Though all appears quiet outside these foreboding ruins, delving deeper may reveal otherwise....
Zudramdân may not be as formidable as Annâk-khurfu, but the dwarves' northern camp allows them some modicum of safety in the long fight to retake their home.

The rushing waterfalls of the Greylin River drown out even the loudest of sounds at Grálinvarth. From this vantage point, one can easily spot the Rushgate and Annâk-khurfu, as well as glimpse the valley of Misthallow on a clear day.

Crude constructions deface the Gates of Gundabad, a mocking reminder of the dwarves' losses and defeats. One might wonder what else the Orcs have done to further corrupt the former dwarf-kingdom past this foreboding threshold.

Perched above the Greylin River, the Hárveg Bridge had been, until recently, broken and impassable. The dwarves have skilfully mended the bridge, opening safe passage to and from Misthallow once more.
Dwarf-ruins of Elderslade
Discover the Gates of Gundabad
Explore the ruins left behind by dwarves in Elderslade.
Explore the dwarf-ruins scattered across Elderslade.
Discover Zudramdân
Discover Caivád Sâr
Discover Drenghól
Discover Shakal-atrâd
Discover Zarkul-sulûn
Discover Howlers' Notch

Following the defeat of the Angmarim ritualists who had resided within, Shakal-atrâd once again belongs to the dwarves. Reclaiming the ruins was a step forward -- a small step, perhaps, but a step forward nevertheless.

Where once the haunting howling of Wargs filled the air around Howlers' Notch, now only the guttural growling of hill-beasts can be heard. The former Warg den houses vicious hill-beasts, manipulated and bred for war by hobgoblin beast-tamers. Cages and chains imprison the wild hill-beasts that have been captured against their will.
Orkish forces overwhelmed the dwarves at Zudramdân and claimed the ruins as their own. Now Zudramdân is a shell of its former self, its interior set ablaze and crawling with Orcs.

Caivád Sâr remains a stronghold for the evil forces of Elderslade. Undeterred -- and perhaps fuelled -- by the raging war outside, the Angmarim continue to torture and experiment within its ghastly chambers.

Despite being entrenched deep within enemy territory, Drenghól has remained hidden from prying enemy eyes. Its position within Elderslade has proved useful, as it offers a clear view of Gundabad's outer walls.

At the front lines, the Gabil'akkâ vanguard stands their ground, planting themselves firmly into the trenches. An endless stream of orders enter and leave Ifbar-athrâkh, the command center the dwarves have dug nearby. While others must think about the larger picture of the war, those in Ifbar-athrâkh concern themselves with the details of taking and controlling Orc territory.

The Orcs have dug out winding tunnels in the shadow of Zudramdân, further defiling the dwarf-ruin. From these tunnels, they create plans to thwart the Gabil'akkâ vanguard and bolster their own defences.

Seated in the northern reaches of Elderslade, Bagûd-mekhem stretches out from Gundabad and peers down into the valley. At this elevation, the cold winds carry an unnatural chill. Combined with the swarms of battle-ready Orcs, Bagûd-mekhem is a daunting sight to behold.

Hardy fortifications have replaced the Orkish barriers that previously guarded Zarkul-sulûn, keeping the dwarves' enemies at bay. It is from here that the dwarves formulate new strategies with which to defeat their foes, and perhaps dare to dream about reclaiming Gundabad at long last.

The War of Three Peaks has transformed a once-grassy plain of Elderslade into Azgh-buzru, the War-fell. Like Azanulbizar of old, this is to be the site of the bloodiest skirmishes between the dwarves of the Gabil'akkâ and the Orcs of Gundabad.

Defeat many trolls in Elderslade.

Trolls were among the many foul creatures that fled to Elderslade following Morgoth's demise. During the Second Age, a vengeful Lord Brúni led a campaign against the trolls, earning himself the title of Trollbane. The dwarves slaughtered the trolls of the region and drove the survivors into the Ettenmoors. Despite this, trolls have returned to Elderslade and now endanger efforts to retake Gundabad.

Discover Bagûd-mekhem
Discover Dûn Traikh
Discover Caivád Sâr
Explore the enemy encampments found across Elderslade.

The rocky outcrops and hidden caves of the hills of Elderslade make for a perfect location for Warg dens. The ground is littered with bones and the weapons of those who tried and failed against the beasts.
A foul odour permeates the air, and the rumble of low growls can be heard in the distance.

Squatting amidst sun-bleached bones of ancient worms, Malkorlash grants the hobgoblins control of both the nearby river and roads. The encampment also serves to hamper passage through the hills to the Wyrmsgráf River on the eastern side. The hobgoblin and dragon-kin filled passage is from whence Malkorlash, \qmountain gap,\q gains its name.
Discover Howlers' Notch
Discover Malkorlash
Enemy Encampments of Elderslade
Explore the enemy encampments found across Elderslade.

Skulking in the shadows of Gundabad's great walls, Hanksar-mokh is a vile nest of Orcs. About the bone piles and hide tents, ancient dwarf-made structures lie in ruins, giving a hint of former glory. Rough scaffolding affords the goblin-kind the ability to swarm up and down the walls without having to use Gundabad's huge staircases.

The air about Bagûd-mekhem is unnaturally cold, with whipping winds cutting through all but the thickest furs and leathers. Ramshackle scaffolding and rough high walls have been erected about the northern walls of Gundabad. Orcs, goblins, and things even more feared swarm between walls of wood and stone.

Dûn Traikh bears testament to how far the Angmarim have pushed into Elderslade, and for how long they have enjoyed free reign in the lands of the dwarves. Though their realm has fallen, there are those within the walls of Dûn Traikh who strive to bring back the kingdom the Witch King of Angmar once begot.

Dark and looming, the spire of Caivád Sâr is where the Angmarim come to engage in ritual, arcane arts, and torture. Caivád Sâr provides a line of defence along the eastern road, housing numerous deadly forces. Its tower thrusts up to the heavens, a grasping claw from which enemies can be spotted miles away.

Skulking in the shadows of Gundabad’s great walls and twin to Hanksar-mokh, Kulûg-mokh too is a vile nest of Orcs. About the bone piles and hide tents, ancient dwarf-made structures lie in ruins, giving a hint of former glory. Rough scaffolding affords the goblin-kind the ability to swarm up and down the walls without having to use Gundabad's huge staircases.

Towards the end of summer, the seed pods of the yellow-rattle turn to paper thin, dry husks. The sound made when the wind blows and rattles the seed within is how this lively plant got its name.

Sought after by clothiers, the spines of the teasel can be used to raise a fuzzy nap on fabrics, especially wool. Water that collects in small cups which form around the stem is said to reverse signs of aging when applied to one's skin.
Leathery, dark green leaves and bright yellow flowers make wood spurge a lovely ground cover. When cut, however, the plant bleeds a milky white liquid that may cause pain and irritation of the skin.

A versatile plant that has both medicinal and culinary uses, Shepherd's Purse is often mistaken for a weed. Though its healing properties span numerous ailments, Shepherd's Purse is also thought to be beneficial in addressing a great number of blood-related issues.
Legends say that someone wearing this scraggly pink flower on their lapel will soon find love. They are more likely to be swarmed by butterflies, who have a deep fondness for ragged robin.

This lovely little plant is said to be able to do everything from spreading cheer to curing ailments of the eyes. Some whisper that a tonic of eyebright dripped into the eye before bed will grant the sleeper prophetic dreams.
Small and delicate, speedwell makes a fine tea, but does not make one move more quickly, as rumours often suggest. It may benefit one who suffers from leprosy or gout, however.

Often looked upon with grimaces or trod underfoot, behind the needle-like bristles, the stem of the knotted thistle can be boiled down and used in pie like rhubarb. The flowers, however, have a history of being used to curdle milk by jealous neighbours.

This ancient Arnorian ruin once stood as a sentinel, keeping watch over the Brandywine River. These days, the crumbling walls play host to dark forces who use Overwine Hall as a base from which to set forth to ravage and raid the Wildwood.
The tall and thin tower of Norwarden is now home to those for whom it was built to guard against. The years have not been kind to the watch-tower's old stonework, nor have its newer residents.
Carved from the very bedrock of the mountain itself, Sutwarden was once a majestic Arnorian watch-tower. It has since fallen to ruin, and is further defiled by its current occupants.

The small village of Cotfast was originally built by the Free Peoples. The villagers were forced to abandon it due to a bad harvest and the growing threats and dangers of the Wildwood. Now it is home to brigands and Orcs alike.

The twisting tunnels of Writhenset were carved into the hills long ago, by unknown miners. Left abandoned for centuries, the mines have become a contested battleground among those who seek their wealth and secrets.
Sun bleached bones and rusted swords litter the hillside of Gnawbone Pit. The Wargs who den among the rocks have grown strong and fierce on the bounty of the Wildwood.

High above the rapids and rushing water of the Netherwell, a makeshift bridge sways in the wind. Marl the Rockscrambler was the first man in known history to have scaled the walls of the Cirith Núr chasm. Sadly, whatever beast was lying in wait on the side of the Wildwood made short work of the adventurer.

Blomley Sward is a beautiful meadow, carpeted with thick green grass and countless white flowers. It would be the perfect place for a hobbit's picnic, were it not for the beasts that prowl the hillside and nearby woods.
Sites of the Wildwood
Explore Overwine Hall
Explore Norwarden
Explore Sutwarden
Explore Cotfast
Explore Gnawbone Pit

Trader's Wharf is the home base of the League of the Axe and one of the few access points into the Wildwood. Merchants, hunters, miners, and others pass through this small port on their way to and from gathering resources in the forests.
Explore the many interesting locations to be found within the Wildwood.
Explore the many interesting locations to be found within the Wildwood.
Wooden supports and scaffolding line the walls of the western entrance to Writhenset mines. The pit has been carved out of the mountain over unknown generations, but the mines go deeper still.

In the days before Cotfast was overrun, one of the village's children wandered away from her parents. Helva was found a day later, her back to this cliff, with wolves closing in. A brilliant, snow-white stag stood tall before her, keeping the wolves at bay. The arrival of the villagers meant the wolves were outnumbered, and they dispersed. The stag gently touched his nose to the top of the child's head before vanishing over the ledge.

Nature has reclaimed the ruined walls and shattered dome of this ancient gazebo. The view from the bluff encompasses much of the Wildwood, but the Old Bluff-house does not seem to have been a watch-tower. Instead, the structure harkens back to a time where building for beauty's sake was possible.

This rocky prominence above the central Wildwood grants an unobstructed view of the surrounding valley. Given the dangerous beasts that frequent this area, it is unclear who is the hunter and who is the prey.
Huge wooden beams line the rock walls leading to the eastern entrance of the Writhenset mines.

Hidden Threats of the Wildwood
Strong beasts and foes roam the Wildwood.
It takes much for goblins to expel one of their own, but his viciousness and unpredictable bouts of rage made Azdág undesirable among his own kind. He wanders the Wildwood now, plotting his revenge.

Rumours of how Lagshal Bone-cracker got his name abound. Some say his blows can shatter bones through metal armour. Others whisper that Lagshal once dined on the marrow of one of his enemies. Many suggest both are true.

Deep in the bowels of the Writhenset mines, Broghosh weaves innumerable strands of her silvery thread into deadly traps. The darkest tunnels are filled with her skittering brood, who have been know to swarm over their prey like an ocean wave upon the shore.
A master of stealth and cunning, Drúhuk glides across the Wildwood like the smoke his coat resembles.
Along the cliffs of the Brandywine, thunderous footsteps warn of the approach of a ferocious moose. Even the fiercest Warg gives way when the Master of the Wildwood passes by.
Deep within a twisting network of tunnels is a hulking mass of fur, dagger-like claws, and razor sharp teeth. When the Lord of the Stone-den comes to surface, the very Wildwood shivers.
The snow-white fur about Dulglok's muzzle is perpetually stained and caked with bloody gore. Even more terrifying than his bite, however, is the fierce Warg's uncanny guile.

Deep furrows of silver and red scars crisscross the thick hide of a massive boar who stalks the Wildwood. Though they be cracked, snapped, and yellowed with age, beware the tusks of the Grand Old Wild-tusk.

The name of Hull the Wolf-hearted is whispered even amongst the murderers and poachers who call Cotfast their home. He is rarely seen and even more rarely does he speak. It is said that he can glide like a soft breeze within a handbreadth of even the most vigilant of creatures or persons.

Once, a fellow Orc called Thraumak a liar for boasting that he had felled a large tree with a single swing of his axe. Thraumak responded by demonstrating his ability on a nearby tree, which fell directly onto his naysayer's head.
Strong beasts and foes roam the Wildwood.

A hidden entrance called Bagûd-mekhem, the Gate of Wind, lies just east of Gundabad. Zhurmat, with his fearsome mount the horrible two-headed troll Groz-and-Ulk, leads a force that threatens the Gabil'akkâ below.

Not content with ruling Moria, Azog sent forth his servants to defile and conquer the once-pristine lands of Azanulbizar.
'Sullying the waters of Kibil-nâla with their filth, the Orcs had constructed a crude border-fort along the great-way of old, blocking our surest path to the East-gate.'
'Before the gates of Moria, Azog and his Orcs wrought a great battlement. In the shadows of his watch-towers, the skulls of countless dwarves had been set on pikes in mockery of Thráin.'

'When at last we came to Azanulbizar, we found the pass through Baraz blocked by a great Orc-encampment. There would be no reinforcements from the north - at least, none that would meet us as friends and allies.'

Azog's Realm
Not content with ruling Moria, Azog sent forth his servants to defile and conquer the once-pristine lands of Azanulbizar.

'Far above the East-gate on the slopes of Zirakzigil, the Orcs made camp with trolls out of Moria. From those dizzying heights, the trolls hurled countless stones down into the dale, killing Orcs and dwarves alike.'

'In the shadow of Atrad-zarakh on the slopes of Shathûr, the Orcs had built a sprawling watch-post. Nestled among their crude trappings were countless bats, creatures long-favoured by Azog and his sons to use as spies at Azanulbizar.'
'To the north of Khur Azan, we found the old bridge destroyed. In its place, the Orcs had erected a small crossing to guard the pass to Shathûr.'

'In the low-hills of Zirakzigil, I found a great den of wargs. Before Komog, youngest son of Azog, was slain at Gundabad, his wargs had claimed the lives of countless dwarves. At last, vengeance would be ours!'
Countless treasures were pillaged by Azog and the Orcs at Azanulbizar.
'In the midst of the fighting at Azanulbizar, several caches of lost treasure out of Moria were reclaimed from Azog and his vile ilk.'
Learn of the reclamation of lost caches at Azanulbizar

Although Khazad-dûm was abandoned long ago, remnants of its splendour might still be found in Azanulbizar.

'Before the fall of Moria, Amdân was once a thriving trading village that sprung forth beneath the great archway Durin himself had set at the southern border of the realm of Khazad-dûm. It has now become the mustering camp of the Haban’akkâ.'

Remnants of Khazad-dûm
Although Khazad-dûm was abandoned long ago, remnants of its splendour might still be found in Azanulbizar.

'Once a mighty thoroughfare and trading route leading out of Khazad-dûm through Amdân and into the Misty Mountains, the great-way had mostly vanished after the fall of Moria, leaving only stray stone and markers in its wake.'

'In the dark of winter, Labam-gairu, or the Whitcleft in the Common tongue, had all but frozen solid. Cold water still flowed from its eastern falls as it neared the lands of the Elves, but this tale does not speak of their realm.'

'At Khur Azan, the paths to Khazad-dûm and Lórien met. In by-gone times, a stone pavilion was wrought in commemoration of friendship between dwarves and Elves. The pavilion of Khur Azan still stands, but the realm of the Elves now seems cold and distant even beneath its brilliant, golden eaves.'
'Ah, the Silverlode! As brilliant and chilling as ever it had been! Falling from Kheled-zâram, its cool mist soothed the wounds of war.'

'Once the pass to Atrad-zarakh, an avalanche on the slopes of Shathûr left it inaccessible for many years after the fall of Moria. In constructing one of their crude bridges to reach the old pass, it seems the Orcs have unwittingly done us a great favour!'

'With the aid of the Kámbrada, we won a foothold on the slopes of Bundushathûr. The great guard-post of Ashmargathâl was had fallen to the Orcs, but no longer. Alas, the watching-spire beyond would be harder won.'

'It was at Atrad-zarakh, the watching-spire, that the great bells of Khazad-dûm once rang across Azanulbizar. Once sounded in times of celebration, they became a warning-beacon in the latter days of Moria. Alas, now the tower is overrun.'
'Of all the passes among the peaks of Khazad-dûm, the most-travelled in times of old was Tharkh Baraz — the Redhorn Pass. It is my hope that in years to come it might prove safe to walk again.'
'Even the corruption of the Orcs could not dim the beauty of Anlakh-zeleg, the Dimrill Stair! At the foot of Tharkh Baraz, its falls shimmered in sunlight as they cascaded down into Kheled-zâram.'

'In truth, little is known of Tharkh Zigil. Once a pass carved into the slopes of Zirakzigil, it fell into disuse even before the fall of Moria. Perhaps it was once meant to lead to Durin's Tower, but I have not discovered its true purpose.'
'Once an armoury and southern watch-post of Khazad-dûm, Zirakazhâr was overrun by Orcs not long after the fall of Moria. If we are to overcome Azog's forces, it must be reclaimed!'

'Ah, the Mirrormere! There must be some enchantment upon it, for always it reflects the night sky. It was in the waters of Kheled-zâram that Durin the Deathless first glimpsed a crown of stars upon his head, and in his wisdom, he delved the first halls of Khazad-dûm.'

'It has been many years since any dwarf has looked upon Durin'abal. Durin's Stone was set in commemoration of where Durin the Deathless stood when first he gazed into Kheled-zâram. It brings me great comfort to see it, even in the midst of war.'

'After so many years, the facade of Nud-mekhem, the great East-gate, has resisted falling to complete ruin despite the efforts of the Orcs. The gates are defaced with Orkish scrawls, but as with all works of the Orcs and their ilk, it cannot endure!'

In the year 1981 of the Third Age, the Longbeards made their final stand against the Balrog known as 'Durin's Bane'. The brave dwarves that defied the terror on that day would be the saviors of their people, but the fate of their kingdom was certain.

Sites of Máttugard
You have explored Maergrind, The Noble Gate. This is the primary entrance to the great dwarf-city of Gundabad.
Explore the many interesting locations to be found within Máttugard.
Explore the many interesting locations to be found within Máttugard.
You have explored Zidir-nesad, The Steepset. The great court and throne of the Steepset were once the seat of Gundabad’s lord.
You have explored Shalakibal. The waterways of Shalakibal bring fresh waters to Máttugard from underground springs.
You have explored the hall of Vérnozal. The hall of Vérnozal was once a place where the nobles of Gundabad would come to converse and make decisions for the city.
You have explored Asbaj-khîrfin. Once a building of commerce found within the mighty court, it is now a small dwarf-outpost.
You have explored Imrêkh-guthlu. Once a great home of a noble in Máttugard, now the building is a small dwarf-outpost, keeping watch over the entrance to the Deepscrave.

Enemies of Máttugard
You have explored Búshatap. The walkways and stairs were once a place of leisure in Gundabad.
Explore the many enemy locations to be found within Máttugard.
Explore the many enemy locations to be found within Máttugard.
You have explored Sadauk-kala. The high walkways would fill with dwarves when a fallen lord was carried in a grand procession from Máttugard to the Houses of Rest.
You have explored Vâr Nuchur. The high perch of Vâr Nuchur was once a great garden used for feasts at Steepset.
You have explored Brúvraum. These old dwarf work-tunnels once followed the path of the underground waterways of Shalakibal.
You have explored Tholmuzog. Over the many years of Orkish occupation, many have set up encampments within the lower reaches of Máttugard, and away from the light.
You have explored Khorroz. This large cavern, once illuminated by the warm glow of braziers and torches, was a bustling hub for trade with visitors to Gundabad.
You have explored Ronglagam. The old dwarf work-tunnels have collapsed and been dug up once more by the many burrowing creatures in Máttugard.

Complete Chapter 7
Complete Chapter 8
Celeblír has asked you to help him find Bilbo Baggins, who has disappeared from Imladris without a word to anyone! What adventure has the old hobbit embarked upon now?
A search of the grounds of Rivendell turned up nothing but concern for Bilbo from the Elves who reside there.
After a daring escape from the dark, you finally achieved the rescue for which you entered the mountain!
A confrontation with a jailor in the dungeons was only the beginning of your rescue attempt.
A dangerous game of hide and seek revealed a way inside the mountain where you feared Bilbo had gone.
The goblin camp proved a slight hindrance, but you persevered in your quest to recover the missing hobbit.
Your trail led north among wargs and goblins, and at the end of it you made an unfortunate discovery.
Complete Chapter 1
The Further Adventures of Bilbo Baggins

Noted author and adventurer Bilbo Baggins intended to spend the rest of his days in the peace and quiet of Rivendell, home to Lord Elrond and haven of the Elves, but sometimes adventures come calling....
You made your way inside the dangerous mountain, sealing gates as you went in a desperate attempt to slow the attack of your foes, creeping ever closer to the missing hobbit.
An old travelling companion of Bilbo's provided needed insight to the hobbit's activities, but an unnatural storm swept in and hindered your efforts to follow the old adventurer.
A friendly face in Giant Valley lent a hand, but still there was no sign of the old hobbit.
Canaddal and Ringhul agreed to keep their eyes peeled for any sign of the old hobbit, but it is a known fact that hobbits can be difficult to spot when they set their minds to hiding.

As the Sixth War of the Dwarves and Orcs neared its end, each of the Seven Houses gathered beneath the banner of Thráin at Amdân.

'Beneath the banner of the Haban’akkâ, King Thráin dwelt with his two sons, Thorin and Frerin, as well as the dwarf Kalin, who was betrothed to Thráin's daughter, Dís, in the days that preceded the Sixth War of the Dwarves and Orcs.'

'Many others followed from Thrór's Coomb to avenge the dishonour done upon Durin's Folk, chief among them the line of Farin. Though there was no new home to be won in their quest, the Longbeards in exile could not abide the defilement of their kingdom of old.'
Learn of the House of Thráin's encampment at Amdân
Learn of the Exiles' encampment at Amdân
The War-camp of Thráin
As the Sixth War of the Dwarves and Orcs neared its end, each of the Seven Houses gathered beneath the banner of Thráin at Amdân.
'When word of Thrór's death reached the Iron Hills, his brother Grór wept and tore his beard. After a time, he called upon his son, Náin Orcsfoe, to muster the Iron-folk to war.'
'Long allies of Durin's Folk, the Landorrim were swift to answer Thráin's call to war. Led by Agni the Wild, the Landorrim marched from the Blue Mountains to aid in the hunt for Azog.'

'Although old enmities still lingered between Durin's Folk and the Zhélruka, the slaying of the heir of the Eldest of the Houses could not go unanswered. And so, King Vélat led an army of his from Ered Cernin.'

'Once the proud dwarves of Drása's Folk, the destruction of their homeland and culling of their people by the Dark Lord in the Third Age left the Kámbrada greatly diminished. Although the two began the war as bitter enemies, King Usk of the Kámbrada and King Vélat of the Zhélruka gained a mutual respect for each other and bonded through their shared hatred of Azog and the Orcs.'

'Perhaps the wisest of the Seven Houses, King Brítu the Redeful pledged the Temámir to the Haban’akkâ of Thráin. Alas, after a string of devastating losses during the Sixth War of the Dwarves and Orcs, all that remained of the royal line was Jegín, a young princess of the Temámir—now named and so honoured as King by her people.'

'Fervent dwarves and ancient allies of Durin's Folk, the Narfanghoth were the first to pledge themselves to the Haban’akkâ of Thráin. Led by the inimitable Drógar Bloodwhisker, the Narfanghoth swore brutal vengeance upon Azog and all of his kin.'

'Not since before the fall of Khazad-dûm had the Abnúzhu treated with Durin's Folk, but it mattered not when word of Thrór's death reached Ered Cernin. Led by Shâlim Nightcloak, the Abnúzhu travelled west and their friendship with Durin's Folk was renewed, at least for a time.'
