You found a page of 'Martial Movement'
You already know how to move; you have been doing it all your life. Brom had better be able to justify your purchase, or you will show him just how well you can move, to his peril!

Brom spends most of the available space on this page describing a particularly memorable brawl from his younger days. 'You should have seen it,' he writes. 'There were chairs flying through the air, but they were like so many wisps of cloud to us, for nary a one could touch us!'

On this page, Brom discusses a number of different feints you can use to disorient your opponents, including such diversions as the Whoops Not That Way, the Over Here Not There, and the Too Fast For You.

On this page, Brom floats a disturbing hypothetical situation. 'In the event you find yourself engaged in combat with a TBDCLASS who is also familiar with the contents of this book, you may find yourself locked in a perpetual dance of dodging and weaving, with neither combatant able to land a successful blow!'
Brom has no further advice to counter this situation; he apparently just thought it was interesting.

On this page, Brom notes the importance of maintaining complete focus when engaged in the middle of a whirling storm of battle. 'Only a heightened sense of awareness can enable you to side-step whatever projectiles might be coming your way,' he writes.
Toward the bottom of the page he seems to contradict himself. 'Sometimes you might need some luck on your side,' he notes. 'But reading such instructive texts as these is ultimately the most important thing, of course. Thanks for buying my book!'
Demand an explanation from Brom

Martial Movement

The first four pages of this book can be found on enemies scattered across Angmar, Eregion, and Moria. The last four pages of this book can be found on enemies scattered across Forochel, Moria, and the Misty Mountains.
Martial Movement was written by Brom Hawksbeard, a TBDCLASS from Bree-land.

Class Deeds - Tier 1
Complete these three deeds to earn a Class Trait Point.
In dire times, call on hidden reserves of strength and carry on.
Use Ignore Pain
No matter what tricks your opponent may deploy, fight on.
This is your objective description.

On this page, Brom recommends a simple means of improving the accuracy of your kicks: by setting an apple atop a wooden fence-post, closing your eyes, and attempting to strike the apple from its place with your foot.
'If you are able to do this,' Brom writes, 'you can graduate to smaller apples and higher posts.'

On this page, Brom engages in a lengthy detour discussing punches instead of kicks. At the bottom of the page he recommends that you consult another of his books, 'The Art of the Perfect Punch,' for even more melee-related material.
You wonder if that book is full of information about kicks, and who suggested Brom write these books in the first place.

On this page, Brom has drawn a number of diagrams intended to demonstrate the proper form of three powerful kicks. Unfortunately, his artistic skills are rather less than his brawling prowess, and the drawings are impossible to understand.

On this page, Brom details the problems and pitfalls of attempting to strike an opponent with your foot while jumping. 'Unless you are quite fast,' he writes, 'your opponent may be able to grab your leg during the approach, and then where will you be? Leave this manoeuvre to the experts!'

On this page, Brom continues his apparently heart-felt prohibition against jump-kicks. 'Trust me, dear reader,' he writes, 'you do not want to jump at someone with your foot extended, only to have them grab you out of midair. It would be humiliating... I assume.'
You suspect the author of Knowledge of Kicks had a bad experience executing this sort of manoeuvre at some point in his history.

On this page, Brom discusses the importance of kicking with both your left and right legs.
'But not at the same time,' he concludes.

On this page, Brom compares the art of brawling with your feet to the practice of dancing. 'But not like they do it at court,' he continues. 'Brawling with your feet is much nearer the sort of dance you'd find at a country inn... and more fun, too!'

On this page, Brom recommends the purchase of another of his books, Martial Movement. Between the covers of that 'fine investment' he promises to explain a number of manoeuvres that will allow you to dodge the type of kicks you have learned from this tome.
'But don't worry,' he writes, 'for your opponents will not have read it.'

On this page, Brom lists a number of follow-up moves to use against opponents who have been consumed with rage following the successful execution of the 'look at the thrush!' manoeuvre detailed on a previous page. Most of these seem to rely upon beating a hasty retreat.
On this page, Brom goes into great detail on the differences between a 'thump' and a 'wallop.' As terms of art, they leave much to be desired.

On this page, Brom asks the question 'Is the most valuable punch the one you never need to throw?'
His answer: 'no.'

On this page, Brom lists a number of vulnerable spots a skilled TBDCLASS might target with punches in order to debilitate his opponents. Unfortunately, his understanding of anatomy is less than thorough, and most of his advice only applies to humanoid opponents.

On this page, Brom suggests that if you intend to brawl with spiders or other crawling insects, you should purchase another of his books, 'Knowledge of Kicks,' for valuable advice on dealing with such creatures. 'I will not here describe what type of attack you will need,' he writes, 'but it is not a punch of any kind!'
You suspect he may be referring to kicks, but with Brom it is hard to say.

On this page, Brom notes that many TBDCLASSs never master the art of the perfect punch, despite studying from the best trainers Middle-earth has on offer. 'This reflects poorly on the student, and not on the teachers,' he insists.
Express your dissatisfaction to Brom Hawksbeard in Bree Jail

The flowers, trees, and plants of Sant Lhoer have been cultivated and reared to best harness their deadly properties. Some may take days or months for their effects to be felt, while the spores of others may kill between one breath and the next.
You should find the five deadliest plants within the Poison Garden.
Plants of the Poison Gardens

The flowers, trees, and plants of Sant Lhoer have been cultivated and reared to best harness their deadly properties. Some may take days or months for their effects to be felt, while the spores of others may kill between one breath and the next.

The deadly effects of the noxious spores of festerfoul do not make themselves apparent right away. Rather, it may take weeks or months for the victim to suddenly, and most painfully, succumb to its poisonous toxins.
The towering flowers of strickenbloom are enticing, but a single drop of its toxins can cause one to be struck with frozen limbs, unending slumber, and eventually death.

Scythe-sting is known for its deadly spikes which, seemingly with a mind of their own, break off of the stem and burrow under the skin of any unlucky enough to come into contact. At the heart of each spike lies a dormant seed, just waiting for the perfect, moist environment in which to thrive.
The oozing sap of adder's tooth causes huge and painful blisters on any exposed skin unlucky enough to brush against its stem. When burned, smoke from this plant has been known to cause blindness.

The bright, sweetly flavoured berries of wargsbite are a tempting treat. However, even a single bite of the fruit will soon strike one down. Afflictions start with hallucinations and convulsions, and work up to a mouthful of frothing foam which soon chokes out any and all attempts at gasping for breath.

Thaurisgar, the Vile Apothecary -- Tier 3

In the depths of Thaurisgar, countless foul and twisted experiments roam the shadows--the terrible legacy of Aniochán the Harrower. Before the fall of Carn Dûm, Aniochán worked tirelessly to outdo his rivals and win the favour of the Steward of Angmar. Chief among his tools in shaping his fell creations was a curious ichor known only as the Bile of Ifrinn. Thought to be lost after a disastrous experiment claimed Aniochán's life, now this foetid and vile substance is in danger of being let loose into the world.

Thaurisgar Alchemy

The alchemical concoctions of Aniochán the Harrower has resulted in the most foul and twisted of experiments. Working with many ingredients and shrouding them in darkness, he was able to create fell abominations out of his test subjects. From the many experiments came a solvent that would become the catalyst of his most wretched creations, Bile of Ifrinn.
Using what remains of his research, find all the ingredients to make Bile of Ifrinn

In the depths of Thaurisgar, are remnants of Aniochán the Harrower's foul and twisted experiments. Key among the many tools used to shape his creations was the Bile of Ifrinn. A foetid ichor made by mixing the deadliest of ingredients and substances. Each ingredient carrying with it harmful and undesirable effects. It was in these vile and noxious substances that Aniochán the Harrower found the vile results he aspired to achieve.
From the many experiments came a solvent that would become the catalyst of his most wretched creations, Bile of Ifrinn.

The noxious liquid of festersweat, derived from fungus, is deadly on physical contact. This concentration has been fermented with other alchemical solutions for long periods of time to create alternative results from its various properties.

Strickenseep is a highly toxic and deadly sap that is known to cause extreme paralysis and loss of vision. Its uses in alchemy is taboo. Its properties and effects are undesirable. However, when mixed with other substances, Aniochán the Harrower found that its effects and properties could be augmented to avoid the pitfalls of this sap when encountered alone.

Scythespew is an odorous and viscous liquid. The phial which contains it is cool to the touch, but the vile substance is used to break down the toughest of flesh. The upper limits of its potency as a corrosive is untested and unknown.

The crimson life essence of an adder has many uses in alchemy. In Thaurisgar, it is valuable for its numbing effects, but can be quite deadly if consumed. Ingestion of this substance can result in loss of vital functions. Research suggests it was mainly used as an anesthetic.
The essence of a warg that has been reduced down to its base innate chemical structure by repeated cycles of steeping and simmering at low temperatures for long durations.

Thaurisgar, the Vile Apothecary -- Tier 3 -- Leading the Charge

In the depths of Thaurisgar, countless foul and twisted experiments roam the shadows--the terrible legacy of Aniochán the Harrower. Before the fall of Carn Dûm, Aniochán worked tirelessly to outdo his rivals and win the favour of the Steward of Angmar. Chief among his tools in shaping his fell creations was a curious ichor known only as the Bile of Ifrinn. Thought to be lost after a disastrous experiment claimed Aniochán's life, now this foetid and vile substance is in danger of being let loose into the world.

The foul and twisted experiments have afflicted the creatures that roam within Thaurisgar. These vile creatures must not be allowed to run wild. You should defeat as many as you can before that happens.

Find Gwathrenost
Gwathrenost, the Witch-king's Citadel -- Shadows of the Past

Once the seat of the Witch-king of Angmar, the dread citadel of Gwathrenost casts a long shadow upon the city of Carn Dûm. All but abandoned after the Steward of Angmar was deposed, the remnants of the Iron Crown have crept forth from the shadows, seeking to master a lost artifact of the Witch-king and reclaim dominion of Angmar.

It is rare, indeed, to find this complete volume in such pristine condition. Many of its copies found throughout Middle-earth were mysteriously short of pages, but the Iron Crown has done well to collect them all for those kept within Gwathrenost.
From Tirith Gúlaran, the Witch-king of Angmar, and later, Mordirith, the False King and Steward of Angmar, could watch over all of Carn Dûm and its surrounding lands.

Looming high above Carn Dûm, Gwathrenost was erected long ago during the reign of the Witch-king of Angmar. It was from this nigh-impregnable fortress that Angmar waged its long war against Arnor, devastating the kingdoms of Arthedain, Cardolan, and Rhudaur. After the battle of Fornost turned against the Witch-king of Angmar, it was to Gwathrenost he fled, but he was overtaken by the forces of Eärnur and Glordindel before he could return to Carn Dûm. With Angmar all but destroyed, it laid abandoned for many years until the False King and Steward of Angmar, Mordirith, brought about the first rebirth of Angmar and summoned those still loyal to the iron crown of the Witch-king of Angmar into his service at Carn Dûm.
Kept by the Witch-king of Angmar and, later, the False King and Steward of Angmar, Mordirith, one of the palantíri rested upon this pedestal until the seeing-stone was stolen from Gwathrenost.

It was within this high chamber that Golodir was imprisoned at Gwathrenost, only granted the briefest and most unkind of freedoms on the days he was forced to peer into the palantír at Mordirith's behest. Through all of his suffering, his love for his daughter, Lorniel, never wavered and he dreamt of the day they would at last be reunited. Alas, Mordirith knew well of Golodir's hopes and his faith in those he had left behind at Gath Forthnír....

It was from Tham Mornarcham, long ago, that the Witch-king of Angmar ruled his realm. After he was forced to abandon Angmar, this hall, like all of Carn Dûm, laid empty for many years. However, when Mordirith sought to bring about the rebirth of Angmar, it became the seat of the False King and Steward of Angmar and the high hall of the Iron Crown. It was here that the Ranger Golodir confronted Mordirith in battle, wounded him with the blade, Dúnachar, and forced him into retreat.

Although they were slain during the second downfall of Angmar, Múra, an Angmarim sorceress, and Rodakhan, a woman of the Trév Duvárdain, have not been forgotten among the ranks of the Iron Crown. After the Iron Crown returned to Carn Dûm, their weapons of old, a staff and a halberd, were recovered and ceremonially mounted upon the walls of Gwathrenost. Those who approach these should take care not to disturb them, lest they incur the wrath of the Iron Crown.

Sagroth, Lair of Vermin -- The Seekers of Sagroth
Gárvadach insists there is a prize to be had in the sewers beneath Carn Dûm, but not all who serve him share in this belief, or his apparent willingness to traverse such a foetid place.

Somewhere deeper into the sewer system, they stumbled across what was left of Ogil. Much of the body had already been devoured by whatever foul fauna nested in this place -- so much so that they had trouble identifying him.
Brâc stared at the wreckage of his once-friend. \qWe will die here, searching for a madman's prize.\q
Cruim grabbed his wrist and pulled him back the way they came. \qNo,\q she said, shaking. \qThis whole city is falling to madness. I will not die with it!\q
He wrenched his hand free from her grip. \qThen what are you going to do?\q

\qWe walk with purpose and don't stop until we are out of Angmar,\q Cruim muttered under her breath.
They walked towards the gate of Carn Dûm, an invisible wall of stench affording them privacy from passersby.
\qSomeone will stop us,\q Brâc said. \qThey'll know we are deserting.\q
She scoffed. \qWe smell like someone threw a bundle of hair into a privy and set it all on fire. No one will want to get near us.\q
They remained silent until the gates of Carn Dûm were well behind them.
\qWhere will we go?\q Brâc asked.
\qAnywhere but this doomed place.\q

Cruim sat on the driest patch of stone she could find and removed her left boot. Something wet and spongy slipped out when she upended it, looking like good custard and smelling like old meat -- her prize for straying too close to some slug-like creature.
\qI hate this place,\q she declared.
\qWould you rather be at the glass house?\q asked Brâc, a twig of a man with more sense in his head than muscle on his frame. He was a poor choice for a soldier, but the Iron Crown grew more desperate by the day. It's why they were in this sewer in the first place.

For a while, the two could hear nothing but the sound of their footsteps echo across the tunnel.
\qWhat do you think Gárvadach expects to find here?\q Cruim asked, breaking the silence.
Her companion shrugged. \qI do not know,\q he admitted. \qI cannot think with this odour filling my skull.\q
\qPerhaps he seeks to use the stench itself.\q In an attempt to achieve some measure of Gárvadach's grating affectation, she crossed her arms and wrinkled her nose. \qKneel before me or I shall make you stink like a thousand rotting onions!\q
Brâc rolled his eyes.

As Brâc withdrew his sword from the slug’s corpse, long strings of effluvia clung to the blade. Flicking the sword did nothing to free it from the slime. He grimaced.
Cruim walked past, giving a wide berth to both him and the rapidly liquifying slug. \qYou could run the blade through the water,\q she suggested. \qI'm sure that would help.\q
He eyed the sickly green water with due suspicion. \qI would sooner replace the sword entirely.\q

The War of the Ring is over, but the folk of Gondor must recover from the wounds they suffered at the hands of Sauron's forces. King Elessar desires to travel his kingdom and heal those hurts, but Queen Arwen and the Council of Gondor each want to ensure his safety on such a tour. Foes both old and new threaten to disturb the young peace, and the King of Gondor needs your help to face them and preserve the safety of his kingdom.

The tents of the Haradrim remain at Aegollant, despite the defeat of the Black Serpent at the Battle of Pelennor Fields, but they are now home mostly to brigands and others who hold villainy in their hearts.
The River Erui empties into the Anduin here, and avanc prowl among the reedy banks, threatening unwary travellers.

Orcs and hobgoblins, scattered after the Battle of the Pelennor Fields, have begun to gather in alarming numbers in a camp they call 'Taustrok.' Within dank caves they burrow into the mountainside, threatening to spill over and become a threat to the nearby town of the Harlond.

The ruin of Ost Norhir stands atop the hill overlooking the river south of the Harlond, but now it is inhabited only by wildlife. When the people departed to rebuild their lives in the aftermath of the war, the beasts moved back in to make homes of their own.
Explore enemy encampments and other dangerous places in Lossarnach.
Explore enemy encampments and other dangerous places in Lossarnach.
The encampment that once stood in Galdir's Dell is now burned and unrecognizable. Wargs pad among the scorched wooden structures, and their howls linger on the breezes that sweep over the river.
Find Imloth Melui
Find Arnach

The fields and farms of Nan Harlond stand on either side of the road below the south-harbour of Gondor, no longer threatened by the armies of Sauron but still endangered by occasional foes left behind by their defeated allies. The natural beauty of Lossarnach fights to emerge following the War of the Ring, and the flowers here are a testament to its resilience.

The great wall that is the Rammas Echor encircles Minas Tirith and the Pelennor Fields. During the war, the wall was breached in several places and the forces of Sauron streamed through to lay siege to the White City. Now, dwarves and Gondorian labourers work to repair the damage and shore up the defences once again, though all hope the Rammas will not be needed again for many years.

The Harlond was held by Orcs of Mordor in the days before the Battle of Pelennor Fields, and the creatures burned as many of the Gondorian ships as they could. When Corsair ships flying black sails came up the river from the south, the Orcs were taken by surprise when the banner of the King was raised, revealing the vessels to be commanded by Aragorn and the allies of Gondor. Their arrival on the field of battle proved instrumental in the defence of Minas Tirith and the defeat of Sauron's forces.
Today, the folk of Gondor and dwarves from the White Mountains work to repair and rebuild the south-harbour, hoping that trade and goods will once again flow freely upon the river to ports both near and far.
You have discovered Arnach

Lord Forlong, the ruler of Lossarnach, kept a hall in the village of Arnach until he rode to Minas Tirith during the War of the Ring. He perished in the fighting on the Pelennor and now his hall stands empty, the people of Arnach doing the best they can to go on without their much-loved lord. Arnach remains a bustling settlement for merchants and craftsmen, but the memory of the Haradrim attacks during the previous months remains painful.
Explore settlements and other important points of interest in Lossarnach.
Explore settlements and other important points of interest in Lossarnach.

Imloth Melui, the Vale of Sweet Flowers, is the home of Lady Vanyalos, sister of the Steward Denethor and wife of Forlong, Lord of Lossarnach. Both of these men perished during the war, one inside the walls of the White City and the other without, but the wounds of their passing lie especially deep upon Vanyalos, for she dreamed it would happen and feels the burden of failing to prevent it.
Imloth Melui provides many of the healers who work at the Houses of Healing in Minas Tirith, including the woman Ioreth, who knows a little about an impressive array of things, and an impressive amount about very little.
Find Halach
Find Glaniath
Find Minlos

The small farming community of Glaniath was threatened by Haradrim raiders during the war, and now the people try to pick up the pieces of their lives in the aftermath. Some folk here believe Sirgon's captivity by the Haradrim has made him unfit to rule and his son Faltharan should become Lord of Lebennin in his stead.

Tumladen is the great refuge of Gondor, similar in kind to Helm's Deep in the kingdom of Rohan. During the war, many folk took shelter in Tumladen, including one of Steward Denethor's prickly sisters, the opinionated Lady Terenis. Much to the relief of Captain Imladir, who is responsible for the defence of Tumladen, the Lady Terenis has now returned to Minas Tirith. The sanctuary is no longer crowded with displaced folk of Gondor.

The port city of Pelargir was the site of the pivotal battle against the Corsairs of Umbar during the War of the Ring, when Aragorn commanded the Army of the Dead to seize their ships. Balakhôr the Scourge met his end aboard his grand vessel, the Night-jewel, and it is hoped his death will spell the end of the threat posed by the Heirs of Castamir.
The Gondorian fleet is in shambles following the War of the Ring, and it will be the task of Sirgon, Lord of Lebennin, to rebuild the kingdom's ships and sea-power as quickly as possible. To that end, the city of Pelargir is filled with the sound of hammers and axes at all hours of the day and night.

The beacon of Sirthanc was lit during the war to summon warriors to defend Minas Tirith, but it is now quenched. If the fortune of Gondor holds, it will remain extinguished for many years. It was at Sirthanc that Lord Sirgon was rescued from the captivity of the Haradrim, and now some of his folk believe he should be allowed to step down as Lord of Lebennin so he may heal the wounds of his mind and body.

The beacon of Minlos is the nearest to Minas Tirith, and was seized by Haradrim raiders during the war as they attempted to move against the village of Arnach. Now the beacon has been extinguished and folk of nearby farms hope it will remain unlit for many years, a signal the danger has passed.
Explore settlements and other important points of interest in Upper Lebennin.
Explore settlements and other important points of interest in Upper Lebennin.
The small harbour of Halach was abandoned to the Haradrim during the war, but the defeat of Sauron has allowed the townsfolk to return and begin the long process of rebuilding their lives and homes.
Find Lhingar
Find Sadúkh's Camp
Find Grafeleg

In the aftermath of the War of the Ring, some of the Corsairs fled into the wild and sought to seize victory from their apparent defeat. This is the camp of Sadúkh, who believes he is the one to unify the Corsairs beneath his banner.
After the war's ending, some of the Corsairs fled into the wild in order to regroup. This is the camp of Múshex, who seeks to unify the Corsairs beneath his own banner.
After their defeat at Pelargir, some of the Corsairs escaped into the wild. This is the camp of Hárba, who believes his victory is not far off.
After their defeat at Pelargir, some of the Corsairs escaped into the wild. This is the camp of Bukhád, who is certain that his warriors will have victory if they can recover their strength.

The cave of Grafeleg is tucked into the mountains behind Tumladen, and the bears that dwell within have generally not troubled the residents of the refuge, the folk of Gondor reciprocating in kind. However, with many more folk dwelling behind the walls of Tumladen while the war raged, tensions with those living nearby have been inflamed.
Explore enemy encampments and other dangerous places in Upper Lebennin.
Explore enemy encampments and other dangerous places in Upper Lebennin.

The spiders of Lhingar were not stymied by the waging of the War of the Ring, and they were not hindered by its ending. They creep still among the trees, spinning webs to catch their prey and feasting upon any who stray too near their den.
Find Ost Anglebed
Find Malbarth
Find Erynos

The small village of Malbarth escaped much of the fighting during the war, but tidings from other areas of Gondor filled the townsfolk here with trepidation and fear that their homes would not remain safe for long. Even now there are whispers that some Corsairs fled from the battle at Pelargir and hide now in the wilderness, awaiting their chance to seize the town.

The city of Linhir spans the River Gilrain, and during the War of the Ring the sky here was darkened by foul craft of Sauron. The sons of Comeldir organized the defences, and when the fighting at last was ended, the people stood strong, less divided than their city. Today, with the threat of war behind them and the skies bright and clear once again, the folk of Linhir have returned to their lives.

This small village on the River Serni escaped most of the fighting during the war, but the report of Corsairs and half-trolls attacking other nearby towns filled the residents with dread, as did the darkened skies brought on by the Dawnless Day. Today, the folk of Sarnhad seek to return to their ordinary lives.

Nestled in the forest south of the dwarf-stronghold of Furukzahar, Zarsatrâd serves as an outpost for the Temámir dwarves who live now in the White Mountains. They work to transport quarried stone to various locations in Gondor, eager to help their neighbours repair and rebuild following the War of the Ring... for a reasonable price.

The stronghold of Furukzahar is a bastion of safety for the Temámir Dwarves of the White Mountains. Under the rule of their leader Hámisar, dwarves from any clan are welcome to visit, but relations with the people of Gondor are not especially warm at the moment. Hámisar's decision to shut the doors of Furukzahar and not participate in the War of the Ring has not endeared the dwarves to the residents of Lebennin.

The settlement of Erynos was the site of one of the stranger occurrences of the war, when a number of Corsair raiders were discovered outside the walls of town, apparently drowned. Some folk believe this was the work of the Five Sisters of Lebennin, river-maidens thought to protect the lands through which their rivers flow, but some say they are only figures of myth.
Today the folk of Erynos work to restore their lives and aid those of their neighbours who suffered during the war.

Explore settlements and other important points of interest in Lower Lebennin.

The large city of Ost Anglebed is home to the keepers of the beacon of Amon Anglebed, which was lit during the War of the Ring. Unlike the other beacons of Gondor, the beacon here remains lit despite the arrival of the King's peace. Now the guards maintain a vigil over the townsfolk, fearful that some allies of disloyal Malthellim may think to continue his work and turn control of the town over to foes of Gondor.
Find Thama Aklam
Find Hata Kebir
Find Lornost

The war-camp of Hata Kebir served as one of the primary settlements constructed by the Haradrim and Corsairs that united to threaten Lebennin and the greater lands of Gondor. In the days since the end of the war, brigands have congregated within its bounds and endanger the King's peace.

The Corsairs of Umbar burned the port of Ethillorn as part of their campaign to conquer Gondor for Sauron. Now that the war has ended the Corsairs have gone, but a darker evil has come to Ethillorn and now threatens the surrounding lands.

Lured from the snowy peaks of the White Mountains by the sound of industry at the quarry of Aban-bazan, ferocious snow-beasts have made new dens in the woods of Lebennin. Gnawed bones and filthy carcasses lie in piles beneath the trees and among the rocks, a testament to the beasts' insatiable hunger.

The ruins of Lornost remain a sad reminder of the cruelty inflicted by the Heirs of Castamir and their Haradrim allies: when the folk of Lornost refused to surrender, they were slaughtered and the castle reduced to rubble. Now only wild beasts walk the paths of Lornost, and a cruel breeze drifts among the abandoned buildings.
Explore enemy encampments and other dangerous places in Lower Lebennin.
Explore enemy encampments and other dangerous places in Lower Lebennin.

The war-camp of Thama Aklam was constructed during the war by Haradrim forces seeking to accomplish the aims of Mordor. With the defeat of Sauron, the war-camp has become home instead to brigands and other unsavoury types.
